Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Saturday! [KONTROL] with Sammy Dee (perlon:berlin) + Alex Under LIVE (cmyk:madrid)

------=_Part_78287_23588004.1172790008407
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

I think Monica mentioned this party on SFR already, but for those of you
interested in the full details, here they are.  We're really, really
excited about this one.  We're going until at least 8am (including 1.5 hour=
s
of Alex Under live and 3 hours of Sammy Dee) so you better rest up!


Saturday, March 3rd

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every first Saturday at the Endup


featuring from Berlin, Germany:

SAMMY DEE  ( perlon . poker flat . kanzleramt)

Sammy Dee is one half of Pantytec alongside production partner
and Perlon label founder Zip.  His incredible forward-thinking DJ
sets have helped shape the sound of minimal house and techno
worldwide for over a decade, and have made their legendary
monthly party, "Get Perlonized", the toast of Berlin.


and from Madrid, Spain:

ALEX UNDER -  Live PA  ( plus 8 . trapez . cmyk musik . apnea )

Spain's scorching hot Alex Under has gained international acclaim in
the last few years for his fresh, cerebral, and energetic take on live
techno. Add to that his superb production work and a top-notch
record label, and you've got one of the hottest tickets on the planet
right now.


plus special guest from Seattle:

KRISTINA CHILDS  ( decibel festival . plasmodium radio . krakt! )


with resident DJs:

CRAIG KUNA   ( concept sf . esdjco )
NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( liebe detail . floppy funk )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )

________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 8am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________

Full bios, pics and lots FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K21FB.jpg
Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K21BB.jpg

____________________________________________________


SAMMY DEE  (of Pantytec, Schneider & Radecki, Half Hawaii)

With a career in electronic music spanning nearly two decades, Sammy Dee
(aka Mario Radecki) has built and solidified a reputation for himself as an
innovator of eclectic, off kilter sounds. He began to DJ in Kassel in the
late eighties, soon after returning to his hometown of Berlin, hosting
residencies at Tresor and Ostgut. A particular night, which made Ostgut's
Panorama bar famous, is Get Perlonized, one of the most consistently
successful club nights in Europe.  Along with co-organizer, Pantytec
production partner and Perlon label founder Zip, they put together a
showcase for the unique sounds of Perlon that would unknowingly influence
many worldwide. Complementing Zip, Sammy's unique sets of minimal house and
techno have always proved to be one of the foundations of the night.  When
Sammy is on the decks there is no doubt why he is recognized as one of the
key veterans and icons of the electronic music scene. Currently on the
production side, both a new solo project and a collaboration with Bruno
Pronsato are crystallizing. A departure from his co-productions with Zip,
Guido Schneider, and Baby Ford, you will just have to keep your ears tuned.


Sammy Dee's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Sammy%20Dee

Sammy Dee on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/deesammy


MUSIC:

Pantytec - Maybe (Perlon)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K21/Pantytec_-_Maybe

Sammy Dee & Guido Schneider - Styleways  (Poker Flat)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K21/Sammy_Dee_and_Guido_Schneider_-_Styleways.mp3

_________________________________________________


ALEX UNDER (aka Friendly People, Dolly La Parton, of Musica Charlista)

The deepest meaning of 'collage', defined by Max Ernst, is the general
application of Arthur Rimabaud's 'delirium': "I accustomed myself to simple
hallucination; I saw quite deliberately a mosque instead of a factory, a
drummer's school conducted byangels, carriages on the highways of the sky, =
a
salon at the bottom of a lake: monsters, mysteries, a vaudeville poster
raising horrors before my eyes."  We could describe collage as an alchemic
compound of two or more heterogeneous elements, derivate by their unexpecte=
d
approximation generated deliberately by the search of systematic confusion
and distorted perception.

That's Alex Under's musical universe. Based in Madrid, this producer is the
'CMYK' label manager. He is also one of the men behind 'Apnea' and
'Bemysheep', and one of the founders of Net28 (the net behind these labels
and others like 'CyclicalTracks' and 'Pulpa'). Alex Under confirmed himself
as the new reality of the best international techno, sometimes being minima=
l
and deep, sometimes hard and aggressive, but always original. He creates a
sonic collage combining techno, trance and house elements while he
constructs complex rhythms that arise from the dancefloor, taking the
listeners to a higher level where emotions, depth, mind & body blend in a
unique equation. Alex Under will intrigue beyond your perception.


Alex Under's website:
http://www.cmykmusik.com/

Alex's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Alex%20Under

CMYK MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/cmykmusik


MUSIC:

Alex Under - El Encuentro  (Plus 8)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF209389-01-01-01.mp3

Friendly People - 99.9  (Apnea)
http://mp3.juno.co.uk/MP3/SF245690-01-02-02.mp3

____________________________________________________


KRISTINA CHILDS

As well as being a guest DJ at many clubs in and around the Seattle area,
Kristina Childs has played in Frankfurt, Bogot=E1, Medellin, Dallas, New Yo=
rk,
Portland, and Coeur D'Alene. She has held residencies at Seattle clubs
Contour, Habana's, Art Bar, See Sound Lounge, and is a current resident of
Tost, and Seattle's infamous techno monthly, aptly named Krakt. She runs
Plasmodium Radio and is the Sponsorship Coordinator for Seattle's Decibel
Festival.


Kristina Childs' website:
http://www.kristinachilds.com/

Kristina on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kristinachilds


DJ MIX:

Kristina Childs - Live @ Decibel, 2006
http://www.kristinachilds.com/music/mixes/decibel_2006.mp3


_____________________________________________________

http://www.kontrolsf.com

Subject: [sfraves] my interviewes w/ Lee Burridge & Ethan & Alex 

Again.. these were done @ Love Fest 06 in the VIP room for :code TV..
unfortunately the show itself has never been editted together & i just now
got the interviews from the Exec Producer 'cause he just put them online
like now now!

OK.. disclaimer again, i was mondo sleep dep & Hello 2Day, like i'd have a
thought, ask a question, but like didn't know exactly how to verbalize
where i was gonna go with it 'cause I was sooo confuzed, tired, amped on
caffine, & stuff & it was kinda hard connecting the dots @ times & grrr, I
wish i could go back & do them again, but it's fun for what came out :n) !

With the Lee Burridge interview, it was my 1st interview that day & his
manager, or whoever that lady was, told me to ask specific questions &
blah, so confuzing! For interviewing Ethan, I mean.. Ethan's my big bro &
it's like i needed to do an interview that day with someone i knew already
just to like i dunno... but but but... like I kinda blanked on what i had
planned on asking him & just went by train of thought & stuff...

So here ya go... Enjoy:

Lee Burridge ... oh yeah... he's like this mondo Proggy/ Tech House &
Minimal Techno Producer/DJ...
http://blip.tv/file/135046

Ethan & Alex (from Friends N FAmily)
http://blip.tv/file/129589


& here's the DJ Rap interview if u didn't see it already ;n)
http://blip.tv/file/129563


Tell me what you think & stuff!! Love U all!
Love U All again!!!! {{HUGZ}}}

Subject: RE: [sfraves] BSP: Opulent Temple Breaks Party Tonight!! 

Friday, March 2nd.

Opulent Temple's first step into the greening of BRC in '07 :: Behind the 
Green Door

Yes. After our best year ever in '06, we'll be back with an elevated camp 
experience and production that will go beyond everything we've done to date.

Seriously!

Of course, it will only happen with your continued support and investment in 
your future fun. It works like this - you step up for us in SF, and we'll 
step up for you in Black Rock City.

We welcome none other than UK breaks sensation

Hyper (djhyper.com / UK) to help us blast off our fundraising season.

Also with

Syd Gris (Opel / Opulent Temple)
Spesh (Looq / Qool)
ICON (djicon.com / Reverb)
Billy Cassazza (Nutbass / Opulent Temple)
Layne Loomis (Deep End)
Dulce Vita (Opulent Temple),

and more tba...

At Mighty, 119 Utah St. @ 15th.

$10 pre-sale on sale @ www.opulenttemple.org

$15 at door if playafied (just make an effort!)
$20 street clothes

http://www.opulenttemple.org/archives/030207/030207-OT_front-535.jpg

http://www.opulenttemple.org/archives/030207/030207-OT_back-535.jpg

Twenty-Seven year old Guy Hatfield is a man with a mission. Heralded as the 
new Breakbeat leader of the pack and the hardest workingman in the UK dance 
scene, he continues to turn heads and push boundaries to great acclaim.

Hypers pioneering Y3K compilation albums secured his name in the dance 
scene as one to watch and spawned many copycat Breakbeat albums. Guy went on 
to surpass expectations with his world-renowned Bedrock Breaks CDs and can 
lay claim to the biggest selling full price Breakbeat comps to date.

Hypers unique DJ sets, sliding between genres, have earned him the respect 
of fellow pioneers, Paul Oakenfold, John Digweed, Timo Maas and BT (who 
lists him as one of his favourite DJs). Through shear hard work and over 
the last few years Guy has also achieved one of his main aims in taking 
Breakbeat from a backroom stalwart to a main room attraction blowing away 
many larger (and higher paid) jocks worldwide who commit to a more limited 
sound.

He regularly is asked to guest mix on BBC Radio 1 for DJs Annie 
Nightingale, Seb Fontaine and Fergie. Hyper frequently tours Stateside where 
he is considered as one of the (if not THE) scenes leading lights. He is a 
popular and frequent guest at the US largest clubs Spundae and Buzz. All 
this activity and profile lead to Hyper being chosen as the support DJ for 
Breakbeats biggest band, The Crystal Method on tour in the USA in spring 
04.

In the studio Guy has been writing his much anticipated debut artist album. 
Recent releases on Timo Maas label 4:20 Recordings have proven a successful 
teaser of what1s to come. Guys production style contains the strong 
elements and main room crossover one has come to expect from his dance floor 
filling remixes. He has built on the notoriety of his mix (now a Breakbeat 
anthem) of 2001's biggest track 'Addicted To Bass', and other charting acts 
Filter and Joy Kitikonti. Hypers popular remix of Terminalhead was also 
chosen for a Radio 1 TV ad campaign.

Recently Guy has also collaborated with some of his favourite producers 
General Midi, Uberzone, Rui Da Silva and John Ross (one time production 
partner of both Sasha and BT), the results are groundbreaking.

Some genuinely great club remixes and productions have naturally attracted 
the attention of major labels and artist seeking to find a credible remixer 
for use on their artist forthcoming releases. Hyper first major label remix 
came for Pink Trouble and God Is A DJ, remixed to such a high standard 
that Pink herself has asked that he be considered for remix duty on all her 
future singles. Also this year Hyper has remixed Sugababes, Paul Van Dyk, 
Sarah McLauchlane, The Crystal Method and BT.

Hyper also runs his own successful breaks label Kilowatt. Artists signed to 
the label include Terminalhead, Stir Fry, Flatliners, General Midi, False 
Prophet and MobileGazer  singles available now.

The promotion company Waxworks he set up is still the biggest in Breaks 
after 7 years. Guy is also DJ Magazines specialist breakbeat reviewer.

Hyper is one of THE best technical DJs in Breakbeat, expect much more from 
him and expect your expectations to be surpassed.




SFR: Ranger
San Francisco
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see

>successful teaser of what1s to come. Guys production style contains the 
>strong elements and main room crossover one has come to expect from his 
>dance floor filling remixes. He has built on the notoriety of his mix (now 
>a Breakbeat anthem) of 2001's biggest track 'Addicted To Bass', and other 
>charting acts Filter and Joy Kitikonti. Hypers popular remix of 
>Terminalhead was also chosen for a Radio 1 TV ad campaign.
>
>Recently Guy has also collaborated with some of his favourite producers 
>General Midi, Uberzone, Rui Da Silva and John Ross (one time production 
>partner of both Sasha and BT), the results are groundbreaking.
>
>Some genuinely great club remixes and productions have naturally attracted 
>the attention of major labels and artist seeking to find a credible remixer 
>for use on their artist forthcoming releases. Hyper first major label remix 
>came for Pink Trouble and God Is A DJ, remixed to such a high standard 
>that Pink herself has asked that he be considered for remix duty on all her 
>future singles. Also this year Hyper has remixed Sugababes, Paul Van Dyk, 
>Sarah McLauchlane, The Crystal Method and BT.
>
>Hyper also runs his own successful breaks label Kilowatt. Artists signed to 
>the label include Terminalhead, Stir Fry, Flatliners, General Midi, False 
>Prophet and MobileGazer  singles available now.
>
>The promotion company Waxworks he set up is still the biggest in Breaks 
>after 7 years. Guy is also DJ Magazines specialist breakbeat reviewer.
>
>Hyper is one of THE best technical DJs in Breakbeat, expect much more from 
>him and expect your expectations to be surpassed.
>
>
>
>
>SFR: Ranger
>San Francisco
>plurranger@hotmail.com
>Who knows where the night leads
>It's dark and no one can see
>
>_________________________________________________________________
>The average US Credit Score is 675. The cost to see yours: $0 by Experian. 
>http://www.freecreditreport.com/pm/default.aspx?sc=660600&bcd=EMAILFOOTERAVERAGE

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - Ambient Mafia happy hour this Friday!

-----FRESCO FRIDAYS-----
"A Happy Hour you can't refuse."
DOWNTEMPO - TRIPHOP - ACID JAZZ - LOUNGE     
DRINK SPECIALS!!       
2nd FRIDAY of the month
5PM - 12 MIDNIGHT       
@ THE MINT LOUNGE
414 JESSIE (JESSIE/MINT)
 
============
Join the AMBIENT MAFIA every month at the Mint Lounge, as we
give your stress and tension a pair of cement shoes, and dump
'em in the bay to sleep with the fishes...

Bringing you the illest in chill, and a groove so smoove...
it's criminal.
  
Proceeds from this monthly installment will go to the costs
incurred from Matt Jakes' wake.  Donations are welcomed and
encouraged, and for every donation we receive, we'll be handing
out an Ambient Mafia cd as thanks.
 
FRIDAY March 9th, 2007
DJs: 
drop (Ambient Mafia)
Calamity Jane (Ambient Mafia, WoM SF)
sixty4k (Ambient Mafia, Mirai Kanai)
Big Sloppy (Ambient Mafia, High Jinx)
Actual Rafiq (Ambient Mafia, the dRow)
Hickory (Ambient Mafia, The Extra Credit)
SeventhSwami (Ambient Mafia, Want It)
 
FRIDAY APRIL 6th, 2007
DJ Lineup TBA soon!!
(We'll keep ya posted, bambinos!) 
 
***********************************************************
 
After you're done unwinding and you feel it's a good time to
step up the pulse, head out to Stimulus at Le Duplex (1525
MIssion @ 11th St, SF) - 10pm - 4am:  $5 before 11 pm, $10
after - 1-888-650-6660 for more info  -  21+
 
Yes! Our electrotech-centric party is finally just around the
corner. We're really excited about this new endeavor, and we
hope you can join us for this night of nothing but
four-on-the-floor, techy electro deliciousness...

Bouncing, banging, thumping, gritty and raw, electrotech is one
of our favorite dancefloor grooves. Our goal is to celebrate
and fruther spread this sound... join us on this excursion into
electrotech, and get stimulated.

Friday, March 9th
Stimulus-Response Productions Presents:
STIMULUS: EXCURSIONS INTO ELECTROTECH

Featuring the electrofied beats of:

Audiovoid (aka Layerz, Muti Music, MDEX)
vs. Dirt (Cymbalic / Omniscient Records)
Evinrude (Space Cowboys / NetAmp Radio)
Halon (Fake Science / False Profit)
Kinesis (Santa Cruz)
Mozaic (Nexus / Raindance)
Robb Green (Shameless / Tilted Records)
 
http://images.tribe.net/tribe/upload/photo/a51/8c8/a518c8f5-4abd-4866-9409-2478e644448d

Subject: [sfraves] renting gear in Washington, D.C.?

Anyone have experience renting gear in Washington D.C. and have 
anyone to recommend?

Gear in this case is as defined two Technics 1200s and any
of the following (or similar):
Pioneer DJM-600 or better
Allen and Heath X-One 92 or better
Rane MP2016a/XP2016a

If they have lighting rental that's not crazy expensive or
consumes massive amounts of power, that would be helpful
too.

Thanks.

--

> To: <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> Subject: Guest Lecture by Matthew Baggott at UC-Santa Cruz, this  
> Friday, 3/9
>
> Hi,
>
> I'm writing to you today to pass along a special announcement from  
> ASPIRE, a
> student group at UC-Santa Cruz, that will be hosting psychedelic  
> researcher
> Matthew Baggott this Friday for a guest lecture. MAPS staff will be  
> on hand
> to distribute literature, and to speak either before or after the  
> event.
>
> Best Wishes,
> Jag Davies
> MAPS Director of Communications
> http://www.maps.org
>
> ********************************************
>
> Seeing Patterns:
> Clinical Studies with Psychedelics
> A Guest Lecture by Matthew Baggott
>
> UCSC CAMPUS
> March 9th 5:00 P.M.
> Physical Science Building Seminar, Room 240
>
> Psychedelic research in humans? Is that even legal? After decades of
> regulatory restriction, scientists in the U.S. are again studying
> psychedelics in humans. In the
> intervening decades, science has dramatically advanced, with many  
> findings
> and tools relevant to psychedelics. While studies using animals and  
> cells
> have deepened our
> knowledge, they have done so without lessening our puzzlement. Can
> scientific research with human volunteers adequately address the  
> unusual
> effects of psychedelics?
> Matthew Baggott will discuss the challenges of human psychedelic  
> research
> and what we can hope to learn. He will outline a modest program for
> research, emphasizing
> measurement of phenomenology as an important step and illustrate the
> approach with preliminary results from his ongoing research.
>
> Matthew Baggott is a graduate student in neuroscience at the Helen  
> Wills
> Neuroscience Institute, University of California Berkeley. In the  
> mid 1990s,
> he was part of the first team of researchers to gain federal  
> funding to
> study MDMA in humans. In his current research, he continues to  
> study the
> clinical pharmacology and neuroscience of MDMA
> and classical psychedelics.
>
> For more information about this event, contact: aspire_core@ucsc.edu
>
>
>
> *************************************************
>
> Jag Davies
> Director of Communications
> The Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies
> MAPS :: 10424 Love Creek Road :: Ben Lomond, CA 95005
> Tel. 831.336.HEAL (4325) :: Cel. 831.252.0023 :: Fax. 831.336.3665
> jag@maps.org
>
>
> **********************************************************
> Advocating Science over Politics,
> Replacing Fear with Facts:
> Your Support is Needed! http://www.maps.org/catalog
>
>
>
>


--Apple-Mail-1--597077208--

Yeah...it was all right.  MSTRKRFT opened though and hurt my ears.  One of
the worst sets of music I have ever experienced.  Just loud noise, no flow
at all...there were moments where it sounded like it would go off, but it
never did.  the vibe was ruined, Digweed was cool, but didn't go on until
1:30...I left around 2:30 though because I couldn't take the crowd anymore
(normally I don't care about those things, but for some reason, things were
just not right for me there).

OK ppl, a friend sent this to me. *I do not mean any harm by any of this* I thought it was hilarious and want to share it with you =)
   
  
 
        San Francisco    From Encyclopedia Dramatica  
         
The San Francisco skyline. Notice the unique archtecture people believe makes us targets for TERRORISM!


  San Fransico is famous for its gay and being the center of California's homosexual loving status. It's expensive, full of yuppies, goths, and wannabe artists. Burning Man started here, as if that were anything to be proud of. San Francisco also holds one of the largest LSD supplies. 
  It's pretty, but has the same problems as Los Angeles: nice exterior, but not much depth. At least the air is breathable. 
  San Francisco is home to the Golden Gate Bridge, which is the most popular bridge in the world. That is, if you want to jump off a bridge and kill yourself. Remember that when you're planning your next trip and/or suicide. If you want to see the most famous bridge in the world, you are on the wrong side of the country, as the Brooklyn Bridge is in New York. 
  [edit]
  Areas of San Francisco   San Francisco is usually somewhat over-extended to include the entire San Francisco Gay Area, which encompasses at least three distinct areas: 
  

San Francisco Proper: The city of San Francisco is culturally and artistically amazing, especially when you consider the small size of the city. This is probably due to all the gay there. Like any major urban area, the city is full of hipsters, but the ones in SF are especially annoying because they think because the city is artistic they must be too. Overall though, San Francisco is cultured and a nice place to hang out. Despite what hepkitten may tell you, Brisbane is not a part of San Francisco.          
In this park, you too can take this photo, just like in postcards! YAY!


  The South Bay: Roughly extending from Redwood City down to San Jose, the South Bay is a cultural wasteland and a large suburb to San Francisco. Except for the $1,000,000 you'll pay for a home, there's nothing to distinguish any of the South Bay from the suburbs of any other major city. Note that this area also includes what is sometimes referred to as the Peninsula, to some people, to others the Peninsula is a separate region. The Peninsula is most of San Mateo County. It extends roughly down to the area below Palo Alto. 
  The East Bay: Oakland and the surrounding area is much like San Francisco proper, except a bit more suburban, a bit cheaper, and with a bit more murder. Oakland is also the home of the Black Panthers. Berkeley is famous for being home to all the bitter liberals that have been pissed off since Nixon was elected. While Oakland is sometimes jealous of San Francisco, the East Bay has a surprising amount of arts, culture, and fun without ever having to cross the bridge to San Francisco. Also, the East Bay has a great view of beautiful San Francisco, while San Francisco has a view of Oakland. Also also, Beast in Pig Latin is East Bay, so it must be cool. 
  Fisherman's Wharf: The northern waterfront area of San Francisco from Ghirardelli Square or Van Ness Street, ass pirates descend from ships and rape young boys like Catholic priests. The villagers live in constant fear of the local pirate population. The intro video of ABC's Full House features Fisherman's Wharf, with scenes of Bob Faget. 
  The North Bay: Also known as Marin county, the richest per-capita county in America, or "utter shit." The North Bay is the only part of the Bay Area with no BART, primarily because they care more about property values and keeping out "undesirable influences" than the integrity of the community. The people who live in Marin are either ex-hippies with a lot of money (usually from real estate) who want to fuck over black people without having to deal with them, their entitled children, or (most recently) successful members of Generation X who are only seen in public pregnant, with a stroller, and a latte from Starbucks. Unless you're willing to put down $30 for a 75 minute folk show starting at 6:30, there's nothing to do within the county limits but crystal meth or psychosis. Every teenager who grew up in Marin wants to move to Europe. 
  The Coastside: To the south of San Francisco proper, even below South San Francisco, lies Pacifica. The coastside extends from there all the way down to an interesting hybrid hippie/hickville called Half Moon Bay. Don't be fooled though: the city of Half Moon Bay and all the little minor towns to the north of it are unbearably dull and the only decent thing to ever come from there was a fuckload of meth. Pacifica, which has a closer proximity to the actual city, is less dull and has more blacks. Actually, most KKK meetings have more blacks than Half Moon Bay does. 
  The Clubs: San Fransisco is notorious for the amount of titty-bars, and strip clubs that could be seen by just driving a couple city blocks. Most of them being ran by jews, attract many a thousand. In certain areas of "the city", such as the Castro District, California's asshole, as /b/ is the internet's asshole, there can be found many gay bars. These are usually peaceful, but make great targets for terrorism, or a public display of hatred.

You're welcome!

Ya, that was me back there in the corner seeing what I could output.  We're 
gonna make sur eto have a sub next time.  The gal that hooked us up with 
sound wasn't expecting me to push the subsonic ranges.

First set was pretty much all power noize.  Lots of the new Terrorfakt with 
a little This Morn Omina thrown in (tribal noize).  Second set was more 
gothic, Skinny puppy stuff with Helium Vola and other stuff.

I don't write anything down or preplan much.  I sorta watch what mike is 
doing on stage and try to match it up with whatever comes to mind, thats' 
why the sudden flip to a little Lords of Acid.

I agree that MSTRKRFT was disappointing and technically flawed (they need to
learn to beatmatch).  Definitely killed the vibe somewhat, and the crowd
seemed like there were a good number of people there for MSTRKRFT that
didn't know what Digweed is about.

Digweed played dark and techy, the kind of set that really sucks you in.
The first two hours seemed deliberate, the last hour he went nuts on the
filters and effects and playing crazy stuff.  I loved every minute of it,
stayed until the end.  He dropped Saints & Sinners - Pushin Too Hard, the
new Valentino Kazyani remix of Nathan Fake - Outhouse, and Apollo 440 -
Liquid Cool as far as classics that I recognized.  Also some good stuff off
of his new Transitions CD and recent transitions sets.  All in all, maybe
not the most perfect Digweed night but the music still beat the pants off of
almost anything else (if you ignored mstrkrft).

I agree, typically the crowd at ruby is better after the bar closes.  But
everytime I go there, without fail, I have all sorts of creepy guys trying
to grab me from behind while I'm dancing and 'claim' me.  It just is
unpleasant.  I have had many wonderful experiences there though (such as
Sasha right after Thanksgiving).

For whatever reason, MSTRKRFT killed my roll...and by the time Digweed was
getting going, I just needed a break from it all.  I wish I could have stuck
it out, but when the vibe isn't right, I choose to leave so I don't drag
anybody down with me.  So, my friend Keith (DJ Deckard) invited a few over
to his and he played some yummy electro for us!

Subject: [sfraves] WR: Danny's Going Away Shingdig Adventure

So I got to the City around like ummmm... 7:30ish & got off Civic Center/
8th street from BART & actually had this mondo pleasant & musical walk to
Transfer (Thanks to my ipod).. i fuckin' swear man.. i either felt like i
was in a music video or like well.. i practiced my model walk down the cat
walk a few times :)  Got to Transfer & slowly people started slowly
showing up.. HELLO 2DAY.. I swear man.. Heeeeella People from the Rave
Retirement Home came out to play!!  I swear man.. there were sooo many old
skool FnFers out & about!  Even Fuckin' Terrac, who disappeared last year,
showed up & was apparently visiting for the weekend 'cause fucker lives in
Oregan now & didn't tell anyone he moved!  But yeah.. it was Dope seeing
sooo many people & i swear man.. if it was a warehouse, lol, yeah... it
was just a Dope reunion!

Music was alright!!  It's started out w/ alota proggy house/ breaks to
some yummy Electro-ie kinda Grooves to "glitch"ie music to house... No
Techno :(  Oh Well!  But it was fun just dancing w/ everyone who was
there!!  I honestly spent alota time outside socializing & reconnecting w/
people!  Fave sets that night were definetly Mizz Calamity Jane's & DRC's
sets.. i swear man.. i was like hella drunk @ the beginning 'cause an old
Homie bought me strong drinks  & I swear I didn't see/ hear Forest Spin   
:(   There was oooh.. Nikita who closed was Dope too!! :)  Oh yeah..
Scotty Hampton (if some of you remember) came out to party!

So when Transfer closed, we all migrated to the old Cloud Factory house in
the Castro & partied somemore!!  We were there for like almost an hour
just kickin' it well, I ate like mini cup cakes, cheese, chips/ dip, &
oooh.. Pocky Sticks!!!  Actually.. there was like 2 unopened boxes that
the hostess bought for the party that no one touched & gave to me to take
home!!  I even met this Austrailian dude/ foreign exchange student who
lives there!  He was fun!!

Oh yeah... so like alota people who were @ Transfer like went home or
other events that night... so there was actually like 15-20 of us left...
so after we left the CF house, we went to check out that Jeno/ GArth
warehouse shindig in the Mission.. as soon as we got there, like from the
looks of what was outside, Limos, people dressed up like it was Sound
FActory, etc, yeah... total Froo Froo crowd.. someone in the crew spoke w/
the promoter 'cause we tried to get like group discount to get in, but
no... $20 each person.. so we said fuck it & left!!  I mean.. the music
did sound alright, but man... i was fiending sooooooooooo hard for more
breaks or some jungle & wasn't too much in the mood for more house tbh! 
Also, alota people in our Danny ontourage were broke like me (shut up), so
yeah, we tried thinking of other ways of free entertainment!

We almost went to End Up, but didn't... then we went to this Speak Easy in
the Mission as well, but that was closed.  So we ended up giong to someone
Dude's house in the the Haight & kicked it for like 2 hours i guess...
lol.. more people came & met up w/ us there...  LoL.. oh oh ohohoho h oh
oh wait.. the most fuckin' trippy part of the early morn...

So we were still in the Mission.. walkin' back from the closed speak easy
& this Limo was like coming down the rode... Danny flagged it down & w/in
15 mintues, we were on this hella early morning ride to the Haight in a
fuckin' Limo!!  Heeeeeeello 2Daaay!!  So fun!!!  Oh my gosh man.. that was
Awesome!!  It was totally mondo my 1st time in a Limo & it was perfect!!!

OK.... so it was around like 6:45 now & we all packed up & went to Shadow
Lounge for their Sunday Morning party!  Well.. it was interesting 'cause
like i mean... between 3 DJs who were like ummmm... totally tagging, I
only like 1 of the DJs who dropped proper yummy music for my traste that
early in the morning!!  I mean.. he totally got off on alota breaks &
electro & some proggy this n that when the other 2 DJs, while i was there,
only played like house.. lol

Ooh yeah... so i was talkin' to the bouncer & man... i swear.. i Love
talkin' to bouncers 'cause I found out alota stuff about the club he
normally bounces @ ummmm.. Clash or Flash or whatever.. but yeah... lol...
Hello 2Day... he told me alota Yummy tidbits about that vlub & Tommy Lee
who's a montly "resident" @ that club!  LoL.. all he does is stand behind
the DJ & throws his hands... LOLOLOLMAO!!!  Anywaze, yeah... the group was
now down to like 12 people & we all danced, laughed, lounged on the sofas,
drank, took pictures!!  I mean.. it was a really good way to like get up
the energy again to take bart home!!!

So around 15 past 8AM.. me & Scotty headed over to BART & went home!!  But
I'm tellin' ya man... it was a fucki'n FUN ASS NIGHT!!!  YAAAAY!!!

ok.. I promise to cath up on all my WRs & stuff this week!!  I know, I
know,.. i'm hella laggin'...

Love All U RaverS!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

you know, i took a break from star trek for like the past year and  
due to just traveling and stuff i missed most of the original airings  
of enterprise.  right now they're on scifi monday nights from 7-11.   
i like the show but i think they lost people by doing a prequel  
rather than continuing along another show either 24th century based  
or maybe even an anthology based series which i think would have been  
the best, that way you have different actors and situations.  plus  
captain kirk commanding the enterprise for 20 years with the same  
crew isn't realistic.  but there's some fun episodes and all in all  
it's a fun show.  check it out for sure.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [NRR] star trek (was: (nrr) QOD (Tue))

I'm a huge trekker, even formed the Star Trek Club back in HS (its still
going and now called the Sci-Fi club).

Yes ST XI should be interesting, hopefully they will do better than the
nextgen movies (my fav is still #6). It will be out by xmas08:

http://www.trektoday.com/news/270207_02.shtml

There are still casting rumors floating about (refer to link at the end of
the article) but if they are true it does worry me a bit.

Gary Sinise as Bones, Adrien Brody as Spock and Matt Damon as Kirk? The
first two arent so bad, but Matt Damon as Kirk? Yikes! That boy cant act his
way out of a nutsack! Oh wait, nor could Shatner...maybe it is a good match.

I was a big fan of Enterprise, the show was awesome around the third season
(like most of the other trek series). Was very sorry to see it go. Most
people would argue differently but DS9 is still my favorite series, go
Defiant!

-Smithers

now

e
like now now!

OK.. disclaimer again, i was mondo sleep dep & Hello 2Day, like i'd hav=
e a
thought, ask a question, but like didn't know exactly how to verbalize
where i was gonna go with it 'cause I was sooo confuzed, tired, amped o=
n
caffine, & stuff & it was kinda hard connecting the dots @ times & grrr=

wish i could go back & do them again, but it's fun for what came out :n=
) !

With the Lee Burridge interview, it was my 1st interview that day & his=

manager, or whoever that lady was, told me to ask specific questions &
blah, so confuzing! For interviewing Ethan, I mean.. Ethan's my big bro=

it's like i needed to do an interview that day with someone i knew alre=
ady
just to like i dunno... but but but... like I kinda blanked on what i h=
ad
planned on asking him & just went by train of thought & stuff...

Subject: [sfraves] 3/16/07: Mighty Breaks w/ Krafty Kuts & Soul of Man! 

Ok, so this isn't a BSP cuz I'm not playing at it - but at midnite on the 
16th (aka the 17th, bka St.Patty's Day), I turn a young ol' 33 years of age, 
and I will be shakin' my tailfeather at Mighty to some of the best fucking 
breakbeat available! The headliners are BEAST, and the locals (including 
SFR's own Bam) are all super on point! Come out and buy me shots till I 
can't see straight!

Fri. March 16th: Mighty Breaks presents A Fingerlickin' Thang! with
Krafty Kuts and Soul of Man!

http://www.mightybreaks.com/mb/albums/events/031607_mb_front.jpg

http://www.mightybreaks.com/mb/albums/events/031607_mb_back.jpg

Two of the biggest names in breaks are coming to San Francisco to blow the 
roof off of Mighty. Krafty Kuts just swept at the Breakspoll Awards taking 
home the awards for Best Album, Best DJ and Out Standing Contribution to 
Breakbeats! The kid is on Fire!!!! Both Justin and Jem from Soul of Man will 
be here as well. Local DJs Murphstar, Kapt'n Kirk, Felix The Dog, Bam and 
Ding Dong are on the line up as well.

Pre sale tickets are $10!!!!!

www.mightybreaks.com for more info

Subject: [sfraves] 3/17/07: Opel 5 Year Anniversary w/ Dylan Rhymes, Meat Katie & 30Hz!!!!

I'm also not playing at this (so no BSP this time either), but this is 
another BANGER of an event, and it's OFFICIALLY my birthday! Next weekend 
SMOKES for good parties, ya heard?!?!


Opel 5 Year Anniversary  (info taken from Opel's site)

Opel presents V: A Celebration of 5 years of parties with purpose.

"We came into this not just to throw great parties. We started with the 
purpose of throwing benefits for such diverse groups as Seneca Center, the 
September 11th Children's Fund, Greenpeace, Bay Area Girls Center, 
EnVironmental Defense, and a number of Burning Man art communities and 
projects. We were inspired to use the gathering to point towards evolution 
within the support of community.

FiVe years later we find ourselves still pushing to build community, social 
change, inner inspiration, provide a platform for different artistic 
vehicles, cutting edge dance music, and high octane fun.

For our anniVersary party, we'll be bringing together all the elements that 
have flaVored our eVents over the years. An all out line up of local and 
international talent, fashion show of local designers pushing the future 
edge, a variety of performance and dance from members of the community, and 
lots of other goodies you won't want to miss!"

Lineup features headlining talent from one of the best labels in breakbeat 
and tech-funk right now - Lot 49!

Meat Katie (Lot 49, meatkatie.com - UK)

Dylan Rhymes (Lot 49 - UK)

30Hz (Lot 49 - UK)

w/ support from an all star local lineup that includes:

Syd Gris
Hoj
Melyss
Alain Octavo
Dirtyhertz
Clark Hamon
Crux - [e] & Kevin Knapp

More info at www.opelproductions.com

Presales $15 (limited!)
www.mighty119.com
21+
9:30pm to 4am


Marc(O)
The Mario Bros.//Otherworld//Ill Behavior//The MidnightSons (DC/SF)
www.themidnightsons.com
www.myspace.com/the_mario_bros
www.myspace.com/illectrofunk

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

Last night I went to my local English-esque pub and had dinner.  I  
really like the pub thing, I probably drink too much but oh well.  I  
try to walk more for the exercise.  Finished watching my Star Trek  
episode that I fell asleep on last night, how dare me.  Then, TV OFF!   
I set my internet radio tuner (Real Player) to listen to Jeff Rense,  
how double dare me.  And I fell asleep and didn't consciously hear  
anything.  So last night I probably sleep walked to the nearest white  
supremacy meeting.  Part of me now wonders if I could somehow combine  
this all, the pub, the Star Trek, the evil white power radio shows,  
and maybe Colgate toothpaste would jump in and save the day somehow.   
I don't know, I'll maybe work on that.

--

I never turn off the TV.  It wards away evil spirits.

- The Outer Limits

Oooh.. here's the info.. found it:

yeah i know (i hear what your thinking Matthew)... blah blah blah.. i have
insomnia.. Hello 2Day...


Tuesday, March 06, 2007

  Hybrid U.S. Tour Dates


On March the 8th, we will be returning to the US for our Spring 2007 Live
Tour. It's been three years since the last American outing and fresh from
a sell out tour of Australia, we'll be playing coast to coast with an all
star line up from our latest album, I Choose Noise. Joining us will be
John Graham from Quivver, Peter Distefano from Porno For Pyros, new
recruit and vocalist Charlotte James along with the full band and special
guests.

LA Times had this to say about our live performance at Coachella 2006 : "A
genre is back in style. Hybrid met expectations early, deliver an hour
long set that incorporated elements of breaks, progressive, trance &
psychedelia."

The full list of confirmed dates are as follows :

08th March '07 - Ruby Skye, San Francisco -www.rubyskye.com
10th March '07 - Avalon, Los Angeles - www.avalonhollywood.com
13th March '07 - Club Sound, Salt Lake City - www.soundslc.com
14th March '07 - Gothic, Denver - www.gothictheatre.com
15th March '07 - 930 Club, D.C. - www.930.com
16th March '07 - Webster Hall, NYC - www.webster-hall.com
17th March '07 - Vision, Chicago -www.visionnightclub.com
18th March '07 - House of Blues, Orlando - www.hob.com
24th March '07 - Ultra Music Festival, Miami - www.ultramusicfestival.com

Tickets are avalable from the respective venue's websites as listed.

Please check local press for set times.

Hope to see you there,

Mike and Chris


--

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

Subject: [sfraves] Re: [dcraves] Yes it is RR: Jean Baudrillard, dead at 77

x-posted from DCraves by request


>
> Legba Carrefour wrote:
> > Jean Baudrillad, philosopher, died yesterday, March 6, in Paris at the
> > age of 77.
> >
> > Baudrillard was a French writer best known through his connection to
> > postmodernism and his development of the notion of hyperreality. His
> > book Simulacra and Simulacrum, an attack on consumerism and the modern
> > age of the image that advocated the claim that we had descended
> > permanently into a world of virtuality, mediated through images and
> > ideas, appeared in the movie the Matrix (In one scene, Neo pulls the
> > book from the shelf and the book itself is revealed to be a
> > simulation--the insides contain no book, but a set of computer disks,
> > and is not-ironically, supposed to look like a drug box, playing to
> > Baudrillard's idea of what consumer culture was doing to us).
> >
> > Rave culture through the 90's was very much so wedded to post
> > modernism and Baudrillard played no small part in the development of
> > the ideas of rave culture as a critique of the post-Cold War consumer
> > world. From the virtual boxes we used to engage each other (as
> > probably the first subculture to pretty much grow itself on the
> > fertilizer of the Internet) and make our music, to the very real, yet
> > simultaneously abandoned (by reality) warehouses we threw our parties
> > in, Rave very much so had an expression of what living in the
> > hyperreality meant.
> >
>
> > An obituary and review of his work, up at the Times Online:
> 
  http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/article1483898.ece
> 
> If you want to check out his work, I'd recommend grabbing "Simulacra
> and Simulation," "The Gulf War Did Not Take Place," and "The Spirit of
> Terrorism: And Requiem for the Twin Towers".
> 
> There's also a pretty extensive Wikipedia entry on him. And look up
> Situationism and, of course, the grand-daddy of rave culture
> influencing theorists, Hakim Bey, author of "Temporary Autonomous
> Zone".
> 
> Legba
> 

On 3/7/07, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:

> Why don't you cc: all these eulogic posts out to brian@hyperreal.org ?
>
> I'm sure he'd appreciate the sentiment and that at least one person's on
> this network is paying attention to this sort of shit.
>
> For myself, I'm going to go light a candle and go grieve the loss of
> Captain America, (aka Steve Rogers of Brooklyn, NY), who died today, as
> well, at the age of 90. :'(
>
> ~nyc
>>

Oddly enough, nobody posted anything at all, on this past Sunday, so 
Happy belated 15th Birthday SFRaves! :-P

before. :-D

Here's Brian's first message from 15 years ago:

> From bbehlen
> Wed Mar 4 11:18:33 1992
> From: bbehlen (Vitamin B)
> Date: Wed, 4 Mar 92 11:18:24 -0800
> Subject: To start things off...
>
> Here's a list of some upcoming events I've heard about...
>
> Friday March 6th through Sunday March 8th - The WOOPY BALL - yes, a 
> weekend-long rave, taking place in Oakland. info: 1-800-894-9001. 
> Should we have a meeting place?
>
> Friday March 6th - Primal Scream at the Warfield. okay, I know this 
> isn't exactly "underground", but it's being billed as a rave, and 
> rumors exist that the Orb is gonna be there, too.....
>
> Saturday, March 7th - The Gathering This sounds great. Jeno, Garth, 
> and Josh. 415-267-4800
>
> Friday, March 13th - Lunacy - 510-874-4924. Scott Hardkiss'll be there.
>
> Friday, March 21st - The Utopia Project presents Matrix - 510-874-4955 
> I'd elaborate on each of them but I have to go to class in about ten 
> minutes.....:)
>
> Wow!
>
> 35 subscribers in 24 hours!
>
> This may get gigantic...... Brian
http://www.sfraves.org/archives/sfrlist/1992/sfr.9203.gz

BTW, I'm using Firefox and the archive unzipped instantly instead of 
having to go through the two/three step process that I've had to 
manually go through in the past, which means that it might be easier for 
google spiders to do their magic. Just thought I'd pass that one along.

PLUR, bitches,

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Catharsis on An Epiphany Of Sound Thur. morning

So, Catharsis will be dropping by KZSU Stanford radio this Thur., March 8th for 
the last half of Epiphany of Sound. Which means he plans on starting up at 
around 10:30am and going until noon.  Since the show starts at 9a, I'll start 
with either a live mix myself, or an appropriate pre-recorded mix.  (Time will 
tell.)

As for Catharsis, he's planning a fresh set of hard techno & hardcore.
He's also said he's barely had time to check out the new records, so I'm 
expecting that the universe will guide things on a really fun path.  (We all 
know how that energy flows!)

If you're in the SF Bay Area, you can tune into KZSU at 90.1 FM.  And if you 
can't tune in over the air for whatever reason, we're streaming at 
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu (may I suggest the AAC stream?? ;) )

Anyway, hope to have you listening tomorrow!


http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php

Subject: [sfraves] [sflnc-announce] CALL FOR ACTION -Tolerance - The real
  challenge facing San Francisco

--=====================_25482109==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"



>Entertainment Moguls , Music Mavens, Partiers and Folks that cherish San Francisco's freedoms:
> 
>Our friends at Kink.com made news on the world stage last month with their purchase of the Armory.  This long abandoned building is at the gateway to the Mission for decades has suffered from a lack of a great idea for its use and then came Kink.  Pledging to be a good neighbor and to open its production facilities to Indy film producers all while creating cutting edge adult web based entertainment, Kink has become a nexus in the evolution of San Francisco.
> 
>After being granted permission to use the building a group of folks who have an objection to the idea that Kink could be a good neighbor have called for a hearing that is TOMORROW at 10 AM.  These folks are using a conservative moral agenda to influence city policies.  They are harbingers of the challenges that face the street fairs as several neighbors pressure the city to restrict hours of operation and alcohol service, they are the folks who don't want nightlife and they represent the biggest challenge to our most important quality as a great city - TOLERANCE.
> 
>Read what the owner, Peter Acworth has asked us (the tolerant folks who cherish our freedoms while respecting each other's differences) to do and do what you know is right.  
> 
>Show Up at the Hearing, 
>Write an email of support ( <mailto:linda.avery@sfgov.org>linda.avery@sfgov.org )
>Forward this to your other lists.    
> 
>Terrance Alan, Chairman 
>San Francisco Late Night Coalition
> 
>----------------------------------------------------------
>
>Hi Everyone,
>
>This is a reminder to please come and support kink.com at the special Planning Department hearing this Thursday.
>
>Thursday March 8th 10am-noon
>
>City Hall, Room 416
>
><http://sfgov.org/site/planning_page.asp?id=56603>http://sfgov.org/site/planning_page.asp?id=56603
>
>The Armory is zoned to be a movie studio, and before buying the building, I received a letter of determination from the Planning department stating so.
>
>As you know, a small but loud group of people have objected to the fact that our movies are adult in nature on moral grounds. City officials listened to these people and for whatever reason, decided to hold this meeting.
>
>It is important that we outnumber the protestors at this meeting. This issue is really much bigger than kink.com or the Armory. If you are among those who cherish San Francisco for its freedoms, please join us.
>
>Thanks,
>
>Peter
>
>PS please feel free to forward this on to other lists.
>
> 


<http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/>http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/ 

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

"An adult is one who has lost the grace, the freshness, the innocence of the child, who is no longer capable of feeling pure joy, who makes everything complicated, who spreads suffering everywhere, who is afraid of being happy, and who, because it is easier to bear, has gone back to sleep.  The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

"Music rots when it gets too far from the dance.  Poetry atrophies when it gets too far from the music."
-Ezra Pound

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: Aloha!!

so I made it out here to kona, on the big island.  I am loving it, except 
there are lots of roosters where i am. (pretty fucking annoying) Definately 
not the type of cock I was looking for :P
I wanted to say thanks to everyone who came to say goodbye last saturday.  I 
had a blast!
I hope you are all doing well.  I just realized I got here in time for the 
Kona BrewFestival and Rebirth, Ka Pilina, Hawaii's version of Burning 
Man...I think I am going to volunteer.  Why the hell not??
Be well everyone!!
Danny Picard
===============================================
It is Ka Pilina's pleasure to officially announce:

Rebirth 2007
The Hawaii Interactive Arts Festival
April 26th - 29th
At the Shire, near Pahoa on the Big Island

Tickets are on sale NOW!
Simply go to kapilina.org/kapilina/buytix.php to buy a ticket right now.

Rebirth 2007 (an official Burning Man Regional event), is a 4 day 
interactive art festival in the jungles of Puna including a 20' phoenix, 
fire spinners, luau, performance, music, installations, and much more. Come 
prepared to camp for 4 days, express your creativity, and make connections. 
This event is a nonprofit gathering of artists, no one is making money, and 
vending is banned inside, you come to give and share. Rebirth 2007 is 
organized following the Burning Man 10 Principles, which you can see for 
yourself here: regionals.burningman.com/netwo....html.

Tickets for Rebirth 2007 are $35 (100 available online and 100 are for sale 
on the Big Island) and $45 (700 available online, at the gate, and soon in 
an outlet on an island near you) while supplies last. Discounts available 
for volunteers, artists, performers, and some low-income tickets, see 
website for details.

We are looking for volunteers to help the event run smoothly and there are a 
lot of different jobs we need to do. We really need the help of some 
passionate people, if you are interested in really helping out and 
participating by volunteering then go to our website for all of the details. 
We are also looking for groups to form themecamps to help make the event one 
of the brightest expressions of interactive art outside of Burning Man, see 
the site for more details. We are giving out at least $1,000 in art grants 
go to kapilina.org/kapilina/artgrants.html for all the info and an 
application. The art grant cycle is now open and closes March 15th.

See www.kapilina.org/bigisland...h2007.html for all the information you need 
about Rebirth 2007.


The Ka Pilina Interactive Arts Society, Inc. (501c3)
hawaii@burningman.com
www.kapilina.org
kapilina.tribe.net/

From: Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net>
Date: Thu, 8 Mar 2007 12:03:36 -0800
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Happy Birthday! Thanks for the memories!

Re: http://www.sfraves.org/archives/sfrlist/1992/sfr.9203.gz

What a fabulous first three weeks of messages, names and parties are  
here (March 4-24, 1992)! I wasn't among the original 35 list members-- 
that came a bit later--but I had already met many of those who posted  
here and who  became good friends and acquaintances. Among those  
names here:

Brian Behlendorf (who started the list and still called himself  
Vitain B online) His great fresh reviews (" I have the new list of  
upcoming events ready. It's about 2K - should I publish it to the  
list or just make it available on request? I could make this a weekly  
thing, like every Wednesday I'll put up a list of all
the announced events coming up or something.....")

Roxanna Stieber (who drove a lot of us Santa Cruz posse up to  weekly  
raves)

Geoff White (the big guy who finessed so many encounters with the law  
and otherwise was a great Danger Ranger)

Robert Jesse (who passed out The Rhythm Society flyers and had  
special events, years before the St. John's Divine Rhythm Society  
that he helped found)

Michael Wertheim (and his great Twitch Remix series)

Chris Beaumont (of nutrient/smart  drug memories)

And others I got to know who were also shining parts of the scene:
Niels Mayer
Ovid Jacob
Jon Drukman
Jonathan Steuer
ulmo (Brad Allen)
Preston
Derek Chung

Then there are the mostly local DJs and music makers that I spotted  
in messages here:
DJ Spun
Harry Who?
Mr Tim
Jeno
Garth
Markie Mark
Thomas
Scott Hardkiss
Ernie Munson
Noel
Rick Preston

And those wonderful early '90s references in the scene:
Map points
Smart drinks/bars
Intellex and Renew-You
X
Anubis Warpus in Santa Cruz
BPM
word-of-mouth beach raves
the original Ameba and Hose Wares

And the parties:
ToonTown
Mr. Floppy's Funhouse
The Gathering
Rave Called Sharon
The upcoming Psychic TV party at the Townsend the coming November

Great  stuff!
Happy 15th all!
Will

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Fwd: New royalty threatens internet radio

------=_Part_226552_21161152.1173385592252
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Rusty / SomaFM <rusty@somafm.com>
Date: Mar 6, 2007 12:41 PM
Subject: New royalty threatens internet radio

You may have heard, but once again internet radio is facing huge additional
royalties for broadcasting music. These royalties are in addition to the
ones that we pay to ASCAP and BMI, and are a royalty that is only paid by
internet broadcasters. Over-the-air (AM/FM) broadcasters are explicitly
exempt from this royalty; it only applies to internet broadcasters and
subscription music services.

In the past, we paid royalties based on a percentage of our revenues, in our
case 10% of our revenue. But the new royalties don't allow that percentage
of revenue factor, and instead charge us for each song we play times the
number of people listening.  This works out to about $8 per average
concurrent listener per month.  In 2006, we averaged over 6000 average
concurrent listeners per month, and the royalties we will have to pay for
2006 is about $628,000, over 4 times the amount of money we brought in.

And these rates go up drastically each year, until 2010, where they
are 2.5times their initial rate: by then we will have to pay over $1
million
dollars a year in royalties if we want to stay on the air.

So you can see that this puts us in an impossible position. And to make it
even worse, the rates are retroactive to 2006.

It doesn't seem fair that a small radio service like SomaFM has to pay all
these additional royalties, when over-the-air stations who reach much larger
audiences are exempted from paying them.

If you are in the USA, we would appreciate it if you could sign this online
petition which will be presented to members of Congress.

It's important for us to let Congress know that independent internet radio
is about to be forced out of business.

We need to keep our existing "percentage of revenue" royalty rate structure,
or better yet, have Congress extend the exemption to internet radio stations
as well as terrestrial (over-the-air) stations.

       http://www.petitiononline.com/SIR2007r/petition.html

Thanks for all of your support for SomaFM in the past. We will do what we
need to do to keep SomaFM on the air and broadcasting.  We love you!

Rusty Hodge,
General Manager and Program Director
SomaFM.com

--------------------------------------------------------
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to the
SomaFM news  update mailing list.

To unsubscribe, use this URL:
http://somafm.com/mailinglist/signoff.html?email=sosteen,gmail.com&mode=signoff

------=_Part_226552_21161152.1173385592252--

From sfraves-return-138058-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Mar 08 21:18:17 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-138058-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 17912 invoked by uid 1103); 8 Mar 2007 21:18:15 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 17896 invoked from network); 8 Mar 2007 21:18:15 -0000
From: tsheets@saturn5.com
Date: Thu, 8 Mar 2007 13:13:31 -0800
To: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
Cc: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <20070308211331.GA31726@atari.saturn5.com>
References: <7a86c50c0703081217j1392bd7bicc0907fd08f18eb8@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <7a86c50c0703081217j1392bd7bicc0907fd08f18eb8@mail.gmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.5.13 (2006-08-11)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] what was in the early "smart drinks"?



There are actually some drugs and substances that may increase mental
performance.  Piracetam is one of the most proven.  It is perscription
here in the US, but available in Mexico, or by mail order.  Another one
legal here is Argenine Pyroglutimate.  If you mix these with some other
brain-vitimans like DMAE and Choline, you can sort of feel an affect.  
Sort of like being more awake, but not like caffiene.  There is a multi-
vitamian called "Deep Thought" that is loaded with DMAE and other substances
that is qutie effective.

Very few "smart bars" actually put any of these substances in their drinks.
There was a crew in San Deigo that actually made true, powerful smart drink
with these things.  Maybe some in SF?

I dabbled in all this years ago, but then decided at my age I can't
really improve my mental performance much.  I will wait until I am old
and my brain starts to slow down.  That is where most of the research on
these drugs seem to have promise.

Some of the combinations I messed with made my dreams go insanely vivid.
I think it was the DMAE.

-troy

On Thu, Mar 08, 2007 at 12:17:57PM -0800, Bam wrote:

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what was in the early "smart drinks"?


Mondo 2000 use dto talk a lot about Smart Drugs a lot.  If I had my full 
library I could pull out the emcyclopedia they did and find out what all 
they talked about, but Choline was a big one.  I know DHEA is another, as 
well as 5-HTP and Meletonin.  The whole basis is to provide the base chems 
your brain need sto break down into the various aminos that it'll burn 
through.

Basically like taking on glucose while going through heavy physical 
exertion.  It won't make you stronger, but it'll provide fuel that your 
body needs.  Same goes for he smart drugs, that for the most part the just 
fill up your proverbial gas tank.  If you use up the chems or not is 
another story.  I agree with teh mindset that it's better to have a little 
exces syour don't need instead of lacking when you need it.

Same can't be said for complex carbs.  ;)

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Happy Birthday! Thanks for the memories!

Jason Philips wrote:
> "Wow! 35 subscribers in 24 hours! This may get gigantic......"
>  
> That has to be one of my favorite quotes. 
>
>   
..........
Me too, that's why I chopped it there, though I must admit seeing that 
filled me with a very bittersweet feeling, seeing as how it actually did 
get organically gigantic, for a minute, and then our government, feeling 
completely threatened by this movement, went out of its way to destroy 
rave the way it did.

Things could be so different now, but they're not.

As far as "Smart Drinks" go, at the time Brian sent out that first email 
I was a straightedge, (second worst decision of my adult life next to 
enlisting in the Marine Corps), stockbroker trainee working on Wall 
Street, less than two weeks away from passing my Series 7 & 63 NASD 
Registered Representative Licensing Test, in March of 1992, which means 
that rave was one of the furthest things away from my mind. At the time, 
the way I dressed was pretty close to Ed Norton in 'fight club' instead 
of the slackerish looking person I am today.

As it turns out, one of the very first IPOs I worked on was for a small 
Canadian company that was one of DNA Lounge's very first suppliers of 
Smart Drinks, something I didn't find out until years later.

Unfortunately the name of the company escapes me and using google is 
turning out to be an exercise in futility.

~nyc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what was in the early "smart drinks"?

There used to be smart drinks at DNA in the early
90s... excellent business before the bar would open at
6. They had a menu with a few of the mental
performance type substances, you could choose like
jamba juice.

Also, Mr. Curb was the man of Smart Drinks in SF. Used
to see his booth everywhere... Not sure what he put in
his drinks, but they were the best IMHO. I tried to
emulate as best I could when I ran a couple smart bars
for Moksha Tribe parties. Seemed like they kept the
crew ripping thru setup and stryke! Most folks i think
ended up hocked up and jitttttterrrryyy.... 

good times.


--- tsheets@saturn5.com wrote:

> 
> 
> There are actually some drugs and substances that
> may increase mental
> performance.  Piracetam is one of the most proven. 
> It is perscription
> here in the US, but available in Mexico, or by mail
> order.  Another one
> legal here is Argenine Pyroglutimate.  If you mix
> these with some other
> brain-vitimans like DMAE and Choline, you can sort
> of feel an affect.  
> Sort of like being more awake, but not like
> caffiene.  There is a multi-
> vitamian called "Deep Thought" that is loaded with
> DMAE and other substances
> that is qutie effective.
> 
> Very few "smart bars" actually put any of these
> substances in their drinks.
> There was a crew in San Deigo that actually made
> true, powerful smart drink
> with these things.  Maybe some in SF?
> 
> I dabbled in all this years ago, but then decided at
> my age I can't
> really improve my mental performance much.  I will
> wait until I am old
> and my brain starts to slow down.  That is where
> most of the research on
> these drugs seem to have promise.
> 
> Some of the combinations I messed with made my
> dreams go insanely vivid.
> I think it was the DMAE.
> 
> -troy
>

When I first began going to events in Tucson there was some guy who was mak=
ing smart drinks. It seemed such a science. Later it seemed like more peopl=
e just made fruit smoothies and the art died off. I would love to see a tru=
e resurgence of smart drinks. I am not a chemical user but with my poor die=
t the smart drinks always seemed to give me a good boost.=20
=20
Jason

i went to the full moon gathering down in southern california, actually. Saw
Mr. Annand, Acid Circus performing live (sooo awesome), dj Brian, Chadwick,
and a very very funky set from Treavor. It was a good time - not too cold at
night, a light breeze during the day, and lots of sunshine and beautiful
people.

I'll miss California.

~juju

On Thu, 8 Mar 2007, Will Penna wrote:

> Re: http://www.sfraves.org/archives/sfrlist/1992/sfr.9203.gz
>
> What a fabulous first three weeks of messages, names and parties are here 
> (March 4-24, 1992)! I wasn't among the original 35 list members--that came a 
> bit later--but I had already met many of those who posted here and who 
> became good friends and acquaintances. Among those names here:
>
> Brian Behlendorf (who started the list and still called himself Vitain B 
> online) His great fresh reviews (" I have the new list of upcoming events 
> ready. It's about 2K - should I publish it to the list or just make it 
> available on request? I could make this a weekly thing, like every Wednesday 
> I'll put up a list of all
> the announced events coming up or something.....")
>
> Roxanna Stieber (who drove a lot of us Santa Cruz posse up to  weekly raves)
>
> Geoff White (the big guy who finessed so many encounters with the law and 
> otherwise was a great Danger Ranger)
>
> Robert Jesse (who passed out The Rhythm Society flyers and had special 
> events, years before the St. John's Divine Rhythm Society that he helped 
> found)
>
> Michael Wertheim (and his great Twitch Remix series)
>
> Chris Beaumont (of nutrient/smart  drug memories)
>
> And others I got to know who were also shining parts of the scene:
> Niels Mayer
> Ovid Jacob
> Jon Drukman
> Jonathan Steuer
> ulmo (Brad Allen)
> Preston
> Derek Chung
>
> Then there are the mostly local DJs and music makers that I spotted in 
> messages here:
> DJ Spun
> Harry Who?
> Mr Tim
> Jeno
> Garth
> Markie Mark
> Thomas
> Scott Hardkiss
> Ernie Munson
> Noel
> Rick Preston
>
> And those wonderful early '90s references in the scene:
> Map points
> Smart drinks/bars
> Intellex and Renew-You
> X
> Anubis Warpus in Santa Cruz
> BPM
> word-of-mouth beach raves
> the original Ameba and Hose Wares
>
> And the parties:
> ToonTown
> Mr. Floppy's Funhouse
> The Gathering
> Rave Called Sharon
> The upcoming Psychic TV party at the Townsend the coming November
>
> Great  stuff!
> Happy 15th all!
> Will

On 8 March 2007, tsheets@saturn5.com wrote:

>
>
> There are actually some drugs and substances that may increase mental
> performance.  Piracetam is one of the most proven.  It is perscription
> here in the US, but available in Mexico, or by mail order.  Another one
> legal here is Argenine Pyroglutimate.  If you mix these with some other
> brain-vitimans like DMAE and Choline, you can sort of feel an affect.
> Sort of like being more awake, but not like caffiene.  There is a multi-
> vitamian called "Deep Thought" that is loaded with DMAE and other substances
> that is qutie effective.
>
> Very few "smart bars" actually put any of these substances in their drinks.
> There was a crew in San Deigo that actually made true, powerful smart drink
> with these things.  Maybe some in SF?
>
> I dabbled in all this years ago, but then decided at my age I can't
> really improve my mental performance much.  I will wait until I am old
> and my brain starts to slow down.  That is where most of the research on
> these drugs seem to have promise.
>
> Some of the combinations I messed with made my dreams go insanely vivid.
> I think it was the DMAE.
>
> -troy
>
> On Thu, Mar 08, 2007 at 12:17:57PM -0800, Bam wrote:
>> regarding "smart drinks/bars" at raves...just what was mixed in those
>> things back then?
>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: [dcraves] Yes it is RR: Jean Baudrillard, dead at 77

FWIW It should be noted that _Simulacra_ is a straight up work of
philosophy, and one translated from french at that.  I found it
required quite a commitment to read, sometimes going over pages two
and three times to grok Baudrillad;s (necessarily) invented
nomenclature - hyperreality, etc.  One of my personal disappointments
is that I have yet to make it all the way through.


(By way of comparison, I thought nieztche's Thus Spoke Zarathustra was
pretty readable, although it is, like camus's stuff, basically a
story.)

-jasonh




On 3/7/07, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
> x-posted from DCraves by request
>
>
> >
> > Legba Carrefour wrote:
> > > Jean Baudrillad, philosopher, died yesterday, March 6, in Paris at th=
e
> > > age of 77.
> > >
> > > Baudrillard was a French writer best known through his connection to
> > > postmodernism and his development of the notion of hyperreality. His
> > > book Simulacra and Simulacrum, an attack on consumerism and the moder=
n
> > > age of the image that advocated the claim that we had descended
> > > permanently into a world of virtuality, mediated through images and
> > > ideas, appeared in the movie the Matrix (In one scene, Neo pulls the
> > > book from the shelf and the book itself is revealed to be a
> > > simulation--the insides contain no book, but a set of computer disks,
> > > and is not-ironically, supposed to look like a drug box, playing to
> > > Baudrillard's idea of what consumer culture was doing to us).
> > >
> > > Rave culture through the 90's was very much so wedded to post
> > > modernism and Baudrillard played no small part in the development of
> > > the ideas of rave culture as a critique of the post-Cold War consumer
> > > world. From the virtual boxes we used to engage each other (as
> > > probably the first subculture to pretty much grow itself on the
> > > fertilizer of the Internet) and make our music, to the very real, yet
> > > simultaneously abandoned (by reality) warehouses we threw our parties
> > > in, Rave very much so had an expression of what living in the
> > > hyperreality meant.
> > >
> >
> > > An obituary and review of his work, up at the Times Online:
> >
>   http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/article1483898.ece
> >
> > If you want to check out his work, I'd recommend grabbing "Simulacra
> > and Simulation," "The Gulf War Did Not Take Place," and "The Spirit of
> > Terrorism: And Requiem for the Twin Towers".
> >
> > There's also a pretty extensive Wikipedia entry on him. And look up
> > Situationism and, of course, the grand-daddy of rave culture
> > influencing theorists, Hakim Bey, author of "Temporary Autonomous
> > Zone".
> >
> > Legba
> >
>
> On 3/7/07, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> > Why don't you cc: all these eulogic posts out to brian@hyperreal.org ?
> >
> > I'm sure he'd appreciate the sentiment and that at least one person's o=
n
> > this network is paying attention to this sort of shit.
> >
> > For myself, I'm going to go light a candle and go grieve the loss of
> > Captain America, (aka Steve Rogers of Brooklyn, NY), who died today, as
> > well, at the age of 90. :'(
> >
> > ~nyc
> >>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what was in the early "smart drinks"?


>>
>> On Thu, Mar 08, 2007 at 12:17:57PM -0800, Bam wrote:
>>> regarding "smart drinks/bars" at raves...just what was mixed in  
>>> those
>>> things back then?

We used to make a fruit smoothy-type drink and add stimulants like  
Guarana, Gotu Kola, Ginsengs, green tea and the like with a bit of  
Kava Kava, http://www.erowid.org/plants/kava/.

Apollo



apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: [dcraves] Yes it is RR: Jean Baudrillard, dead
 at 77

There was a class I took in college about Post Modernism; we read lots 
of art philosophers, one of the ones we studied extensively was 
Baudrillard. That class was some of the most densest reading I have ever 
done. Those, with the discussions, became one of the most rewarding 
classes I ever took in college. I kept all of the papers and notes.

Simulcra is worth-while reading.

-tim

jason hemmenway wrote:
> FWIW It should be noted that _Simulacra_ is a straight up work of
> philosophy, and one translated from french at that.  I found it
> required quite a commitment to read, sometimes going over pages two
> and three times to grok Baudrillad;s (necessarily) invented
> nomenclature - hyperreality, etc.  One of my personal disappointments
> is that I have yet to make it all the way through.
>
>
> (By way of comparison, I thought nieztche's Thus Spoke Zarathustra was
> pretty readable, although it is, like camus's stuff, basically a
> story.)
>
> -jasonh
>
>
>
>
> On 3/7/07, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
>> x-posted from DCraves by request
>>
>>
>> >
>> > Legba Carrefour wrote:
>> > > Jean Baudrillad, philosopher, died yesterday, March 6, in Paris 
>> at the
>> > > age of 77.
>> > >
>> > > Baudrillard was a French writer best known through his connection to
>> > > postmodernism and his development of the notion of hyperreality. His
>> > > book Simulacra and Simulacrum, an attack on consumerism and the 
>> modern
>> > > age of the image that advocated the claim that we had descended
>> > > permanently into a world of virtuality, mediated through images and
>> > > ideas, appeared in the movie the Matrix (In one scene, Neo pulls the
>> > > book from the shelf and the book itself is revealed to be a
>> > > simulation--the insides contain no book, but a set of computer 
>> disks,
>> > > and is not-ironically, supposed to look like a drug box, playing to
>> > > Baudrillard's idea of what consumer culture was doing to us).
>> > >
>> > > Rave culture through the 90's was very much so wedded to post
>> > > modernism and Baudrillard played no small part in the development of
>> > > the ideas of rave culture as a critique of the post-Cold War 
>> consumer
>> > > world. From the virtual boxes we used to engage each other (as
>> > > probably the first subculture to pretty much grow itself on the
>> > > fertilizer of the Internet) and make our music, to the very real, 
>> yet
>> > > simultaneously abandoned (by reality) warehouses we threw our 
>> parties
>> > > in, Rave very much so had an expression of what living in the
>> > > hyperreality meant.
>> > >
>> >
>> > > An obituary and review of his work, up at the Times Online:
>> >
>>   http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/article1483898.ece
>> >
>> > If you want to check out his work, I'd recommend grabbing "Simulacra
>> > and Simulation," "The Gulf War Did Not Take Place," and "The Spirit of
>> > Terrorism: And Requiem for the Twin Towers".
>> >
>> > There's also a pretty extensive Wikipedia entry on him. And look up
>> > Situationism and, of course, the grand-daddy of rave culture
>> > influencing theorists, Hakim Bey, author of "Temporary Autonomous
>> > Zone".
>> >
>> > Legba
>> >
>>
>> On 3/7/07, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
>>

>> > well, at the age of 90. :'(

don't know, I could be wrong.  Maybe our little buddies at Google
could auto-gzip a few archives and let us know.

friend Dan called me from Chicago to tell me about this website, and I
guess he felt it so important that he called me back 15 minutes later
to make sure I read some of the stories.  But anyway, I'm sure all of
you already know who this guy is, because I'm pretty slow on the uptake.

>"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path
>toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and
>enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,
>sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and
>Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can
>find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and
>economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond
>what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative
>pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in
>squalor."
>-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.
>

>the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
>gradually become visible."

ntertainment project that never happened. =0A=0ADuring the entire meeting h=
e twitched, flinched, squirmed,exclaimed, jibbered, babbled,and excitedly r=

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
