Subject: [sfraves] NRR: The Simulated Death of Jean Baudrillard

--Apple-Mail-2--273995110
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed


> The Simulated Death of Jean Baudrillard
>
> This is a satire piece. For you literalists and Jean Baudrillard
> groupies out there - no ill will is intended here toward Jean
> Baudrillard and his memory, his relatives or the country of France or
> any philosophers who choose to write in an obscure manner.
>
> Also no ill will is intended toward Woody Allen, Jean Reno or the
> Wachowski brothers or the relatives and groupies of Marshall McLuhan.
>
> An inspiring reference: NY TIMES OBIT
>
> From:
> http://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/07/books/07baudrillard.html?ei=5087% 
> 0A&em=&en=b374d5a55b20ddac&ex=1173502800&pagewanted=print
>
> March 7, 2007
> Jean Baudrillard, 77, Critic and Theorist of Hyperreality, Dies
> By PATRICIA COHEN
>
> excerpts:
>
> A: Like other postmodernists with whom he was often associated
> (despite their differences), he was frequently criticized as obscure.
> "If the texts seem incomprehensible, it is for the excellent reason
> that they mean precisely nothing," Alan Sokal and Jean Bricmont wrote
> in their 1998 book "Fashionable Nonsense: Postmodern Intellectuals'
> Abuse of Science."
>
> Mr. Baudrillard was not unaware of the problem. "What I'm going to
> write will have less and less chance of being understood," he said,
> "but that's my problem."
>
> B: "All of our values are simulated," he told The New York Times in
> 2005. "What is freedom? We have a choice between buying one car or
> buying another car? It's a simulation of freedom."
>
> This idea was picked up by the American filmmakers Andy and Larry
> Wachowski, who included subtle references to Mr. Baudrillard in their
> "Matrix" trilogy. In the first movie of the series, "The Matrix"
> (1999), the computer hacker hero Neo opens Mr. Baudrillard's book
> "Simulacra and Simulation," which turns out to be only a simulation of
> a book, hollowed out to hold computer disks. Mr. Baudrillard later
> told The Times that the movie references to his work "stemmed mostly
> from misunderstandings."
>
> End of excerpts -
> ----------------------------------------------------------
> The author of this post asks the reader to consider the following for
> entertainment purposes only.   --ricardieu
>
> Certainly somewhere in our Global Village a creative writer (most
> likely writers) is now working on a draft to the effect that Jean
> Baudrillard's death was a simulation.
>
> Included in the body of the text (of a play, screenplay, short story
> or novel etc.) will be Jean's ascent to the 'pearly gates' among other
> possible locales in our Creator's existence.
>
> Upon greeting St. Peter or whomever/whatever, it (that is the soul of
> Jean Baudrillard) will question the authenticity of the media present
> - the 'pearly gates', the 'halo' around St. Peter (for that matter,
> whether or not St. Peter was designed by Disney World engineers or
> perhaps Las Vegas employed engineers).
>
> St. Peter or whatever entity that has been chosen by our Creatorship
> will soon become flustered with this soul (even though this is at a
> level of eternity where there is no specific time or space) and
> confer with our Creatorship (the source of our Beingness).
>
> Then we do a jump cut to the Gates of Hell.
>
> Again we find the soul of Baudrillard questioning the authenticity of
> where it is.
>
> Perhaps this soul questions the existence of Lucifer and or Satan (or
> one of their minions and their actual throne of power and thus kingdom
> of darkness) who is trying to really frighten this particularly
> doubtful soul about the prospects of eternal damnation.
>
> Jump cut - back to the Kingdom of Heaven.
>
> The soul of Baudrillard is in a heavenly screening room alone watching
> the 1950's kid's show, 'The Howdy Doody Show,' with Buffalo Bob and
> Clarabelle the Clown and Phineas T. Buster. Besides the soul of
> Baudrillard are dvd containers with titles such as 'The Muppets',
> and....(this is where the reader can use their simulated/or otherwise
> imagination to name other puppet shows made popular by audiences
> throughout the global village).
>
> The soul of Baudrillard is ruminating/reflecting (while screening the
> videos) when will I ever have a real experience, something that is
> truly authentic?
>
> On the other side of a mirror on the wall (like in most cop movies
> where there is a scene showing the interrogation room as well as the
> room on the other side of the mirror where there are detectives in
> rapt observation of the suspect/perpetrator) there is the conversation
> to the effect....
>
> Angelic handlers composite dialog:
>
> What do we do with this soul? I personally do not want to flub this
> gig and have to go through another one of those incarnation gigs
> again. Like Lucifer sent this soul back to us. Like how many times
> does that happen?
>
> Yeah, I have gnosis on your drift.
>
> (A sort of eternal silence beats by. )
>
> Yo, I've received our orders from our Creatorship.
>
> And what might that be?
>
> We take this soul back to the incarnation process/chamber.
>
> Yeah, and then what?
>
> We take this soul back to the incarnation process, after we dose him
> with our heavenly light.
>
> Yeah, and then what?
>
> The message I've received is that we prepare this soul for an
> incarnation as a Ken doll.
>
> A Ken doll?
>
> You know, a Ken doll goes with a Barbie doll.
>
> And...?
>
> And this soul will then hopefully experience simulation in an
> authentic manner.
>
> Wow, our Creatorship is really on the ball!
>
> That IS the job our Creatorship.
>
> And that's no simulation.
>
> (Momentary white out. )
>
> Jump cut to an underground den occupied by the Wachowski brothers and
> the real non-deceased Jean Baudrillard. (This is a satire Wachowski
> bros please don't sue my arse. You are millionaires and I am NOT!)
>
> Jean: (through an interpreter who looks a lot like the French actor
> Jean Reno, but is not) Like dudes, like I just said you got it wrong
> the first time. You used my book in the first flick of your Matrix
> trilogy - but you just...
>
> Andy: We know what you said. Our movies were a simulation of a book
> about simulations and the simulation of reality and we still got it  
> wrong!
>
> Larry: And dude that Chinese elixer really makes you look 35 years
> younger...
>
> Jean: Really, your not sh*ting me? Where did you get this elixer?
>
> Larry: We got it from Woody Allen. You know he did that flick,  
> 'Alice'?
>
> Jean: Woody Allen?
>
> Larry: Well no, not exactly from Woody Allen. Someone who looked a lot
> like Woody Allen. I've heard that Woody uses doubles like Andy Warhol
> did.
>
> Jean: (Looks at himself in a wall mirror.) This is amazing, not only
> do I look about 35 years younger my memory feels that young also -
> even the simulacra of my
> memories feel much younger, I wonder if this a computer generated
> special effect. Are we really here?
>
> Andy: Jean - enough with that talk. You don't how many times people
> have pulled that number on us while we were actually talking to them.
>
> Listen up here Jean, we did this first Matrix trilogy as a level ONE
> simulation.
>
> Larry: Now we are ready to consult with you, really, on a second
> Matrix trilogy that will be a better simulation that the first level
> simulation.
>
> Andy: Yeah, like all those spin-offs of our Matrix trilogy are like...
>
> Larry: Andy....let's focus on the positive...our Creatorship has dealt
> us some strong hands and now...
>
> Andy: Yo bro...I telepathicly got you.... (the bros stare at Jean) we
> like want to keep the ball rolling and we now have the real Jean
> Baudrillard as a willing collaborator.
>
> Jean: I don't know how to thank you (as he looks at his rejuvenated
> self image again in a wall mirror) guys.
>
> Andy: Yo Jean, your are here as an act of divine intervention by our
> mutual Creatorship and ...
>
> Larry: Like Andy dude, don't reveal too much too soon. Let Jean
> acclimatize to his new surroundings and possibilities.
>
> Andy: Your right bro, as almost always.
>
> Jean: So what's on the menu?
>
> Andy: This time we focus more on a media ecology slant in our second
> Matrix trilogy.
>
> Jean: Media ecology?
>
> Larry: You know Marshall McLuhan....
>
> Jean: Marshall McLuhan?....didn't he check out the last day of 1980?
>
> Larry: Well you are right, the incarnated soul of the one known as
> Marshall McLuhan passed on in 1980 but we have two sisters who channel
> his soul as well as the Egyptian God known as Thoth.
>
> Andy: And so far going over the transcripts of the channeling
> sessions, most people who call themselves 'media ecologists' are
> stuck on the surface tip of the iceberg.
>
> Jean: Holy merde! Please excuse me. I mean 'gosh'! This sounds
> important! But what do you mean 'stuck on the surface tip of the
> iceberg'?
>
> Andy: Well there are those who say there is more to our mediated
> reality than what interfaces with our physical sensory apparatus.
>
> Like an iceberg supposedly only has 30 per cent of its mass above the
> surface of the water. The rest is hidden beneath the surface of the
> water. There are those who frame media ecology as including this
> 'more' .... as Para Media Ecology and others as Deep Media Ecology.
>
> Larry: Jean, haven't you read Lynne McTaggart's books THE FIELD and
> THE INTENTION EXPERIMENT?
>
> Jean: Well no. I guess I have some more reading to do. (Extends both
> hands to shake hands with the Wachowski brothers.) For the first time
> in my life, I just don't know what to say?
>
> Larry: Dude, we are so glad you are here and on board with our second
> level Matrix trilogy. Our library is yours to glean from.
>
> Andy: I get this calls for a hug sandwich.
>
> Jean: A what?
>
> (Andy and Larry hug Jean from opposite sides, while Jean's interpreter
> (who looks like the French actor Jean Reno, but is not, snaps a
> digital photo of the hug sandwich performed by the Wachowski brothers
> on Jean Baudrillard.)
>
> FADE TO BLACK
>
> White titles are shown on black:
>
> THE END OF THE BEGINNING
> OF THE SIMULATION KNOT.
>
> FADE IN
>
> An actor is walking through a deserted NYC Central Park in the
> afternoon of a Spring day - on a jogging/bike path. The actor looks a
> lot like Woody Allen and even simulates his voice pattern/speech mask,
> but is not the real Woody Allen.
>
> Actor: Supposedly Alexander the Great disassembled the "Gordian
> Knot" with a well struck blow of his sword. Supposedly that swift act
> amazed the vanquished people who owned and treasured the Gordian Knot.
>
> Perhaps we are all in for a switcheroo where the currently resurrected
> Alexandrian Library, commonly referenced as the 'internet' will
> provide a circumstance in which the global village will, through
> increasing levels of information driven transparency
> achieve peace throughout humanity via empathic driven compassion.
>
> (Actor - waves off the hidden cue card holder.)
>
> Actor: The actor removes his mask (Like, but not the same, as in the
> tv series 'Mission Impossible' and looks even more like Woody Allen,
> but is still not the real Woody Allen).
>
> It is not an accident that in most tarot decks, based on the Kabbala,
> the major arcana card referenced as 'The Fool' is given the naught
> number of zero.
>
> To me, humor, is the most important solvent to resolving the
> conflicting situations in our global village today. Did you see the
> film 'Borat'? Did you like this film? Hopefully the cultures and
> 'peoples' that were humorously satirized in this film have some
> understanding about the unifying power of satire.
>
> Or do you prefer the film, 'The Departed'?
>
> Imagine the actor, James Cagney known for this line, "You dirty rat."
> Imagine how many other actors imitated that line, including the
> actor, Red Buttons, who actually imitated Cagney's voice to the actor
> James Cagney in the film by Billy Wilder titled 'One Two Three.'
>
> Imagine a chorus of, 'You dirty rat,' that occurs during a special
> session of the United Nations in which each country's delegates are
> yelling that phrase at the nearest seated foreign country's delegates.
>
> How does that make you feel?
>
> Are you glad to be alive in a climate of simulated conflict?
>
> It is to your heart and hands that this message is directed to each
> and every real person who reads this internet post....ahhh who hears
> me in this film.
>
> We are the true 'powers that be' and it is now time, above all times,
> that we honor our respective 'callings' and encourage others to do the
> same.
>
> (A yellow colored cab stops by. The actor who looks like Woody Allen,
> but is not, waves a smiling kiss goodbye to the camera and enters the
> cab.)
>
> JUMP CUT TO SCREENING ROOM
>
> (Lights come on. Jean Baudrillard and the Wachowski bros. are seated.
> They look at each other. The Wachowski brothers are seated on either
> side of Jean.
>
> Jean: I don't know about that.
>
> Andy: What do you mean Jean?
>
> Jean: Couldn't we get the real Woody Allen to play the fake Woody  
> Allen?
>
> (The Wachowski brothers break into deep laughter and again hug Jean
> from both sides.)
>
> FADE TO LIGHT
>
>
> __._,_.___
>
>

> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Mary Morris <morrism@washpost.com>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Thursday, March 8, 2007 6:15:52 PM
> Subject: [sfraves] track notes on DEEP by ROR-SHAK
>
>
>
> (available on iTunes, btw :)
>
>
>
> 1.  "Lisa's Song" feat. Lisa Shaw:  "We had a soulful track in the works
>
> and needed a soulful voice. I knew people who knew Lisa Shaw so I just
>
> reached out. She was available to quickly come in and write something.
>
> Lucky timing. She sang in Stakka's broom closet." (DB) "This was a lo-fi
>
> vocal recording which turned out great. We met Lisa for the first time
> when
>
> she came to my apartment. We worked out that the best place for her to
> sing
>
> was in my closet next to the studio, before I converted it into the plush
>
> new vocal/sneaker closet it currently is. Poor Lisa had no room to move
> and
>
> had to hold the mic. It was summer and extremely hot, but she did three
>
> takes, all identical and immaculate. (Stakka)




-- 
- Nic

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - Tonal: Shamrock Green w/ Justin Long next Friday!!!

Friday, March 16th

11 PM 'til very late
Rock It Science, Prismatic Tracks, Crush Collective, and sfhousemusic.com
present:

Tonal: Shamrock Green

Raw SF Warehouse Location: call 888-482-9281 or 415-412-0406, or visit
prismatictracks.com or sfhousemusic.com the day of for directions 
$10 before midnight, $15 after
$5 discount for dressing UP in Shamrock Green (at door person's
discretion--make some serious effort people!)
 
Before you have time to stop talking about how incredibly intimate, vibey,
and fantastically dressed up the crowd at Fire Engine Red was, not to
mention Miles Maeda's set, we are proud to annouce Tonal: Shamrock Green!
Yes, as if you needed another excuse to get wasted this is St. Patty's Day
weekend.  Get ready for the next throwdown in this series of sick new color
themed parties brought to you by some of the hottest crews in the
underground house scene. Tonal parties continue showcase talent flown in
from out of town as well as some of your favorite local house jocks. We look
forward to continuing to bring you high quality events, so strap on your
dancing shoes, bring everybody you know and get ready to move it! 
 
DJ's:
 
Justin Long (Dotbleep, No Assembly Firm, Chicago)
 
We are incredibly excited to have one of the sickest dj's we've ever seen
ready to rip the decks to shreds for this one!  Justin beats the dancefloor
up like few others, tearing through jackin' chicago beats, acid house, techy
glitchy dirty madness, and anything else that will make you lose your mind
and stomp your feet.  His label Dotbleep consistently puts out some of the
hottest tracks around, and his remix and production work with Dan X under
the moniker No Assembly Firm routinely works dancefloors into a frenzy.  If
you've missed Justin's sets at Stompy or the Endup we are not quite sure
what you've been thinking.  Get ready for a serious treat live and direct
from the Windy City!  www.myspace.com/dj_justinlong

Deron Delgado (Stompy, Good Family)
 
DJ, Producer, Label boss, and part of a growing internet empire (stompy.com)
pushing funky, pumping tunes into the cd decks of dj's across the globe,
Deron Delgado is a huge part of the dance music community in San Francisco
and beyond.  Deron's dj sets always seem to have the perfect blend of hot
tracks that have yet to even hit the shelves, today's best cuts, and just
the right sprinkling of dancefloor classics all mixed to perfection.  We are
honored to have Deron closing the night out proper for us.
www.myspace.com/derondelgado
 
Andrew Phelan (Prismatic, Drop Music, So Sound) vs. Eric Sharp (Rock It
Science)

What happens when you take 2 talented local SF dj's and put them on the
decks together warming it up for one of their favorite dj's in the world?
Make sure you get your ass on the dancefloor to find out.  Andrew and Eric
both have crates that stretch far into the vaults of house music and you can
be sure that they will be digging deep to Tonally turn up the heat for this
one.  Work it out! 
 
Andrew Kelsey (Blue Collar Entertainment)

A veteran of SF's underground scene (some of you geezers may remember The
Fool), Andrew Kelsey has since graduated to building one of the fastest
growing booking agencies in the US, Blue Collar Entertainment.  Mr. Kelsey
has a nose for finding great dj's, which can probably be attributed to the
fact that he is a great dj himself.  We wish that Andrew spent a little bit
more time getting himself behind the decks, so we had to jump at the chance
to get him to rock it for you.  Get here early in time for the man to open
things up in high style!



---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what was in the early "smart drinks"?


I was talking more about the original sobe stuff like Zen Tea, Elixer, 
Power, Blizzard, etc etc.  Mostly flavored corn syrup with some herbals in 
them like kava kava, St Johns Wort, etc.

My favorite of course was when some of the companies trie dto claim not to 
have cafine, but were using Gurana instead.  ;)


At 07:00 AM 3/9/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>Exactly.  The whole energy drink craze grew out of smart drinks.
>
>But people shouldn't confuse these supplements with the more extreme stuff 
>like piracetam.
>
>I had one experience with a guy who shall remain nameless (some on this 
>list might know him) who got really into smart drugs/drinks during the 
>Mondo 2000 era.  He was a well known software developer and I guess felt 
>these substances helped him concentrate for long periods of time.  When I 
>met him, it was at a business meeting for a large virtual reality 
>entertainment project that never happened.
>
>During the entire meeting he twitched, flinched, squirmed,exclaimed, 
>jibbered, babbled,and excitedly rambled about things that seemed entirely 
>trivial to everyone else.  If you've seen the movie Matchstick Men the 
>scenes where Nick Cage is experiencing the world all sped up in fast 
>forward seem close to how this must have felt.
>
>He might have thought he was smarter, but he actually was just wired as 
>fuck.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: anyone been to cozumel???

Cozumel is an island that's supposed to have some of the best diving in 
the world. Playa Del Carmen is a smallish town on the mainland nearby, 
I've been there a couple of times. Also Tulum a little bit further down 
the coast is supposed to be great. Mayan ruins and stuff.

ah yes - Playa Del Carmen.  Araya and I spent a week there a few  
years ago.  We didn't make it out to Cozumel. Maybe next time.

If you do find yourself in PDC, be sure to check out Cavernas Chak  
Tun - incredible limestone caves with an underground lake you can  
swim in.  this was one of the highlights of our trip. bring bug  
repellant!

-philip-

From: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>
Date: Fri, 9 Mar 2007 19:06:23 -0500
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: anyone been to cozumel???

Personally I wouldn't stay in Cozumel unless you wouldn't get  
restless spending an entire vacation in the city of Monterey (I  
would).  I think Playa or Akumel are better choices if you want to  
explore all the pyramids, I rented a car for about $300 a week, that  
included the Mexican insurance.  If you do that, I think the most fun  
way to do it is drive on the back roads, sure they're potholed but  
you get to see how the locals live, pretty much like they did a  
thousand years ago except they have lights in their grass huts and  
they sell beautiful art.

Before my last trip there I purchased a wonderful book called The  
Yucatan by Antoinette May, it's a great all around tour book and  
tells you her opinion on the best places to stay and eat and see in  
the entire region, so if you do decide to stay in Cozumel that's a  
good book to help you decide.

If you can make it out to the Balakanche Caves, it's a very sacred  
Mayan site.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] nrr: anyone been to cozumel???


i just came back from playa del carmen and tulum.  we stayed near playa for=
 half of the time and in tulum the other half.
that worked out well since playa is a lot more touristy and active, while t=
ulum is a quiter, lie on the beach type of place.=20
tulum has a range of lodging options, from bare bones huts for ~$30/night t=
o nicer cabana hotels for ~150/night to a few nicer small hotels.
in tulum we stayed at zamas(zamas.com) which was pretty nice, but if you se=
arch around online you can find all kinds of places to stay.
the ruins in tulum are pretty cool because they sit on a cliff overlooking =
an amazing beach and ocean.
there's also numerous cenotes(underwater rivers/lakes) in the tulum area.

i have a few of our photos on flickr - http://www.flickr.com/photos/9333679=
3@N00/sets/72157594556445642/

email me if you want any more info on the area.




----------------------------------------

http://webexhibits.org/daylightsaving/b.html

When we change our clocks

Beginning in 2007, most of the United States begins Daylight Saving Time at 2:00 a.m. on the second Sunday in March and reverts to standard time on the first Sunday in November. In the U.S., each time zone switches at a different time.


Spring forward, Fall back

During DST, clocks are turned forward an hour, effectively moving an hour of daylight from the morning to the evening.


Date change in 2007

On August 8, 2005, President George W. Bush signed the Energy Policy Act of 2005. This Act changed the time change dates for Daylight Saving Time in the U.S. Beginning in 2007, DST will begin on the second Sunday in March and end the first Sunday in November. The Secretary of Energy will report the impact of this change to Congress. Congress retains the right to resume the 2005 Daylight Saving Time schedule once the Department of Energy study is complete.


When in the morning?

In the U.S., clocks change at 2:00 a.m. local time. In spring, clocks spring forward from 1:59 a.m. to 3:00 a.m.; in fall, clocks fall back from 1:59 a.m. to 1:00 a.m. In the EU, clocks change at 1:00 a.m. Universal Time. In spring, clocks spring forward from 12:59 a.m. to 2:00 a.m.; in fall, clocks fall back from 1:59 a.m. to 1:00 a.m.

In the U.S., restaurants and bars have various closing policies. In many states, liquor cannot be served after 2:00 a.m. But at 2:00 a.m. in the fall, the time switches back one hour. So, can they serve alcohol for that additional hour in October? The official answer is that the bars do not stop serving liquor at 2:00 a.m., but actually at 1:59 a.m. So, they have already stopped serving when the time changes from Daylight Saving Time into Standard Time. In practice, however, many establishments stay open an extra hour in the fall.
In the U.S., 2:00 a.m. was originally chosen as the changeover time because it was practical and minimized disruption. Most people were at home and this was the time when the fewest trains were running. It is late enough to minimally affect bars and restaurants, and it prevents the day from switching to yesterday, which would be confusing. It is early enough that the entire continental U.S. switches by daybreak, and the changeover occurs before most early shift workers and early churchgoers are affected.

Some U.S. areas

For the U.S. and its territories, Daylight Saving Time is NOT observed in Hawaii, American Samoa, Guam, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, and Arizona. The Navajo Nation participates in the Daylight Saving Time policy, even in Arizona, due to its large size and location in three states.


 
---------------------------------
8:00? 8:25? 8:40?  Find a flick in no time
 with theYahoo! Search movie showtime shortcut.
--0-239277150-1173581794=:8042--

> >>
> >>Some U.S. areas
> >>
> >>For the U.S. and its territories, Daylight Saving Time is NOT observed=
 in
> >>Hawaii, American Samoa, Guam, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, and
> >> Arizona.
> >>The Navajo Nation participates in the Daylight Saving Time policy, even
> >> in
> >>Arizona, due to its large size and location in three states.
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>---------------------------------
> >>8:00? 8:25? 8:40?  Find a flick in no time
> >>  with theYahoo! Search movie showtime shortcut.
> >

> > Play Flexicon: the crossword game that feeds your brain. PLAY now for
> > FREE.

I never notice a huge diff. between pressies and capsules, other than 
feeling slightly more worn out, I would guess it being due to adulterants in 
pressies.

That being said, since I've seen you mention that you're supposed to be on 
ainti-depressants, and knowing E can mess with your brain chemistry, I'd say 
maybe you lay off pills altogether for a while.

Also, if you have done a good deal of it in the past, you may need a solid 
year or so off of doing them in order to let your brain really have a good 
recovery from the damage it does. Sounds like you're really getting nasty e 
hangover, and that means it's time to ease back big time.

I've had some pills that really jacked me up before. Most likely a DXM/MDMA
combo. I got bad seritonin syndrome with a bad headache, my arms went numb,
and my hand and arm locked up like a lobster claw and I couldn't move it. It
freaked me out.

them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles  
for your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're  
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

of empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another  
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and  
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  - 
Fritz Williams

Yuri's Night Bay Area 2007 - A Space and Sound Expo
at NASA's Ames Research Center - Moffatt Field Hangar 211*
Mountain View, CA, USA, Earth, Milky Way
13 April 2007

Join Us to Celebrate a Very Special Night in Honor of Yuri Gagarin -  
First Man in Space

Yuri's Night is a World Space Party celebrated at over 90 events in  
30 countries to commemorate the anniversary of the Vostok 1 Launch.  
The 2007 San Francisco Bay Area Yuri's Night will take place on April  
13 at NASA's Ames Research Facility* in Mountain View, California.  
This event is brought to you by Nexus and Symbiosis Events.

www.WorldSpaceParty.com

Featuring the SOUNDS of:

PLAID - Live (Warp Records - UK) - Special 2-Hour Live Plaid Set!
TELEFON TEL AVIV - Live (Hefty Records)
SUTEKH - Live (Context, Soul Jazz, Leaf)
OOAH + BORETA - Live (Glitch Mob)
MR. PROJECTILE & JONAH SHARP (aka SPACETIME CONTINUUM) - Live
(Reflective, Astralwerks; Semi-Sexual)
The Glitch Mob RD - Live (Designed Disorder - LA)
WELDER - Live (Cyberset SF)
MOZAIC (Nexus)
DR. TOAST - Live (False Profit)
and many more TBA...

SPECIAL GUEST SPEAKERS
Hosted by Keynote Speaker ANOUSHEH ANSARI
The first privately-funded female space explorer!

SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
Interact with technological exhibits and displays from the world of  
space and science. Second Life Kiosks, Intergalactic Siloutte  
Dancing, Multi-Dimensional Jump Rope, and much more will be presented  
for your entertainment and education....

ART INSTALLATIONS, DECOR, and PERFORMANCE ART
Dazzle your senses a wide array of visual stimulation and interactive  
performances from world-class artists of all kinds. Intergalactic  
stilting, Orbital LED hooping, Celestial light performance, UFO  
flowplanes, and a Parade from the Future are only some of the magic  
in store for you...

Rotations and Revolutions:
KC Bella Fuega (Orbital hooping and bellydance)
Flowtoys (Celestial light performance and UFO flowplanes)
VigilAntiUP (Intergalactic stilting)
Parade from the Future (Featuring circuit benders and other-worldly  
creatures)

We hope you will join us for this epic adventure into the world of  
Space, Science, Sound, and Art...

www.WorldSpaceParty.com

Brought to You by:
Nexus - www.nexusorg.org
Symbiosis - www.symbiosisevents.com . www.symbiosisgathering.com
..and an amazing crew of dedicated volunteers! Get Involved:  
www.worldspaceparty.com/volunteers.php

*Pending Finalized Legal Approval
References to NASA Ames shall not be construed as official NASA  
approval or endorsement of any non-Governmental or commercial entity  
or activity.

them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles  
for your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're  
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap  
of empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another  
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and  
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  - 
Fritz Williams

but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson

ainti-depressants, and knowing E can mess with your brain chemistry, I'd say 
maybe you lay off pills altogether for a while.

year or so off of doing them in order to let your brain really have a good 
recovery from the damage it does. Sounds like you're really getting nasty e 
hangover, and that means it's time to ease back big time.

better riding experience at speeds that won't put you in handcuffs.

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Subject: [sfraves] And now, for a funny trip down memory lane...


For those of you who might think I was always jaded... here's an old 
backup of my website I found covering the dates 1997-1998, complete with 
my old DJ calendar & reviews section (this was a genuinely interesting 
time in the SF scene, and many of our list's DJs saw a meteoric rise in 
popularity as house [and to a lesser degree breaks] became almost purely 
club music & massive music for a while and a host of energetic new crews 
filled the void throwing illegal parties).

http://saturn5.com/andy/old/author.htm

A funny walk down memory lane, from when I first started playing out at 
parties (i'd been doing house parties a bit before that).  And maybe, just 
maybe had a more positive outlook.

Anyway, had to come to grips with this being ten years old, and there was 
enough funny shit in there that I thought I'd post it for old times' 
sake... some of the first Viberation events, Tom & Stacy parties, the 
Harmony 5 year bust, some SoCal desert events, SFR list goings on, the 
legendary Static, good stuff!

I'll see if I can find a copy of an old set to go with it... but there you 
have it for now.

Enjoy!
andyw

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

If it's an issue for you, then I'd suggest starting with Patti Smith's 
'Horses' and 'Easter' and once your ears have gotten tuned, you can then 
work your way up to the sounds of records being scratched on turntables 
as being a valid form of artistic expression in this milieu.

It'll be another 5 years before the Beastie Boys are eligible, and lord 
knows what it's going to take for NWA to get their props, bet you won't 
be bitching then.

:-P

~nwa

On 3/12/07, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
> For those of you who might think I was always jaded... here's an old
> backup of my website I found covering the dates 1997-1998, complete with
> my old DJ calendar & reviews section (this was a genuinely interesting
> time in the SF scene, and many of our list's DJs saw a meteoric rise in
> popularity as house [and to a lesser degree breaks] became almost purely
> club music & massive music for a while and a host of energetic new crews
> filled the void throwing illegal parties).
>
> http://saturn5.com/andy/old/author.htm
>
> A funny walk down memory lane, from when I first started playing out at
> parties (i'd been doing house parties a bit before that).  And maybe, just
> maybe had a more positive outlook.
>
> Anyway, had to come to grips with this being ten years old, and there was
> enough funny shit in there that I thought I'd post it for old times'
> sake... some of the first Viberation events, Tom & Stacy parties, the
> Harmony 5 year bust, some SoCal desert events, SFR list goings on, the
> legendary Static, good stuff!
>
> I'll see if I can find a copy of an old set to go with it... but there you
> have it for now.
>
> Enjoy!
> andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves] It's about fucking time

FUCK YEAH.

Punk rock, bitches.

Tonight was only the second time in my life I got to see her live, 
(missed this show http://tinyurl.com/27j7g5 of hers back last October, 
as did everyone else out on the sidewalk), but the first time I saw her, 
in May of 1979, at the Palladium, (today an NYU dormitory with a plaque 
outside commemorating its history, very sad), it was like being shot out 
of a motherfucking cannon.

Tonight was no different.

But then again, what can you expect from a chick that blew away Jimi 
Hendrix on the first note of the first song she ever released to the 
world at large?

BTW, trivia question.

I had a list of 4 White Americans that got to use the *N* word with 
impunity, (if anybody was gonna say anything tonight it would have been 
Mr.Sharpton, and he didn't), and I had Mark Twain, Quentin Tarantino, 
and Patti Smith, all who got a pass on 'artistic license', but I can't 
think of the 4th white person.

I know it's not Michael Richards, so if anybody wants to help a bruva 
out, Apollo, feel free to chime in, it will be much appreciated.

Thanks!

~nwa

ps: the reason she peed on the sidewalk is prolly because she was scared 
shitless

the man speaks the truth.

with that, since we're on the topic of bikes, if anyone is interested in a 
basket-case '95 CBR900 with 17' wheel conversion and Metzler R2 tires with 
about 600mi on them - they've about 4yr old but protected from the sun 
entire time - i've got one to get ride of.

now all the fairing is broken and in a box, the tank is smashed, and the 
block got a small punch through in the same place they all do during a 
wreck... at the oil sensor hole - jbweld is how we all fix them.  otherwise, 
engine is race-ready- gps-verified 168mph top speed - D&D slip-on, 520 chain 
conversion, pedal relocators (so you don't drag the pegs with the 
cat-on-velcro Metzlers when your draggin' a knee through The Carousel ;)

it's yours for $600 firm, which is about the value of the 17" 600 wheel 
conversion alone.  will not part out 'cause i need this bitch gone. 
obviously a salvaged title but fully legit to register if you want to put in 
the time and have a badass rat bike for next to no money.

this used to be the bike: 
http://www.se30.com/users/grindingbassline/pix/album01/IMG_2113

(sexy raver chick not included :)

-=dave

wrecking bikes is g r a t e !

> Tonight was only the second time in my life I got to see her live,  
> (missed this show http://tinyurl.com/27j7g5 of hers back last  
> October, as did everyone else out on the sidewalk), but the first  
> time I saw her, in May of 1979, at the Palladium, (today an NYU  
> dormitory with a plaque outside commemorating its history, very  
> sad), it was like being shot out of a motherfucking cannon.
>
> Tonight was no different.
>
> But then again, what can you expect from a chick that blew away  
> Jimi Hendrix on the first note of the first song she ever released  
> to the world at large?
>
> BTW, trivia question.
>
> I had a list of 4 White Americans that got to use the *N* word with  
> impunity, (if anybody was gonna say anything tonight it would have  
> been Mr.Sharpton, and he didn't), and I had Mark Twain, Quentin  
> Tarantino, and Patti Smith, all who got a pass on 'artistic  
> license', but I can't think of the 4th white person.
>
> I know it's not Michael Richards, so if anybody wants to help a  
> bruva out, Apollo, feel free to chime in, it will be much appreciated.
>
> Thanks!
>
> ~nwa
>
> ps: the reason she peed on the sidewalk is prolly because she was  
> scared shitless
>

TB, that might as well be a Neneh Cherry, Happy Mondays, Inspiral Carpets 
or Shamen video.

Ok, found a set I put out from back then (there's a weird turn down in the 
volume a bit into it... like I answered a phone call or something, it just 
annoys me cause it's out of phrase and kinda sudden)... but it's what I 
was playing peak hour back then.  That set is called "stoopid" (cut in my 
home studio on three decks circa late 98 on a PMC-17).

Also, in a couple minutes there should be the set that's had me sorta 
bouncing all morning), from Poznan, Poland - Marcin Czubala (think of 
him as eastern europe's answer to Niel Landstrum).  This is just my kinda 
techno, dorky and fun all at the same time.  Think this set is about two 
years old, so it doesn't fit in with the retro vibe but I just liked it 
too much to not share.

http://www.saturn5.com/andy/old/music/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] It's about fucking time

so trance that samples classical music is also classical?

Hell No.

Another example:  Ram Jam remade Lead Belly Ledbetter's "Black 
Betty."  The original was a folk song.  The remake was a rock song.

Just because rock is sampled, the end product is not necessarily rock.


sarilion

AndyW wrote:

> For those of you who might think I was always jaded... here's an old
> backup of my website I found covering the dates 1997-1998, complete with
> my old DJ calendar & reviews section (this was a genuinely interesting
> time in the SF scene, and many of our list's DJs saw a meteoric rise in
> popularity as house [and to a lesser degree breaks] became almost purely
> club music & massive music for a while and a host of energetic new crews
> filled the void throwing illegal parties).
>

> parties (i'd been doing house parties a bit before that).  And maybe, just
> maybe had a more positive outlook.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] It's about fucking time

RockNroll is more a concept than a specific style/genre. It's an attitude, 
or at least, it started off that way. The fusion of rhythm & blues and 
'tude. Guess where the rhythm & blues came from  black folks. Guess who 
started hip-hop...

You can't stretch your mind far enough to conceptualize that?




>From: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] It's about fucking time
>Date: Tue, 13 Mar 2007 18:18:33 -0700
>
>so trance that samples classical music is also classical?
>
>Hell No.
>
>Another example:  Ram Jam remade Lead Belly Ledbetter's "Black Betty."  The 
>original was a folk song.  The remake was a rock song.
>
>Just because rock is sampled, the end product is not necessarily rock.
>
>
>sarilion
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] It's about fucking time

I didn't respond to you for a reason- but come on man-

Oh ok- so Rock and Roll is just a concept- and thus- any random  
Jungle track, because of its use of the R&B amen break, as well as  
its attitude, is thus Rock?
Are you listening to yourself?

Take step a back- art involves innovation.
Art involves taking the old and creating the new.
Art by its very nature is derivative.
Even the earliest cave painters painted only what they had already  
seen roaming the savannah.

Led Zeppelin, my #1 group anywhere, was entirely influenced by the  
R&B at the time-
Does that make them any less worthy in my mind?
Hell no- I mean- Pink Floyd is #2, but... Led Zeppelin released what-  
6 albums?
And there are only 3-4 songs on *all* of them that I dislike?
IMO they were surely better than anyone they got any inspiration from.

The key to enjoying art is to take it for what it is, not what  
inspired it.

Oh and just for the record- do you know where the term "rap" comes from?
Blondie - Rapture.
Yes- *gasp* a blonde white girl was actually the first true rapper.
All other rappers before her had simply talked over other people's  
songs.
She met Fab 5 Freddie, then was the first to talk over her *own*  
music- and things took off from there.

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

Subject: Re: [sfraves] It's about fucking time

Most of modern music is a trickle down (in one form or another) from 
rockNroll. So in an abstract way, yea, even Jungle could be considered it's 
own form of rock. I've heard more than one person mention it being the 
"heavy metal" of EDM.  There must be SOME reason people can make that 
connection.

But since you argue with me any time I say anything, it's not as if you 
letting me in on a little Blondie trivia (that any music fan worth his/her 
salt would already know) makes a whole fuck of a lotta difference. So climb 
on outta yer Chevy pickup truck, and turn off the "Big & Rich" for long 
enough to hear what me and a whole fuckload of other people are 
sayin'....the point is, enough people in this country have determined that 
hip-hop is worthy of being inducted into the "rockNroll" hall of fame, 
whether or not you agree.

Booya.

And just for the record - the fact that you think Led Zeppelin (whom I like, 
don't get me wrong) is BETTER than the people they took inspiration 
from...is well...questionable at best. I suppose you prefer Clapton solo 
moreso than The Cream.

Now climb on back up into yer Chevy, put yer Travis Tritt tape back on, 
salute your bust of Dubya, and move along.

From: Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net>
Date: Wed, 14 Mar 2007 10:26:48 -0700
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductees

Hi there,
      Well, I absolutely agreed with the following, including Led Zep  
being one of the greatest rock and roll groups of all time.
      That is, until the assertation that the word "Rap" comes from  
Blondie. First of all, I disagree that a true rapper is one that raps  
over their own music vs. someone else's, but even if we accept this  
as a premise, your argument just does not pass muster. Rapper's  
Delight was released in 1979, Rapture was released in 1980 and  
Blondie was certainly not the first person to talk over their own  
music. To begin with, Rapper's Delight is done with all live  
musicians and doesn't have a single sample on it.
       To go back further, Hip Hop is widely recognized as having  
been created by Kool Herc, who was heavily influenced by the Jamaican  
soundsystems of his youth, James Brown, and most importantly the Last  
Poets. The Last Poets most definitely rapped over their own music.  
You could even argue that songs like "Love is Strange" by Mickey &  
Sylvia were predecessors of Rap Music. Coincidentally, Sylvia  
Robinson was also the owner of Sugarhill Records, the label that put  
out Rapper's Delight.
      Trying to say that we get the term "rap" from Blondie is just  
plain wrong and really takes away from the rest of your argument.  
It's also insulting to the richness of black culture going back to  
rapping and proto-rapping in Blues, Jazz, and even earlier black music.


Re:
I didn't respond to you for a reason- but come on man-

Oh ok- so Rock and Roll is just a concept- and thus- any random
Jungle track, because of its use of the R&B amen break, as well as
its attitude, is thus Rock?
Are you listening to yourself?

Take step a back- art involves innovation.
Art involves taking the old and creating the new.
Art by its very nature is derivative.
Even the earliest cave painters painted only what they had already
seen roaming the savannah.

Led Zeppelin, my #1 group anywhere, was entirely influenced by the
R&B at the time-
Does that make them any less worthy in my mind?
Hell no- I mean- Pink Floyd is #2, but... Led Zeppelin released what-
6 albums?
And there are only 3-4 songs on *all* of them that I dislike?
IMO they were surely better than anyone they got any inspiration from.

The key to enjoying art is to take it for what it is, not what
inspired it.

Oh and just for the record- do you know where the term "rap" comes from?
Blondie - Rapture.
Yes- *gasp* a blonde white girl was actually the first true rapper.
All other rappers before her had simply talked over other people's
songs.
She met Fab 5 Freddie, then was the first to talk over her *own*
music- and things took off from there.

> -&e->> Harmony 5 year bust, some SoCal desert events, SFR list goings on, the
> -&e->> legendary Static, good stuff!
> -&e->>
> -&e->> I'll see if I can find a copy of an old set to go with it... but there
> -&e->> you
> -&e->> have it for now.
> -&e->>
> -&e->> Enjoy!
> -&e->> andyw

Subject: [sfraves] Track of the Day

When I was a wee lad (1981-1983) living in San Diego, the DJ at the  
local roller rink used to play electro breaks. I remember first  
hearing  "Jam On It", "Planet Rock", and this track there:

Twilight 22 - "Electric Kingdom"
   http://unsafe.nebcorp.com/~st_indigo/tunes/Electric_Kingdom.mp3

Roller skating, video games in the arcade, and electro breaks made up  
most of my summer breaks as a kid.  not bad.

enjoy!

On Mar 14, 2007, at 10:26 AM, Will Penna wrote:

> Hi there,
>      Well, I absolutely agreed with the following, including Led  
> Zep being one of the greatest rock and roll groups of all time.
>      That is, until the assertation that the word "Rap" comes from  
> Blondie. First of all, I disagree that a true rapper is one that  
> raps over their own music vs. someone else's, but even if we accept  
> this as a premise, your argument just does not pass muster.  
> Rapper's Delight was released in 1979, Rapture was released in 1980  
> and Blondie was certainly not the first person to talk over their  
> own music. To begin with, Rapper's Delight is done with all live  
> musicians and doesn't have a single sample on it.
>       To go back further, Hip Hop is widely recognized as having  
> been created by Kool Herc, who was heavily influenced by the  
> Jamaican soundsystems of his youth, James Brown, and most  
> importantly the Last Poets. The Last Poets most definitely rapped  
> over their own music. You could even argue that songs like "Love is  
> Strange" by Mickey & Sylvia were predecessors of Rap Music.  
> Coincidentally, Sylvia Robinson was also the owner of Sugarhill  
> Records, the label that put out Rapper's Delight.
>      Trying to say that we get the term "rap" from Blondie is just  
> plain wrong and really takes away from the rest of your argument.  
> It's also insulting to the richness of black culture going back to  
> rapping and proto-rapping in Blues, Jazz, and even earlier black  
> music.
>
>
> Re:
> I didn't respond to you for a reason- but come on man-
>
> Oh ok- so Rock and Roll is just a concept- and thus- any random
> Jungle track, because of its use of the R&B amen break, as well as
> its attitude, is thus Rock?
> Are you listening to yourself?
>
> Take step a back- art involves innovation.
> Art involves taking the old and creating the new.
> Art by its very nature is derivative.
> Even the earliest cave painters painted only what they had already
> seen roaming the savannah.
>
> Led Zeppelin, my #1 group anywhere, was entirely influenced by the
> R&B at the time-
> Does that make them any less worthy in my mind?
> Hell no- I mean- Pink Floyd is #2, but... Led Zeppelin released what-
> 6 albums?
> And there are only 3-4 songs on *all* of them that I dislike?
> IMO they were surely better than anyone they got any inspiration from.
>
> The key to enjoying art is to take it for what it is, not what
> inspired it.
>
> Oh and just for the record- do you know where the term "rap" comes  
> from?
> Blondie - Rapture.
> Yes- *gasp* a blonde white girl was actually the first true rapper.
> All other rappers before her had simply talked over other people's
> songs.
> She met Fab 5 Freddie, then was the first to talk over her *own*
> music- and things took off from there.
>
>
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] It's about fucking time


On Tue, 13 Mar 2007, Nathan Seven wrote:
-&e->I didn't respond to you for a reason- but come on man-
-&e->
-&e->Oh ok- so Rock and Roll is just a concept- and thus- any random Jungle
-&e->track, because of its use of the R&B amen break, as well as its attitude,
-&e->is thus Rock?
-&e->Are you listening to yourself?
-&e->
-&e->Take step a back- art involves innovation.
-&e->Art involves taking the old and creating the new.
-&e->Art by its very nature is derivative.
-&e->Even the earliest cave painters painted only what they had already seen
-&e->roaming the savannah.
-&e->
-&e->Led Zeppelin, my #1 group anywhere, was entirely influenced by the R&B at
-&e->the time-
-&e->Does that make them any less worthy in my mind?
-&e->Hell no- I mean- Pink Floyd is #2, but... Led Zeppelin released what- 6
-&e->albums?
-&e->And there are only 3-4 songs on *all* of them that I dislike?
-&e->IMO they were surely better than anyone they got any inspiration from.

I have some Howlin Wolf, Robert Johnson, Muddy Waters, John Lee Hooker, 
Son House, Skip James (and list goes on) that I think would blow Led 
Zeppelin off the stage.  In fact, when I first dropped the Robert Johnson 
boxed set in my cd player, I kept snapping out of my listening spot on the 
couch to bug out about *yet another* blatant ripoff (and NEVER with 
credit).  Squeeze that wallet till the juice runs down my leg....

Especially when you consider Led Zeps *severely* mastubatory egocentric 
stage antics and chemical self indulgence at the expense of their ability 
to realize they're on stage and getting paid to kick ass... I hold the 
people in the paragraph above in higher regard.

Add to the the incredible work prior to or being done in parallel to Led 
Zep's first couple albums (namely 13th Floor Elevators, Budgie, Black 
Sabbath, Cream and Jimi with both Band of Gypsies and the Experience)... 
and a lot of the thunder of those first opening strains of Communication 
Breakdown start to not sound so amazing (and mind you, hearing that first 
Zep album loud after being totally musically repressed changed my life as 
a teen).  In any case, the first two Zep albums are essential.  The first 
Peel sessions are incredible.  But almost every live boot I ever heard of 
them sounds like SHIT, and I'm not talking wow/flutter, crowd noise or bad 
acoustics.  By contrast, Skip James recorded almost everything we have of 
him today in a two day stint... one day on piano, one day on guitar in a 
studio... the story is almost too much like the "come and sing into a can" 
bit from O' Brother Where Art Thou.

Rock and Roll is a sound.  It was originally derived from blues, r&b, and 
has grown to absorb everything in it's path.  But I honestly don't think 
most of the prototype hip hop should be considered rock.  At the time hip 
hop came around, rock was dead.  Boston, Foghat, Triumph, Asia, and other 
shit like that were clogging up the channel and not letting in anything.  
I feel honestly weird about Patty Smith in there as well.  It's like 
getting a high five from the enemy you started out wanting to destroy.

Before the mp3 "revolution" stuck it to the man, the punk and hip hop 
undercurrents did (and they did it without fucking the artists... 
creativity won, listeners won, and we got Alternative Tentacles and Def 
Jam in the deal).

I'll shut up now.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v752.2)
References: <7B39C161-9B0D-49E7-AACD-E4EB328F4C8E@comcast.net>
X-Priority: 3
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed

From: Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net>
Date: Wed, 14 Mar 2007 20:11:40 -0700
To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR More Re: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductees

Fair enough, it is based on Good Times by Chic, but the melody was  
slightly changed and the music was played entirely live by sessions  
musicians at the insistence of Sylvia Robinson. So, as you say, up  
for debate. There is an even earlier song - Christmas Rappin' by  
Kurtis Blow that was also played using live instruments and came out  
well before Blondie's Rapture. Again, I agreed with most of your  
points, just took umbrage with the idea that the term "rap"originated  
with Blondie.

Re:
Huh- I had thought that the music in Rapper's Delight was just a  
couple sections of Good Times.

But I see now this appears to be up for debate, with some of the  
sounds being claimed to have been replayed live by their own band or  
something.

Ah well- not really core to the point I was trying to make, and I  
shouldn't have included it in the first place :)

Re:
Hi there,
      Well, I absolutely agreed with the following, including Led Zep  
being one of the greatest rock and roll groups of all time.
      That is, until the assertation that the word "Rap" comes from  
Blondie. First of all, I disagree that a true rapper is one that raps  
over their own music vs. someone else's, but even if we accept this  
as a premise, your argument just does not pass muster. Rapper's  
Delight was released in 1979, Rapture was released in 1980 and  
Blondie was certainly not the first person to talk over their own  
music. To begin with, Rapper's Delight is done with all live  
musicians and doesn't have a single sample on it.
       To go back further, Hip Hop is widely recognized as having  
been created by Kool Herc, who was heavily influenced by the Jamaican  
soundsystems of his youth, James Brown, and most importantly the Last  
Poets. The Last Poets most definitely rapped over their own music.  
You could even argue that songs like "Love is Strange" by Mickey &  
Sylvia were predecessors of Rap Music. Coincidentally, Sylvia  
Robinson was also the owner of Sugarhill Records, the label that put  
out Rapper's Delight.
      Trying to say that we get the term "rap" from Blondie is just  
plain wrong and really takes away from the rest of your argument.  
It's also insulting to the richness of black culture going back to  
rapping and proto-rapping in Blues, Jazz, and even earlier black music.

Re:
I didn't respond to you for a reason- but come on man-

Oh ok- so Rock and Roll is just a concept- and thus- any random
Jungle track, because of its use of the R&B amen break, as well as
its attitude, is thus Rock?
Are you listening to yourself?

Take step a back- art involves innovation.
Art involves taking the old and creating the new.
Art by its very nature is derivative.
Even the earliest cave painters painted only what they had already
seen roaming the savannah.

Led Zeppelin, my #1 group anywhere, was entirely influenced by the
R&B at the time-
Does that make them any less worthy in my mind?
Hell no- I mean- Pink Floyd is #2, but... Led Zeppelin released what-
6 albums?
And there are only 3-4 songs on *all* of them that I dislike?
IMO they were surely better than anyone they got any inspiration from.

The key to enjoying art is to take it for what it is, not what
inspired it.

Oh and just for the record- do you know where the term "rap" comes from?
Blondie - Rapture.
Yes- *gasp* a blonde white girl was actually the first true rapper.
All other rappers before her had simply talked over other people's
songs.
She met Fab 5 Freddie, then was the first to talk over her *own*
music- and things took off from there.

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

solid connections to the arm.  I don't like to resort to licking and =20
sticking them in there but a light lick seems to work.  You know?  But =20
man, these decks look in sorry shape.  I was thinking down the road =20
I'd want to have a really grand DJ console.

in crap.  Removable lid or hinged and springed for coffin type action =20

From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-1435664370-1173976583=:9232"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?

--0-1435664370-1173976583=:9232
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

hey SFR,

recent events in the world of bay area parties have started the wheels turning in my little brain. this list is full of partiers old school and new, so i'm hoping to get a good variety of opinions on what is acceptable in the party scene and what is not.

what do you guys think of parties that get busted or otherwise end prematurely? are there instances when this is forgivable, even expected? or do you feel that organizers, promoters, etc. have a responsibility to their attendees to make sure a party lives up to all it advertised? there was a big bash this past weekend in oakland with a ton of talent and mass hype, and it was meant to last until who knows when... sort of a "party til you drop" environment. big fun. unfortunately the party was busted by the cops, and i think music ended around midnight-ish and patrons were booted from the space by 2am. reactions have mostly fallen into one of two categories:

1) hey, it's an underground party, sometimes they get busted. shit happens in the ug scene - people try really hard to put together something awesome, but given the nature of these kind of parties, sometimes things go awry. 

2) the event organizers owe all these party people something. they paid $15 at the door for a certain kind of party experience and they did not get it. if a party is going to be pumped up this much, it should be properly permitted, etc.

so what do you guys think? if you were at a party that was meant to go until, let's say, 6am, would you be upset if it were shut down at 2am instead? what about 4am? does it make a difference if there was a cover charge or not? when it comes to throwing parties outside of fully permitted, squeaky clean club venues, what exactly do party organizers owe the people who come out to have a good time and support the event?

all opinions welcome...

love,
mo

Get new email alerts with the free Yahoo! Toolbar.
--0-1435664370-1173976583=:9232--

Message-ID: <45F98423.90103@gmail.com>
Date: Thu, 15 Mar 2007 12:36:35 -0500
From: Nate <singinius@gmail.com>
User-Agent: Thunderbird 1.5.0.10 (Windows/20070221)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To:  sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <20070315163623.9239.qmail@web51509.mail.re2.yahoo.com>
In-Reply-To: <20070315163623.9239.qmail@web51509.mail.re2.yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?

I have been to many many parties over the past 10 years that have been 
closed early. I think this is a fairly complicated issue and not very 
simple to judge from the outside. I think when are party is closed 
early, everyone suffers. I suppose it is possible that the promoters 
could still be making out from ticket sales but that varies a lot from 
event to event and I do not think it is the norm.

I think promoters who consistently do the 'right thing' are the ones I 
will support and return to their parties. Doing the 'right thing' could 
vary from booking talent I like, to creating a nice atmosphere, finding 
an interesting new venue, to throwing a free party after one of theirs 
got shut down early.

Generally, after a party gets shut down, I am rarely upset at the 
promoters. I am upset at the unfortunate stuation, but at no one in 
particular. I am sure one factor of this is that I don't believe I have 
ever paid more that $15-20 for a party that has been shut down. If a 
party I paid something like $40-50 for was shut down I think i might 
have more of a reason to complain. However, I think this is indicative 
of the legal legitimacy of the event. I feel like the more I pay for an 
event the more I should be able to expect that it is going to be ran in 
a legal way and I am going to stand a higher chance of getting my monies 
worth.

That's my $.02...

SIN out!


mo corleone wrote:
> hey SFR,
>
> recent events in the world of bay area parties have started the wheels turning in my little brain. this list is full of partiers old school and new, so i'm hoping to get a good variety of opinions on what is acceptable in the party scene and what is not.
>
> what do you guys think of parties that get busted or otherwise end prematurely? are there instances when this is forgivable, even expected? or do you feel that organizers, promoters, etc. have a responsibility to their attendees to make sure a party lives up to all it advertised? there was a big bash this past weekend in oakland with a ton of talent and mass hype, and it was meant to last until who knows when... sort of a "party til you drop" environment. big fun. unfortunately the party was busted by the cops, and i think music ended around midnight-ish and patrons were booted from the space by 2am. reactions have mostly fallen into one of two categories:
>
> 1) hey, it's an underground party, sometimes they get busted. shit happens in the ug scene - people try really hard to put together something awesome, but given the nature of these kind of parties, sometimes things go awry. 
>
> 2) the event organizers owe all these party people something. they paid $15 at the door for a certain kind of party experience and they did not get it. if a party is going to be pumped up this much, it should be properly permitted, etc.
>
> so what do you guys think? if you were at a party that was meant to go until, let's say, 6am, would you be upset if it were shut down at 2am instead? what about 4am? does it make a difference if there was a cover charge or not? when it comes to throwing parties outside of fully permitted, squeaky clean club venues, what exactly do party organizers owe the people who come out to have a good time and support the event?
>
> all opinions welcome...
>
> love,
> mo
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?

------=_Part_56839_349072.1173980545708
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I heard there were quite a few busts over the weekend.... from the zapas
party to the dustfish massive both in oakland, to few other outdoor
renegades in SF as well.  If you've been partying for at least a year, you
should be familiar with the local crews, what type of parties they put on,
etc etc.  My thoughts are as follows, parties cost money, sometimes a big
heap of money.  Sometimes what happens is out of the promoters hands, other
times they're engaged in questionable practices in promoting/throwing
parties, and will go so far as false advertising (ie, saying an event it
permitted until 6am when it's not).  However, the party people need to use
some common sense.  When I saw the size of the Dustfish Massive, I knew
there was no way this could fly under the nose of the OPD.  When was the
last time Oakland had a fully permitted party in a HUGE warehouse???  My
experience with parties has been good crews will always try to do some type
of makeup party-  it may not be as large or have the talen the original
party did- but they know they owe something to all their loyal attendees who
make their events profitable.  On the flipside-  a lot of crews do not fall
in this category- which is partially why I'm pretty picky about the few
parties I do make it out to now.  A little research and common sense will
make your partying experience that much better... but in the world of
electronic music-  busts are inevitable.  You're gonna have to learn to cope
with it at some point.

Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 15 Mar 2007 10:12:36 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?

The big questions I ask, that determine whether or not I don't mind the 
bust, or whether or not I sort of "blame" the promoters are:

1. How blatant were they about promotions? If it's a UG, there have to be 
safety measures taken to insure promotions don't go out (en masse) to the 
"wrong" people. (i.e. irresponsible kids, cops, etc.)

2. How covert were they at the venue? Are kids milling about all over the 
sidewalk? Are shuttles in use? Are security good about getting people in off 
the street?

3. How obnoxiously loud is the music from the street? Can you hear the 
system from blocks away? If so - are there people living nearby?

Basically, if the promoters have no sense of stealthiness, then I hold them 
far more responsible. If they just have a bunch of dumb ass kids there that 
are being over the top and excessively noticeable, then, even though I think 
the promoters should be a bit more selective about WHO they promote to, 
ultimately the attendees have to show SOME respect and responsibility.

Finally, if the promoters did a massively piss poor job with 
security/organizing the event/being cautious, etc. - then they just suck. 
(that "massive" that was supposed to happen last summer in Sacramento - 
Sacramento Summer Music Festival - comes to mind in regards to huge fuck 
ups)

LOL risotto...

I ride an 02 Gixxer 6 and it is nice a lil on the heavy side when compared 
to the newer bikes (I.E R1,new Gixxer, Truimph etc..) but it is still a 
decent bike to have. Lots of power im getting mine geared down for better 
low end. (I.E 520 Chain conversion) im going one down in the front and one 
up in the back. Vortex and D.I.D gold chain stylie!!  like andy said the 
SV650 is a freakin solid bike cheap and from what I hear fun to ride. I 
might get one as a track bike. You can normally pick uup a SV at fremont 
cycle salvage for about 3k in good condition. Matter of fact I just saw 3 
posted on there site the other day. (www.fremontcyclesalvage.com)

as far as im concerned the Italian or "European" bikes for that matter are 
far to over rated. They are expensive, sound like shit (Ducati 776 ,9 series 
etc) and that is the only name people seem to know when people talk to me 
about bikes Ducati this and that.. or aprilia etc..

But none of those bikes are winning the AMA's or Grand Prix's now are 
they!!!

Who are running the top bikes Suzuki, Honda,Yamaha  But then again im sure 
the top riders could win on just about any bike  ;-)

Enough of my seneless ramblings..

If you want "Looks" you can't beat an R1 or R6 they are just Tits when it 
comes to design
you got $$ buy a CBR 600RR expensive but a solid ride.
You like snazzy colors get a Kawasaki ZX6RR (07 model is super tits and fun 
to ride)
You want the lady's to drool you get the "Gixxer"

From: Nate <singinius@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?
Date: Thu, 15 Mar 2007 12:36:35 -0500

I have been to many many parties over the past 10 years that have been 
closed early. I think this is a fairly complicated issue and not very simple 
to judge from the outside. I think when are party is closed early, everyone 
suffers. I suppose it is possible that the promoters could still be making 
out from ticket sales but that varies a lot from event to event and I do not 
think it is the norm.

I think promoters who consistently do the 'right thing' are the ones I will 
support and return to their parties. Doing the 'right thing' could vary from 
booking talent I like, to creating a nice atmosphere, finding an interesting 
new venue, to throwing a free party after one of theirs got shut down early.

Generally, after a party gets shut down, I am rarely upset at the promoters. 
I am upset at the unfortunate stuation, but at no one in particular. I am 
sure one factor of this is that I don't believe I have ever paid more that 
$15-20 for a party that has been shut down. If a party I paid something like 
$40-50 for was shut down I think i might have more of a reason to complain. 
However, I think this is indicative of the legal legitimacy of the event. I 
feel like the more I pay for an event the more I should be able to expect 
that it is going to be ran in a legal way and I am going to stand a higher 
chance of getting my monies worth.

That's my $.02...

SIN out!


mo corleone wrote:
>hey SFR,
>
>recent events in the world of bay area parties have started the wheels 
>turning in my little brain. this list is full of partiers old school and 
>new, so i'm hoping to get a good variety of opinions on what is acceptable 
>in the party scene and what is not.
>
>what do you guys think of parties that get busted or otherwise end 
>prematurely? are there instances when this is forgivable, even expected? or 
>do you feel that organizers, promoters, etc. have a responsibility to their 
>attendees to make sure a party lives up to all it advertised? there was a 
>big bash this past weekend in oakland with a ton of talent and mass hype, 
>and it was meant to last until who knows when... sort of a "party til you 
>drop" environment. big fun. unfortunately the party was busted by the cops, 
>and i think music ended around midnight-ish and patrons were booted from 
>the space by 2am. reactions have mostly fallen into one of two categories:
>
>1) hey, it's an underground party, sometimes they get busted. shit happens 
>in the ug scene - people try really hard to put together something awesome, 
>but given the nature of these kind of parties, sometimes things go awry.
>
>2) the event organizers owe all these party people something. they paid $15 
>at the door for a certain kind of party experience and they did not get it. 
>if a party is going to be pumped up this much, it should be properly 
>permitted, etc.
>
>so what do you guys think? if you were at a party that was meant to go 
>until, let's say, 6am, would you be upset if it were shut down at 2am 
>instead? what about 4am? does it make a difference if there was a cover 
>charge or not? when it comes to throwing parties outside of fully 
>permitted, squeaky clean club venues, what exactly do party organizers owe 
>the people who come out to have a good time and support the event?
>
>all opinions welcome...
>
>love,
>mo
>

>It's here! Your new message!
>Get new email alerts with the free Yahoo! Toolbar.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Tonal - Shamrock Green w/ Justin Long this Friday!

Friday, March 16th

11 PM 'til very late
Rock It Science, Prismatic Tracks, Crush Collective, and sfhousemusic.com
present:

Tonal: Shamrock Green

Raw SF Warehouse Location: call 888-482-9281 or 415-412-0406, or visit
prismatictracks.com or sfhousemusic.com the day of for directions $10 before
midnight, $15 after
$5 discount for dressing UP in Shamrock Green (at door person's
discretion--make some serious effort people!)
 
Before you have time to stop talking about how incredibly intimate, vibey,
and fantastically dressed up the crowd at Fire Engine Red was, not to
mention Miles Maeda's set, we are proud to annouce Tonal: Shamrock Green!
Yes, as if you needed another excuse to get wasted this is St. Patty's Day
weekend.  Get ready for the next throwdown in this series of sick new color
themed parties brought to you by some of the hottest crews in the
underground house scene. Tonal parties continue showcase talent flown in
from out of town as well as some of your favorite local house jocks. We look
forward to continuing to bring you high quality events, so strap on your
dancing shoes, bring everybody you know and get ready to move it! 
 
DJ's:
 
Justin Long (Dotbleep, No Assembly Firm, Chicago)
 
We are incredibly excited to have one of the sickest dj's we've ever seen
ready to rip the decks to shreds for this one!  Justin beats the dancefloor
up like few others, tearing through jackin' chicago beats, acid house, techy
glitchy dirty madness, and anything else that will make you lose your mind
and stomp your feet.  His label Dotbleep consistently puts out some of the
hottest tracks around, and his remix and production work with Dan X under
the moniker No Assembly Firm routinely works dancefloors into a frenzy.  If
you've missed Justin's sets at Stompy or the Endup we are not quite sure
what you've been thinking.  Get ready for a serious treat live and direct
from the Windy City!  www.myspace.com/dj_justinlong

Deron Delgado (Stompy, Good Family)
 
DJ, Producer, Label boss, and part of a growing internet empire (stompy.com)
pushing funky, pumping tunes into the cd decks of dj's across the globe,
Deron Delgado is a huge part of the dance music community in San Francisco
and beyond.  Deron's dj sets always seem to have the perfect blend of hot
tracks that have yet to even hit the shelves, today's best cuts, and just
the right sprinkling of dancefloor classics all mixed to perfection.  We are
honored to have Deron closing the night out proper for us.
www.myspace.com/derondelgado
 
Andrew Phelan (Prismatic, Drop Music, So Sound) vs. Eric Sharp (Rock It
Science)

What happens when you take 2 talented local SF dj's and put them on the
decks together warming it up for one of their favorite dj's in the world?
Make sure you get your ass on the dancefloor to find out.  Andrew and Eric
both have crates that stretch far into the vaults of house music and you can
be sure that they will be digging deep to Tonally turn up the heat for this
one.  Work it out! 
 
Andrew Kelsey (Blue Collar Entertainment)

A veteran of SF's underground scene (some of you geezers may remember The
Fool), Andrew Kelsey has since graduated to building one of the fastest
growing booking agencies in the US, Blue Collar Entertainment.  Mr. Kelsey
has a nose for finding great dj's, which can probably be attributed to the
fact that he is a great dj himself.  We wish that Andrew spent a little bit
more time getting himself behind the decks, so we had to jump at the chance
to get him to rock it for you.  Get here early in time for the man to open
things up in high style!

BEATS FOR PEACE
A benefit for the How Weird Street Fair
Friday March 23, 2007

1015 Folsom
10 pm to 5 am
$20-30 sliding scale, $10 before 11 pm
Limited pre-sales for $15 (at WantTickets.com)
(21+ with ID)
babyHazel.org

You are invited to a benefit of epic proportions for two worthy  
causes as San Francisco's largest club will be transformed into a  
gathering of communities in the name of peace. 100% of the proceeds  
will go to the production of the 8th annual How Weird Street Faire  
and to the Baby Hazel Fund. Hazel is a sweet 11-month old girl who  
was recently diagnosed with cancer and needs help immediately. For  
more information on Hazel, and to donate, please visit http:// 
www.babyhazel.org
World Peace Through Technology Organization

The How Weird Street Faire is an experiment in creating peace,  
uniting the diverse art and music communities of the Bay Area. It is  
also a benefit and celebration for the non-profit World Peace Through  
Technology Organization (http://www.peacetour.org).

We've assembled an awesome collection of music and art representing  
some of the best the world has to offer. This is going to be a  
massive event, so please arrive early to avoid lines.


How Weird Benefit at 1015 Folsom! How Weird Benefit at 1015 Folsom!
The stats:

     * Five rooms of cutting edge music representing every stage from  
this year's How Weird Street Faire; hosted by CCC, Sunset, Tantra,  
Symbiosis, Earthdance, Lowpro Lounge, Dub Beautiful, False Profit,  
Music Without Borders, Get Freaky, Muti Music, and Raindance!
     * Two very worthwhile causes!
     * One amazing time!

The 8th annual How Weird Street Faire will take place on Sunday May  
6, 2007. This will be the last faire on Howard Street. We hope to see  
you there!

For more information, check out the website - www.HowWeird.org

The entire faire squeezed into a building, how weird is that?

"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid  
them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles  
for your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're  
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap  
of empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another  
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and  
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  - 
Fritz Williams

"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone,  
but it worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson
