Subject: RE: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?

--0-1289826472-1173988439=:62769
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=X-UNKNOWN; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8BIT

I heard on ravelinks there's a new crop of crews that are resorting to
weekly renegades at some old backup outdoor spots (like 24th &
Illinois, Daly City stables and marshs off Cargo). Using color flyers even
advertising multiple "stages", and also charging at the "door" by their
"security"?? I'm guessing the lack of (or complacency to look for) UG
spaces is prompting this.

I'm reading it's commonplace for people to bring guns and jack kids. Last
I heard at 24 & Illinois someone fired off an assault rifle and poured 
gasoline on the street an lit it on fire.

The ravelinks kids think these parties are the coolest shit since sliced
bread, and compare them to the movie Groove.

I'm frightened and disturbed by this, hopefully someone will pinch me and
I'll wake up.

-terry

On Thu, 15 Mar 2007, Van Mundegaarde wrote:

> The big questions I ask, that determine whether or not I don't mind the bust, 
> or whether or not I sort of "blame" the promoters are:
>
> 1. How blatant were they about promotions? If it's a UG, there have to be 
> safety measures taken to insure promotions don't go out (en masse) to the 
> "wrong" people. (i.e. irresponsible kids, cops, etc.)
>
> 2. How covert were they at the venue? Are kids milling about all over the 
> sidewalk? Are shuttles in use? Are security good about getting people in off 
> the street?
>
> 3. How obnoxiously loud is the music from the street? Can you hear the system 
> from blocks away? If so - are there people living nearby?
>
> Basically, if the promoters have no sense of stealthiness, then I hold them 
> far more responsible. If they just have a bunch of dumb ass kids there that 
> are being over the top and excessively noticeable, then, even though I think 
> the promoters should be a bit more selective about WHO they promote to, 
> ultimately the attendees have to show SOME respect and responsibility.
>
> Finally, if the promoters did a massively piss poor job with 
> security/organizing the event/being cautious, etc. - then they just suck. 
> (that "massive" that was supposed to happen last summer in Sacramento - 
> Sacramento Summer Music Festival - comes to mind in regards to huge fuck ups)
>
>
>
>
>> From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Subject: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?
>> Date: Thu, 15 Mar 2007 09:36:23 -0700 (PDT)
>> 
>> hey SFR,
>> 
>> recent events in the world of bay area parties have started the wheels 
>> turning in my little brain. this list is full of partiers old school and 
>> new, so i'm hoping to get a good variety of opinions on what is acceptable 
>> in the party scene and what is not.
>> 
>> what do you guys think of parties that get busted or otherwise end 
>> prematurely? are there instances when this is forgivable, even expected? or 
>> do you feel that organizers, promoters, etc. have a responsibility to their 
>> attendees to make sure a party lives up to all it advertised? there was a 
>> big bash this past weekend in oakland with a ton of talent and mass hype, 
>> and it was meant to last until who knows when... sort of a "party til you 
>> drop" environment. big fun. unfortunately the party was busted by the cops, 
>> and i think music ended around midnight-ish and patrons were booted from 
>> the space by 2am. reactions have mostly fallen into one of two categories:
>> 
>> 1) hey, it's an underground party, sometimes they get busted. shit happens 
>> in the ug scene - people try really hard to put together something awesome, 
>> but given the nature of these kind of parties, sometimes things go awry.
>> 
>> 2) the event organizers owe all these party people something. they paid $15 
>> at the door for a certain kind of party experience and they did not get it. 
>> if a party is going to be pumped up this much, it should be properly 
>> permitted, etc.
>> 
>> so what do you guys think? if you were at a party that was meant to go 
>> until, let's say, 6am, would you be upset if it were shut down at 2am 
>> instead? what about 4am? does it make a difference if there was a cover 
>> charge or not? when it comes to throwing parties outside of fully 
>> permitted, squeaky clean club venues, what exactly do party organizers owe 
>> the people who come out to have a good time and support the event?
>> 
>> all opinions welcome...
>> 
>> love,
>> mo
>> 
>> 
>> ---------------------------------
>> It's here! Your new message!
>> Get new email alerts with the free Yahoo! Toolbar.

To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?

well, it sounds like from this synopsis the smaller, more experienced  
crews should just keep doing what they've been doing for years now,  
keep them small and relatively unadvertised.  sfraves perhaps being  
one of the more low key hookup points.  the smart ravelinks kids will  
come around and realize that's not really what a rave is all about.   
didn't we go through this in '96 when hard trance became the median  
to which one judged/was judged by and deep house was suddenly  
considered as downtempo?  i'm not really trying to judge genres here,  
don't get me wrong, i'm just trying to compare some of the attitudes  
i'm hearing about, including those zombie raves with what i saw  
firsthand back then.

> me and
> I'll wake up.

>>The big questions I ask, that determine whether or not I don't mind the 
>>bust, or whether or not I sort of "blame" the promoters are:
>>
>>1. How blatant were they about promotions? If it's a UG, there have to be 
>>safety measures taken to insure promotions don't go out (en masse) to the 
>>"wrong" people. (i.e. irresponsible kids, cops, etc.)
>>
>>2. How covert were they at the venue? Are kids milling about all over the 
>>sidewalk? Are shuttles in use? Are security good about getting people in 
>>off the street?
>>

>>system from blocks away? If so - are there people living nearby?
>>

> The big questions I ask, that determine whether or not I don't mind  
> the bust, or whether or not I sort of "blame" the promoters are:
>
> 1. How blatant were they about promotions? If it's a UG, there have

> over the sidewalk? Are shuttles in use? Are security good about  
> getting people in off the street?

> the system from blocks away? If so - are there people living nearby?
>

> hold them far more responsible. If they just have a bunch of dumb  
> ass kids there that are being over the top and excessively  
> noticeable, then, even though I think the promoters should be a bit  
> more selective about WHO they promote to, ultimately the attendees  
> have to show SOME respect and responsibility.
>

> Sacramento - Sacramento Summer Music Festival - comes to mind in  
> regards to huge fuck ups)

Content-Disposition: inline

I think the reason these spots are gettin blown up is there accessibility.
I don't think the stables has experience this to the same point, as it would
require moving equipment with manpower- more than a few yards too.  IMHO,
I've been a strong advocate of straying away from these locations this
year.  We're blessed to have so many beautiful outdoor spots within an
hour's drive of SF- and I am quite thankful most of em you can't simply just
drive your truck up to and drop your equipment off.  Although it gets
progressively harder to throw outdoor renegades as the years passes...
However, forgotten treatusures suddenly rear there head again.  We were able
to pull off a full moon last month at one of the nicer beaches in santa cruz
county.... of course... sound wasn't up til 3:30am  ;)  I always thought a
longer drive, to a remote and unknown area was part of the adventure of
going to a party-  however, a few younger people I've spoken with this see
this as a reason to avoid such a party!  Bullocks!



On 3/15/07, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
>
>
> On Mar 15, 2007, at 11:12 AM, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>
> > The big questions I ask, that determine whether or not I don't mind
> > the bust, or whether or not I sort of "blame" the promoters are:
> >
> > 1. How blatant were they about promotions? If it's a UG, there have
> > to be safety measures taken to insure promotions don't go out (en
> > masse) to the "wrong" people. (i.e. irresponsible kids, cops, etc.)
> >
> > 2. How covert were they at the venue? Are kids milling about all
> > over the sidewalk? Are shuttles in use? Are security good about
> > getting people in off the street?
>
> Map points.  Any one remember these?
>
>
> >
> > 3. How obnoxiously loud is the music from the street? Can you hear
> > the system from blocks away? If so - are there people living nearby?
> >
> > Basically, if the promoters have no sense of stealthiness, then I
> > hold them far more responsible. If they just have a bunch of dumb
> > ass kids there that are being over the top and excessively
> > noticeable, then, even though I think the promoters should be a bit
> > more selective about WHO they promote to, ultimately the attendees
> > have to show SOME respect and responsibility.
> >
> > Finally, if the promoters did a massively piss poor job with
> > security/organizing the event/being cautious, etc. - then they just
> > suck. (that "massive" that was supposed to happen last summer in
> > Sacramento - Sacramento Summer Music Festival - comes to mind in
> > regards to huge fuck ups)
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >> From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
> >> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >> Subject: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?
> >> Date: Thu, 15 Mar 2007 09:36:23 -0700 (PDT)
> >>
> >> hey SFR,
> >>
> >> recent events in the world of bay area parties have started the
> >> wheels turning in my little brain. this list is full of partiers
> >> old school and new, so i'm hoping to get a good variety of
> >> opinions on what is acceptable in the party scene and what is not.
> >>
> >> what do you guys think of parties that get busted or otherwise end
> >> prematurely? are there instances when this is forgivable, even
> >> expected? or do you feel that organizers, promoters, etc. have a
> >> responsibility to their attendees to make sure a party lives up to
> >> all it advertised? there was a big bash this past weekend in
> >> oakland with a ton of talent and mass hype, and it was meant to
> >> last until who knows when... sort of a "party til you drop"
> >> environment. big fun. unfortunately the party was busted by the
> >> cops, and i think music ended around midnight-ish and patrons were
> >> booted from the space by 2am. reactions have mostly fallen into
> >> one of two categories:
> >>
> >> 1) hey, it's an underground party, sometimes they get busted. shit
> >> happens in the ug scene - people try really hard to put together
> >> something awesome, but given the nature of these kind of parties,
> >> sometimes things go awry.
> >>
> >> 2) the event organizers owe all these party people something. they
> >> paid $15 at the door for a certain kind of party experience and
> >> they did not get it. if a party is going to be pumped up this
> >> much, it should be properly permitted, etc.
> >>
> >> so what do you guys think? if you were at a party that was meant
> >> to go until, let's say, 6am, would you be upset if it were shut
> >> down at 2am instead? what about 4am? does it make a difference if
> >> there was a cover charge or not? when it comes to throwing parties
> >> outside of fully permitted, squeaky clean club venues, what
> >> exactly do party organizers owe the people who come out to have a
> >> good time and support the event?
> >>
> >> all opinions welcome...
> >>
> >> love,
> >> mo

Damn, that place is still being used?  Shows how out of touch I am.

I'm not sure about the "parties out of SF" thing, though.  Except for  
a couple at that place in Sunnyvale and some at peoples' houses, I've  
pretty much been unwilling to LEAVE San Francisco for parties for  
something like more than a year.  Ever since that party Spam threw at  
the crackhouse, where a bunch of the local thugs rushed the door,  
stole the cash box, shot the place up, and broke into a bunch of  
peoples' cars; I and most of the friends that i party with these days  
have been of the opinion that we're done with that side of the bridge.

> thoese who have seen the scene to show them the scene. Does that

makes sense to me... but is anyone listening?

--Apple-Mail-1-269354290
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

First off, it depends on who we're talking about forgiving.

Though I'm less inclined to mouth off about it these days, I'm still  
of the opinion that the pigs busting a party in the first place is  
pretty much always unforgivable.  As far as I'm concerned, so long as  
there is no violence going on, going out to a party falls under the  
first amendment: "the right of the people peaceably to assemble".   
Period.  End of discussion.  And unless there *IS* violence at a  
party, and they are responding to that violence, any cop that has any  
part in busting a party, or even showing its face at one, is  
undeserving of its badge, job, and American citizenship; and should  
have all three immediately and permanently revoked.  They want to be  
a bunch of petty, two-bit thugs lording it over the people instead of  
"serving and protecting" them; they should go do it in some third- 
world dictatorship, where their kind belongs.

But that is probably a bit too naively idealistic for reality.  So,  
working within the system we're stuck with, and as to wether or not  
promoters should be forgiven, it depends on a lot.

Sometimes, events are well and truly out of a promoter's control:

Once, I was at a party that had to shut down at 11pm-ish because a  
gas line burst in the next building over, making the risk that the  
venue could be "blown up" quite literal.  I don't think anybody could  
fault the promoter in the slightest for shutting things down.   
Actual, imminent, real danger of getting burninated == no complaint  
about going home early.

At one fully-permitted, ending-at-2am, and-so-on, party that was  
nevertheless getting busted; as we were filing out of the building, I  
found myself briefly standing behind the promoter, with his permit in  
hand, as the pig was bitching him out.  The exact words the issued  
forth from its mouth were: "I don't care if you have a permit or not;  
we don't want you people in our town.".  I'm not really sure there's  
much you can fault the promoter with if he's gone through all the  
hoops to have his event be permitted and legal, but the cops decide  
to go all Judge Dredd on him... except that maybe he have to have a  
lawyer on hand at the party if he ever tries to throw anything in  
livermore again.

The bulk of the time, though, promoters have at least some control in  
these things.  And a big part of wether a busted party is forgivable  
is wether the promoter was honest about the risks or not in the first  
place:

when there's no imminent danger to life and limb, and the pigs aren't  
doing the "My word *IS* the law!" thing; if a party is promoted as:  
"Fully secured and permitted venue." or similar, and/or costs >= $20;  
it damn well BETTER start not a minute later than the time listed on  
the flyer/BSP, end not a minute sooner, and have every single DJ  
advertised.  It's basic ethics and integrity... you deliver what you  
promise.

On the other hand, if a promoter wants to do things underground  
style, skip the permits, and rely on his wits and his attendees  
discretion and responsibility; I'm fine with that.  But he needs to  
let everyone know that's the case, and charge appropriately.  Having  
a free outdoor or $5 party at a loft somewhere busted is a whole lot  
more forgivable than anything I've dropped $20 or more on.

Then there are those parties when you walk in the door, have a look  
around, and know within the first five minutes that its getting  
busted.  Thats when you just go to the bathroom ('cuz you won't get  
the chance when everybody's being herded out), and start making a  
betting pool about how exactly WHEN the filth will show up.  When a  
party is that obviously poorly put together, it's obvious that the  
promoter was the FIRST one to know how fucked things are, but just  
didn't care and threw it anyway to extract as much money as he could  
before things got shut down.  That's pretty much unforgivable.

The promoters' response to a bust makes a big difference too:

I know that some people here like to hate on them, but one of my  
favorite crews used to be Happy Kids.  At one time, I'd been to more  
Happy Kids' parties than those of any other promoter.  Three of them  
were busted; but I kept coming back because of the stand-up way Marty  
handled things.  In all three cases, he was on the phone immediately  
trying to throw together an afterparty, and anyone who wasn't quite  
ready to drive yet was welcome to stick around and "help clean up".   
In one, your ticket stub was good to get you in to his next party, in  
another it was good for you AND a friend.  And in two of the three  
busts I was there for, about an hour after the pigs had left, he  
turned the music back on, updated the infoline to tell everyone to  
come back to the original venue, and we partied till dawn.   
Regardless of their other faults, *THAT* is how a promoter who cares  
handles busts; and if he were to start throwing parties regularly  
again (Though I actually hope, for his sake, that he doesn't.) I'd  
happily be first in line.


cya,
john


On Mar 15, 2007, at 9:36 AM, mo corleone wrote:

> hey SFR,
>
> recent events in the world of bay area parties have started the  
> wheels turning in my little brain. this list is full of partiers  
> old school and new, so i'm hoping to get a good variety of opinions  
> on what is acceptable in the party scene and what is not.
>
> what do you guys think of parties that get busted or otherwise end  
> prematurely? are there instances when this is forgivable, even  
> expected? or do you feel that organizers, promoters, etc. have a  
> responsibility to their attendees to make sure a party lives up to  
> all it advertised? there was a big bash this past weekend in  
> oakland with a ton of talent and mass hype, and it was meant to  
> last until who knows when... sort of a "party til you drop"  
> environment. big fun. unfortunately the party was busted by the  
> cops, and i think music ended around midnight-ish and patrons were  
> booted from the space by 2am. reactions have mostly fallen into one  
> of two categories:
>
> 1) hey, it's an underground party, sometimes they get busted. shit  
> happens in the ug scene - people try really hard to put together  
> something awesome, but given the nature of these kind of parties,  
> sometimes things go awry.
>
> 2) the event organizers owe all these party people something. they  
> paid $15 at the door for a certain kind of party experience and  
> they did not get it. if a party is going to be pumped up this much,  
> it should be properly permitted, etc.
>
> so what do you guys think? if you were at a party that was meant to  
> go until, let's say, 6am, would you be upset if it were shut down  
> at 2am instead? what about 4am? does it make a difference if there  
> was a cover charge or not? when it comes to throwing parties  
> outside of fully permitted, squeaky clean club venues, what exactly  
> do party organizers owe the people who come out to have a good time  
> and support the event?
>
> all opinions welcome...
>
> love,
> mo
>

I'm aiming at Japan myself.

I just found out that I didn't get into JET this year, though.  I was  
all emo about it for a while before I remembered that there are a  
half-dozen private language schools that were my fallback plan from  
the very beginning.  Plus, the plan was to turn JET down and go  
private anyway, were I to get accepted but placed in the middle of  
bumfuck nowhere instead of a real city.  So next on the list are ECC  
(Top of my list of the private schools.  But they operate on an odd  
schedule and don't interview applicants until the fall.) , Amity, and  
AEON...

Never say never, but Japan is extraordinarily unlikely to invade or  
be invaded anytime soon.  Plus it has the advantages over anything  
south of the border of better food, a cooler language, good music,  
much better nerd toys, some of the largest and safest cities in the  
world, and a good club and rave scene.


cya,
john

On Mar 15, 2007, at 6:26 PM, John B wrote:

>
> The promoters' response to a bust makes a big difference too:
>
> I know that some people here like to hate on them, but one of my  
> favorite crews used to be Happy Kids.  At one time, I'd been to  
> more Happy Kids' parties than those of any other promoter.  Three  
> of them were busted; but I kept coming back because of the stand-up  
> way Marty handled things.  In all three cases, he was on the phone  
> immediately trying to throw together an afterparty, and anyone who  
> wasn't quite ready to drive yet was welcome to stick around and  
> "help clean up".  In one, your ticket stub was good to get you in  
> to his next party, in another it was good for you AND a friend.   
> And in two of the three busts I was there for, about an hour after  
> the pigs had left, he turned the music back on, updated the  
> infoline to tell everyone to come back to the original venue, and  
> we partied till dawn.  Regardless of their other faults, *THAT* is  
> how a promoter who cares handles busts; and if he were to start  
> throwing parties regularly again (Though I actually hope, for his  
> sake, that he doesn't.) I'd happily be first in line.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] busted parties: forgivable?


On Thu, 15 Mar 2007, Deepfog wrote:
-&e->i'll never forget one time when i lived with marty and they brought home
-&e->this clear silicon based dildo they found on the dance floor ... it was
-&e->just so completely random and we were all laughing our asses off and
-&e->pretending to, well, do oral with it ... yea, i agree that the way marty
-&e->handled his parties was fun.  those were the days.

If you mean "fun" being defined as sending a whole party to an underground 
that Harmony was throwing after their party got busted the same night, 
sure.

Nothing like working door, and telling countless doe-eyed huggy revelers 
that we can't let anybody else in (it was "Harmony Full" which means 
putting 1000 heads in a 600 person space).  At the dance studio.  And 
they're all dressed like rainbow bright and don't have the common sense to 
leave when we can't let them in.  So it's this mob of like 250 people all 
huddled around.  At the corner of 20-something and Mission.

Happy Kids sure had energy, but I wouldn't label them one of the more 
organized or conscious collectives in the scene till later in their 
parties.  I'd venture to say that a lot of what we learned from our peers 
(like Harmony and Happy Kids) resulted in some of the "rules" that made 
Viberation kinda different (fanatical dedication to under-capacity ticket 
sales, responsible methods like mappoints and womo/hand to hand promotion, 
open budgets, etc).  All that said, HK was where I ultimately met some of 
my favorite folks in the scene.

andyw

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________
I'm coming down fast but I'm miles above you.

I just talked to a friend who recently went to study in China for a  
month, this person told me firsthand stuff I don't even want to think  
about right now, much less share.  Maybe I will someday.  For me, it  
puts our threads about parties being busted into perspective.  Feel  
lucky.  Sorry to depress you, that's not really my goal.  When you're  
dancing this weekend, please have a moment of silence for the people  
that have it a lot worse than we do and think thoughts they will see  
freedom in their lifetimes.

Have a nice weekend.  - DF

Subject: Re: [sfraves] And now, for a funny trip down memory lane...

On 3/13/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> I miss the days when everyone had a homemade web page like that.  There is something a bit too contrived about the MySpace pages that have replaced them.
>
> I often think we should rebel against the corporate design and slick layouts that have replaced these simple hand made artifacts.  Also they still work after all these years.
>
> I doubt all those fancy CSS pages and flash animations floating about these days will work in 5 years.
>

Well, I don't know about flash (I hope it finds its way off the web)
but the whole point of writing (x)html pages with css is to make the
content legible with our without the fancy styling.

Building web pages with that in mind gives you a better chance of your
page rendering in any future browsers, as well as todays stripped down
cell phone browsers and screen readers.

But it's fukwork friday so enough of that talk ;) and yeah I
appreciate a good throwback in web design too!

<3
j.ordan

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR More Re: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductees

--0-1852473520-1174086204=:8905
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



Will Penna <w.penna@comcast.net> wrote:  Fair enough, it is based on Good Times by Chic, but the melody was 
slightly changed and the music was played entirely live by sessions 
musicians at the insistence of Sylvia Robinson. So, as you say, up 
for debate. There is an even earlier song - Christmas Rappin' by 
Kurtis Blow that was also played using live instruments and came out 
well before Blondie's Rapture. Again, I agreed with most of your 
points, just took umbrage with the idea that the term "rap"originated 
with Blondie.

Re:
Huh- I had thought that the music in Rapper's Delight was just a 
couple sections of Good Times.

But I see now this appears to be up for debate, with some of the 
sounds being claimed to have been replayed live by their own band or 
something.

Ah well- not really core to the point I was trying to make, and I 
shouldn't have included it in the first place :)

Re:
Hi there,
Well, I absolutely agreed with the following, including Led Zep 
being one of the greatest rock and roll groups of all time.
That is, until the assertation that the word "Rap" comes from 
Blondie. First of all, I disagree that a true rapper is one that raps 
over their own music vs. someone else's, but even if we accept this 
as a premise, your argument just does not pass muster. Rapper's 
Delight was released in 1979, Rapture was released in 1980 and 
Blondie was certainly not the first person to talk over their own 
music. To begin with, Rapper's Delight is done with all live 
musicians and doesn't have a single sample on it.
To go back further, Hip Hop is widely recognized as having 
been created by Kool Herc, who was heavily influenced by the Jamaican 
soundsystems of his youth, James Brown, and most importantly the Last 
Poets. The Last Poets most definitely rapped over their own music. 
You could even argue that songs like "Love is Strange" by Mickey & 
Sylvia were predecessors of Rap Music. Coincidentally, Sylvia 
Robinson was also the owner of Sugarhill Records, the label that put 
out Rapper's Delight.
Trying to say that we get the term "rap" from Blondie is just 
plain wrong and really takes away from the rest of your argument. 
It's also insulting to the richness of black culture going back to 
rapping and proto-rapping in Blues, Jazz, and even earlier black music.

Re:
I didn't respond to you for a reason- but come on man-

Oh ok- so Rock and Roll is just a concept- and thus- any random
Jungle track, because of its use of the R&B amen break, as well as
its attitude, is thus Rock?
Are you listening to yourself?

Take step a back- art involves innovation.
Art involves taking the old and creating the new.
Art by its very nature is derivative.
Even the earliest cave painters painted only what they had already
seen roaming the savannah.

Led Zeppelin, my #1 group anywhere, was entirely influenced by the
R&B at the time-
Does that make them any less worthy in my mind?
Hell no- I mean- Pink Floyd is #2, but... Led Zeppelin released what-
6 albums?
And there are only 3-4 songs on *all* of them that I dislike?
IMO they were surely better than anyone they got any inspiration from.

The key to enjoying art is to take it for what it is, not what
inspired it.

Oh and just for the record- do you know where the term "rap" comes from?
Blondie - Rapture.
Yes- *gasp* a blonde white girl was actually the first true rapper.
All other rappers before her had simply talked over other people's
songs.
She met Fab 5 Freddie, then was the first to talk over her *own*
music- and things took off from there.

Subject: [sfraves] FW: [Dancecult-l] Fwd: MTV-U Fulbright Fellowships for Junior U.S. Scholars

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C76810.D4B314E0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="----=_NextPart_001_0002_01C76810.D4B314E0"


------=_NextPart_001_0002_01C76810.D4B314E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 

 

 

Subject: [Dancecult-l] Fwd: MTV-U Fulbright Fellowships for Junior U.S.
Scholars

 

 

 

 

Dear Colleagues,

 

The State Department in partnership with MTV-U is offering Fulbright
fellowships for junior scholars who are US citizens and who are working in
the area of 'culture and music.' In particular the program seeks to fund
projects that use the "power of music as a global force for mutual
understanding." The fellowship has only just been announced and has a very
short deadline: applications are due March 29. I've pasted the call below
and I've attached it as well.

 

Best,

 

Carol 

 

FULBRIGHT-MTVU FELLOWSHIPS

Deadline for applications: March 29, 2007

 

About the Program

Fulbright-mtvU Fellowships, administered by the Institute of International
Education, are for U.S. students to conduct research abroad for one academic
year on study projects of their own design around an aspect of international
musical culture.  For its pilot year (2007-2008), up to 4 Fellowships will
be awarded to outstanding U.S. students nationwide.  In addition to
proposing unique projects on "the power of music" as a global force for
mutual understanding, applicants must submit an outreach plan describing how
they intend to share their activities with their peers during their
Fulbright year.

 

Eligibility

Applicants must be U.S. citizens at the time of application.  Applicants
must have completed a bachelor's degree by the beginning date of the award;
in the performing arts, four years of professional experience may substitute
for the degree.  Preference will be given to recent college/university
graduates.  Applicants must apply to conduct their project in a country
where there is an active U.S. Fulbright Student Program, as listed on
us.fulbrightonline.org.  Applicants must meet all potential host country
requirements, including those related to language and program start dates.
Applications are encouraged for all world regions.

 

Eligible Fields of Study:

Applicants should submit proposals around an aspect of international
contemporary or popular music as a cultural force for expression.
Preference will be given to creative projects that are conveyed in a dynamic
fashion and that are accompanied by a feasible action plan to inform peer
groups via mtvU's various media platforms (broadcast, online and print)
regarding the Fellow's activities in the host country throughout the term of
the grant.  Applicants are encouraged to consider a range of documentary
modes (e.g., blogs, vlogs, photo diaries, news segments) to share their
experiences and findings. Applicants are also encouraged to consider all
aspects of "the power of music" in developing their project proposals.
Along with the study of music in a specific cultural context or
ethnomusicology, proposals will be considered in other music-related fields
including, for example, music and social activism; music in learning; music
and the community, and musical performance.

 

Award Benefits:

The fellowship will provide the following benefits:

Round-trip transportation to the host country

Maintenance for the academic year, based on living costs in the host country

Book and research allowances (Fellows whose projects require extensive
research funding, materials, or equipment must obtain funding from other
sources for such purposes.)

Supplemental health and accident insurance coverage

Foreign language or cultural orientation courses, where appropriate

Media resources (e.g., camera and Internet uplink for students to send
dispatches to mtvU)

 

Additional Information/Application Materials
In addition to the activities proposed for the Fellowship, Fellows may be
asked to participate in special programs, conferences, and/or promotional
activities developed or suggested by the U.S. Department of State, mtvU, the
Institute of International Education, and/or Fulbright Commissions.

 

The deadline for applications is March 29, 2007.

 

For additional information and application materials, please visit
us.fulbrightonline.org.

 

###

The Fulbright Program is the world-renowned, flagship international
educational program supported by the people of the United States and people
in partner countries around the world and sponsored by the U.S. Department
of State.  The Fulbright Program has provided more than 279,000 participants
with the opportunity to study, teach and conduct research, to exchange ideas
and to contribute to finding solutions to shared international concerns. 

 

mtvU is an on-air, online, wireless and on campus network created by and for
the college audience.  Broadcasting via satellite 24 hours a day, 7 days a
week, to over seven million students on more than 740 campuses, mtvU is the
largest and most comprehensive multi-platform channel for college students.

  _____  

Apollo

apollo@speakeasy.org

 

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                 
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

 

"There is suffering in life, and there are defeats. No one can avoid them.
But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles for your dreams
than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're fighting for."  -Paulo
Coelho  

 

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap of
empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another person. ln
those transparent moments we know other people's joys and sorrows, and we
care about their concerns as if they were our own."  -Fritz Williams 

 

"I hate to advocate drugs, alcohol, violence or insanity to anyone, but it
worked for me." -Hunter S. Thompson

<div class=3DSection1>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'color:#1F497D'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'color:#1F497D'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<div>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><span =
style=3D'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";
color:#1F497D'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

</div>

<div>

<div style=3D'border:none;border-top:solid #B5C4DF 1.0pt;padding:3.0pt =
0in 0in 0in'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><b><span =
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Tahoma","sans-serif"'>Subject:</sp=
an></b><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Tahoma","sans-serif"'> =
[Dancecult-l] Fwd:
MTV-U Fulbright Fellowships for Junior U.S. =
Scholars<o:p></o:p></span></p>

</div>

</div>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Dear Colleagues,<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>The State Department in partnership with MTV-U is =
offering
Fulbright fellowships for junior scholars who are US citizens and who =
are
working in the area of 'culture and music.' In particular the program =
seeks to
fund projects that use the &quot;power of music as a global force for =
mutual
understanding.&quot; The fellowship has only just been announced and has =
a very
short deadline: applications are due March 29. I've pasted the call =
below and
I've attached it as well.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Best,<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Carol<span =
style=3D'font-size:13.5pt'>&nbsp;</span><o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><b>FULBRIGHT-MTVU FELLOWSHIPS</b><o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Deadline for applications: March 29, =
2007<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>About the Program<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Fulbright-mtvU Fellowships, administered by the =
Institute of
International Education, are for U.S. students to conduct research =
abroad for
one academic year on study projects of their own design around an aspect =
of
international musical culture.&nbsp; For its pilot year (2007-2008), up =
to 4
Fellowships will be awarded to outstanding U.S. students =
nationwide.&nbsp; In
addition to proposing unique projects on &#8220;the power of =
music&#8221; as a
global force for mutual understanding, applicants must submit an =
outreach plan
describing how they intend to share their activities with their peers =
during
their Fulbright year.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Eligibility<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Applicants must be U.S. citizens at the time of
application.&nbsp; Applicants must have completed a bachelor&#8217;s =
degree by
the beginning date of the award; in the performing arts, four years of
professional experience may substitute for the degree. &nbsp;Preference =
will be
given to recent college/university graduates.&nbsp; Applicants must =
apply to
conduct their project in a country where there is an active U.S. =
Fulbright
Student Program, as listed on us.fulbrightonline.org.&nbsp; Applicants =
must
meet all potential host country requirements, including those related to
language and program start dates.&nbsp; Applications are encouraged for =
all
world regions.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Eligible Fields of Study:<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Applicants should submit proposals around an aspect =
of
international contemporary or popular music as a cultural force for
expression.&nbsp; Preference will be given to creative projects that are
conveyed in a dynamic fashion and that are accompanied by a feasible =
action
plan to inform peer groups via mtvU&#8217;s various media platforms =
(broadcast,
online and print) regarding the Fellow&#8217;s activities in the host =
country throughout
the term of the grant. &nbsp;Applicants are encouraged to consider a =
range of
documentary modes (e.g., blogs, vlogs, photo diaries, news segments) to =
share
their experiences and findings. Applicants are also encouraged to =
consider all
aspects of &#8220;the power of music&#8221; in developing their project
proposals.&nbsp; Along with the study of music in a specific cultural =
context
or ethnomusicology, proposals will be considered in other music-related =
fields
including, for example, music and social activism; music in learning; =
music and
the community, and musical performance.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Award Benefits:<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>The fellowship will provide the following =
benefits:<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Round-trip transportation to the host =
country<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Maintenance for the academic year, based on living =
costs in
the host country<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Book and research allowances (Fellows whose =
projects require
extensive research funding, materials, or equipment must obtain funding =
from
other sources for such purposes.)<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Supplemental health and accident insurance =
coverage<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Foreign language or cultural orientation courses, =
where
appropriate<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Media resources (e.g., camera and Internet uplink =
for
students to send dispatches to mtvU)<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>Additional Information/Application Materials<br>
In addition to the activities proposed for the Fellowship, Fellows may =
be asked
to participate in special programs, conferences, and/or promotional =
activities
developed or suggested by the U.S. Department of State, mtvU, the =
Institute of
International Education, and/or Fulbright Commissions.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>The deadline for applications is March 29, =
2007.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>For additional information and application =
materials, please
visit us.fulbrightonline.org.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>###<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>The Fulbright Program is the world-renowned, =
flagship
international educational program supported by the people of the United =
States
and people in partner countries around the world and sponsored by the =
U.S.
Department of State.&nbsp; The Fulbright Program has provided more than =
279,000
participants with the opportunity to study, teach and conduct research, =
to
exchange ideas and to contribute to finding solutions to shared =
international
concerns.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<p class=3DMsoNormal>mtvU is an on-air, online, wireless and on campus =
network
created by and for the college audience.&nbsp; Broadcasting via =
satellite 24
hours a day, 7 days a week, to over seven million students on more than =
740
campuses, mtvU is the largest and most comprehensive multi-platform =
channel for
college students.<o:p></o:p></p>

</blockquote>

<blockquote style=3D'margin-top:5.0pt;margin-bottom:5.0pt'>

<div class=3DMsoNormal align=3Dcenter style=3D'text-align:center'>

<hr size=3D1 width=3D"100%" align=3Dcenter>

</div>

</blockquote>

</blockquote>

About the attachment 'WinZip Compressed Attachment.zip'
-------------------------------------------------------

The attachments to this e-mail have been automatically compressed
with WinZip(R) Companion for Outlook(R) and can be viewed with
WinZip 9.0 or later.

WinZip can be used to extract the contents of this and other Zip
files that you download from the Internet or receive as e-mail
attachments. In addition to basic zipping and unzipping, features
of WinZip include tight integration with Windows Explorer, support
for most Internet archive formats, advanced AES encryption, and much
more. Please visit the WinZip web site at www.winzip.com/wzt.htm for
more information about WinZip and to download a free evaluation
version.

WinZip Companion for Outlook brings the power of WinZip to the
Microsoft(R) Outlook environment by automatically zipping
attachments to your e-mail messages, saving transmission time and
disk space for both the sender and the recipient.  Please visit the
WinZip web site at www.winzip.com/uct.htm for more information about
WinZip Companion for Outlook and to download a free evaluation version.

Subject: [sfraves] More Re: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductees

James Brown certainly uses the word rap frequently, although he uses  
it in the sense of "to talk informally." If I'm not incorrect he says  
"rap to you" not "rap for you." As far as I can remember he uses it  
to mean his little spoken word asides that he makes during his songs.  
These usually don't rhyme. This usage of the word rap is well  
documented in black slang going back to the thirties with the  
earliest recorded usage being 1929. The American Heritage Dictionary  
states that no less than Winston Churchill uses the term in 1933.
WC - the first B-Boy. ;)


> For the record the term rap was coined by James Brown, in several  
> of his songs he says "Can I rap for ya", one song imperticular was  
> "talking loud and saying nothing", isn't ironic, don't ya think.



Re:  Fair enough, it is based on Good Times by Chic, but the melody was
slightly changed and the music was played entirely live by sessions
musicians at the insistence of Sylvia Robinson. So, as you say, up
for debate. There is an even earlier song - Christmas Rappin' by
Kurtis Blow that was also played using live instruments and came out
well before Blondie's Rapture. Again, I agreed with most of your
points, just took umbrage with the idea that the term "rap"originated
with Blondie.

Re:
Huh- I had thought that the music in Rapper's Delight was just a
couple sections of Good Times.

But I see now this appears to be up for debate, with some of the
sounds being claimed to have been replayed live by their own band or
something.

Ah well- not really core to the point I was trying to make, and I
shouldn't have included it in the first place :)

Re:
Hi there,
Well, I absolutely agreed with the following, including Led Zep
being one of the greatest rock and roll groups of all time.
That is, until the assertation that the word "Rap" comes from
Blondie. First of all, I disagree that a true rapper is one that raps
over their own music vs. someone else's, but even if we accept this
as a premise, your argument just does not pass muster. Rapper's
Delight was released in 1979, Rapture was released in 1980 and
Blondie was certainly not the first person to talk over their own
music. To begin with, Rapper's Delight is done with all live
musicians and doesn't have a single sample on it.
To go back further, Hip Hop is widely recognized as having
been created by Kool Herc, who was heavily influenced by the Jamaican
soundsystems of his youth, James Brown, and most importantly the Last
Poets. The Last Poets most definitely rapped over their own music.
You could even argue that songs like "Love is Strange" by Mickey &
Sylvia were predecessors of Rap Music. Coincidentally, Sylvia
Robinson was also the owner of Sugarhill Records, the label that put
out Rapper's Delight.
Trying to say that we get the term "rap" from Blondie is just
plain wrong and really takes away from the rest of your argument.
It's also insulting to the richness of black culture going back to
rapping and proto-rapping in Blues, Jazz, and even earlier black music.

Re:
I didn't respond to you for a reason- but come on man-

Oh ok- so Rock and Roll is just a concept- and thus- any random
Jungle track, because of its use of the R&B amen break, as well as
its attitude, is thus Rock?
Are you listening to yourself?

Take step a back- art involves innovation.
Art involves taking the old and creating the new.
Art by its very nature is derivative.
Even the earliest cave painters painted only what they had already
seen roaming the savannah.

Led Zeppelin, my #1 group anywhere, was entirely influenced by the
R&B at the time-
Does that make them any less worthy in my mind?
Hell no- I mean- Pink Floyd is #2, but... Led Zeppelin released what-
6 albums?
And there are only 3-4 songs on *all* of them that I dislike?
IMO they were surely better than anyone they got any inspiration from.

The key to enjoying art is to take it for what it is, not what
inspired it.

Oh and just for the record- do you know where the term "rap" comes from?
Blondie - Rapture.
Yes- *gasp* a blonde white girl was actually the first true rapper.
All other rappers before her had simply talked over other people's
songs.
She met Fab 5 Freddie, then was the first to talk over her *own*
music- and things took off from there.

You know, if Hitler says it's raining outside, guess what?  It's
raining!  I mean, I don't like him, I don't like the Ku Klux Klan, I
don't like any of these racist organizations, but if they make a
legitamite statement, it's still a true statement.  You know, it's
just like when you're a child and your parents tell you something and
you want verification on everything, well you know what?  They were
right the first time!  You don't have to look for verification.  I
don't care who you are, if you've got a mind, if you've got eyes, if
you're an American, you can see what's going on in this country.  Your
race matters not.

- Terry Anderson

them. But it's better to lose some of the battles in the struggles  
for your dreams than to be defeated without ever knowing what you're  
fighting for."  -Paulo Coelho

"Suffering and joy teach us, if we allow them, how to make the leap  
of empathy, which transports us into the soul and heart of another  
person. ln those transparent moments we know other people's joys and  
sorrows, and we care about their concerns as if they were our own."  - 
Fritz Williams

Subject: [sfraves] Pet Food Scandal

--=====================_343948687==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I presume that I was not alone in making the sad discovery
that the pet food recommended by our vet was, potentially,
capable of killing our much loved pet.

WTF

Did anyone have ANY idea that SO MANY supposedly
DIFFERENT pet foods both BRANDS and VARIETIES
were ALL MANUFACTURED BY THE SAME COMPANY !!!!!
And that they were ALL subject to recall - this has to make you
wonder about how "SPECIAL" the formulations we PAY EXTRA for
really are - it also has to make you wonder about the
PREMIUM paid for particular NAME BRANDS - "Science Diet" my . . . . .

Along with the revelation that  80% of the pet food
fed to our trusting pals came from only ONE supply stream -
came the realization that the potential poisoning was part of the manufacturing
process for 5 MONTHS before being detected.
Let me guess - whatever agency or procedure was responsible
for the monitoring of that particular concern were eliminated
or greatly reduced by recent "budget cuts" or forgotten legislation.

I don't know about you, but it has me REALLY QUESTIONING
what i really know and understand about my own food chain
and how much I can really trust those entrusted with MY SAFETY.


--=====================_343948687==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Pet Food Scandal

------=_Part_180557_12251523.1174417153622
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Lets put this into perspective:

"I've read that there are about 60 million cats and 75 million
dogs<http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=pets_ownership>in
the
U.S. Do you know how many cats and dogs have apparently died from bad food?
Ten. Wait. About 10. Maybe 8 or 11 or who knows. Does anyone really know?
Anyway, if my math is correct, that would be about 0.000007 percent of the
total cat and dog population. I've read several figures, but the American
Humane Association says that 9.6 million cats and dogs are killed in
shelters every year. So you tell me where the mysterious uproar should
direct its attention - 10 or 10 million?" -Blair
Lovern<http://www.pegasusnews.com/staff/blair-lovern/>

http://www.pegasusnews.com/news/2007/mar/19/tainted-pet-food-stories-are-getting-crazy/

But I do share your sentiment about human food protection. 1 human dead from
bad food is too many.

Have a great day!

> On 3/20/07, Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote:
>> 
>> I presume that I was not alone in making the sad discovery
>> that the pet food recommended by our vet was, potentially,
>> capable of killing our much loved pet.
>> 
>> WTF
>> 
>> Did anyone have ANY idea that SO MANY supposedly
>> DIFFERENT pet foods both BRANDS and VARIETIES
>> were ALL MANUFACTURED BY THE SAME COMPANY !!!!!
>> And that they were ALL subject to recall - this has to make you
>> wonder about how "SPECIAL" the formulations we PAY EXTRA for
>> really are - it also has to make you wonder about the
>> PREMIUM paid for particular NAME BRANDS - "Science Diet" my . . . . .
>> 
>> Along with the revelation that  80% of the pet food
>> fed to our trusting pals came from only ONE supply stream -
>> came the realization that the potential poisoning was part of the
>> manufacturing
>> process for 5 MONTHS before being detected.
>> Let me guess - whatever agency or procedure was responsible
>> for the monitoring of that particular concern were eliminated
>> or greatly reduced by recent "budget cuts" or forgotten legislation.
>> 
>> I don't know about you, but it has me REALLY QUESTIONING
>> what i really know and understand about my own food chain
>> and how much I can really trust those entrusted with MY SAFETY.
>> 
>>

Subject: [sfraves] Good News for Today: Its a less violent world...

Partially inspired by "Pet Food Scandal"

"In sixteenth-century Paris, a popular form
of entertainment was cat-burning, in which a cat was hoisted in a sling
on a stage and slowly lowered into a fire. According to historian
Norman Davies, "[T]he spectators, including kings and queens, shrieked
with laughter as the animals, howling with pain, were singed, roasted,
and finally carbonized." Today, such sadism would be unthinkable in
most of the world. This change in sensibilities is just one example of
perhaps the most important and most underappreciated trend in the human
saga: Violence has been in decline over long stretches of history, and
today we are probably living in the most peaceful moment of our
species' time on earth."
...


http://www.tnr.com/doc.mhtml?i=20070319&s=pinker031907

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: lorazepam...

I took that during my dad's bought with cancer...benzodiazepine, It helped 
my family a lot with getting sleep and feeling mellow.  I had no idea it was 
a muscle relaxer.
this is what Wiki says...
"Lorazepam (first marketed under the brand names Ativan® and Temesta®) is a 
benzodiazepine type drug. As a benzodiazepine, lorazepam possesses all five 
principal benzodiazepine actions (sedative/hypnotic, muscle relaxant, 
anxiolytic, amnestic and anticonvulsant), but to different extents. 
Lorazepam also has found use as an adjunct anti-nausea drug. Lorazepam is a 
potent drug and its unique pharmacological properties underlie both its 
drawbacks and its advantages."

Another thing that I have taken is GABA, works well with muscle stuffs for 
me.  GHB actually affects GABA in your system, hence the HGH production in 
your body...kinda crazy...dont take it before bed, makes you do weird shit 
in your sleep!!!
http://www.truthbeknown.com/gaba.html
or you can chew on some white willow bark :)
I hope you feel better!
Danny

yubetcha!" -Swedish Chef

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Pet Food Scandal


http://www.thehonestkitchen.com/index.shtml

This is who I get my pet food from.  I saw a noticeable difference with the 
doggie when we adpoted her and switched her over.  Previously she was on 
Pedagee (shite!).

Elevated stable energy.  Normal sleep patterns.  BM's became regular and 
rock solid (carpet accidents arn't anything to trip on).  She trimmed down 
to a perfect weight for her size.  Her coat became soft and healthy.  No 
shedding or other annoyances.  She's VERY happy now.

This stuff is great because you can mix up a little or a lot.  You can make 
it soupy or super thick.  I've even mixed in some dry food to give her 
something more to crunch on.  It'll also keep for a very long time, and in 
a pinch, it's 100% human grade so you can eat it too.  ;)

>> >>> wonder about how "SPECIAL" the formulations we PAY EXTRA for
>> >>> really are - it also has to make you wonder about the
>> >>> PREMIUM paid for particular NAME BRANDS - "Science Diet" my . . . . .
>> >>>
>> >>> Along with the revelation that  80% of the pet food
>> >>> fed to our trusting pals came from only ONE supply stream -
>> >>> came the realization that the potential poisoning was part of the
>> >>> manufacturing
>> >>> process for 5 MONTHS before being detected.
>> >>> Let me guess - whatever agency or procedure was responsible
>> >>> for the monitoring of that particular concern were eliminated
>> >>> or greatly reduced by recent "budget cuts" or forgotten legislation.
>> >>>
>> >>> I don't know about you, but it has me REALLY QUESTIONING
>> >>> what i really know and understand about my own food chain
>> >>> and how much I can really trust those entrusted with MY SAFETY.
>> >>>
>> >>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: lorazepam...

My wife has had cancer... twice.

She was prescribed lorazapam, but it turned out that it was nothing that 
a little pot brownie couldn't fix -- just way more expensive. 
Interestingly enough, one of the other drugs she was also prescribed was 
Thorazine which is... get this... a hiccup suppressant. After I did some 
research it turns out that Thorazine is what they also give to people 
when they're having a bad LSD trip. What the connection is between 
hiccups and LSD I don't think I will never know.

-Tim

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Yeah I read the Wiki too and thought it was weird enough that I called the Dr. to make sure I had the right drug.  
>
> Interestingly I've found the effects to be primarily a sort of bizarrely irritating yet energetic boredom.  I'm not sure its helped my back more than the Aleve I took at the same time however.
>
> It is just impossible to get excited anything.  The muscle relaxing part seems to be mostly a lethargy;  I'm not relaxed as much as lazy.
>
> One website I read did describe "paradoxical reactions" resulting from reduced inhibitions which included restlessness and irritability as well other rather extreme symptoms like "inappropriate behavior" which would be somewhat normal for me actually. 
>
> Whatever it is, it is weird and sort of unpleasant.  I find myself to be in a somewhat disturbing state and I am not sure I want to take another one.  Alternatively,maybe I didn't take enough.  The bottle says up to 3 a day "as needed" but I took one and the pills are only 1 mg.  I'll have to see how bad the back is when this and the Aleve wear off.
>
> Also, I'm very sorry to hear about your Dad Danny.  I don't think I knew about that.
>
> Peace,

> "Lorazepam (first marketed under the brand names Ativan® and Temesta®) is a 
> benzodiazepine type drug. As a benzodiazepine, lorazepam possesses all five 
> principal benzodiazepine actions (sedative/hypnotic, muscle relaxant, 
> anxiolytic, amnestic and anticonvulsant), but to different extents. 
> Lorazepam also has found use as an adjunct anti-nausea drug. Lorazepam is a 
> potent drug and its unique pharmacological properties underlie both its 
> drawbacks and its advantages."
>

Well, this one's been sitting at the top of my quote queue for far too =20
long, well, what I mean by that is it's the oldest one.  Kind of held =20
off on it for a while after talking about CPS which is part of this =20
woman's story.  Is what she says true or not?  I'm not sure.  My =20
intuition wants to say yes.  Is Dyncor and Halliburton running huge =20
slave prostitution rings?  Unfortunately, I probably shouldn't want to =20
know but my brain is built where I'd rather.  Then I'd rather take =20
those thoughts and find some good (music) track to get lost in, it =20
always works and makes everything seem so insignificant in a way and =20
that good will prevail over evil.  All we have to do is will it to =20
happen.

In 1978, it was determined I had experienced sufficient trauma to
carry out my first trial run operation.  An enormous quantity of
cocaine had been flown in ... and I was to deliver it into the
neighboring state of Arkansas.  By that time, Bill Clinton's drug
operation was in full swing.  He was governor of Arkansas, and I
delivered it to a remote airport in Wachata Forest, which I've since
identified as Minna Airport.  I also delivered a little packet of
information and a small quantity of cocaine, a personal stash from J.
Bennett Johnson to Bill Clinton.  I delivered it to Bill Clinton, and
he cut out two lines of the coke, and he *did* inhale.  That certainly
wasn't the only time I saw Bill Clinton doing cocaine.

- Cathy O'Brien

Not to ruin the positive news, but unfortunately these types of acts still
occur in countries and cultures that have not gone through reformation and
enlightenment. Groups of people that still circumcise women, stone them for
getting raped, and do not allow them education. Another practice of killing
BORN babies if they are girls also comes to mind and holding dog fights,
cock fights, and animal torture for entertainment. So the human race still
has a long way to go. But, hey, we are doing WAY better then 100 years ago.

On 3/20/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> Partially inspired by "Pet Food Scandal"
>
> "In sixteenth-century Paris, a popular form
> of entertainment was cat-burning, in which a cat was hoisted in a sling
> on a stage and slowly lowered into a fire. According to historian
> Norman Davies, "[T]he spectators, including kings and queens, shrieked
> with laughter as the animals, howling with pain, were singed, roasted,
> and finally carbonized." Today, such sadism would be unthinkable in
> most of the world. This change in sensibilities is just one example of
> perhaps the most important and most underappreciated trend in the human
> saga: Violence has been in decline over long stretches of history, and
> today we are probably living in the most peaceful moment of our
> species' time on earth."
> ...
>
>
> http://www.tnr.com/doc.mhtml?i=20070319&s=pinker031907

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
A Benefit for the How Weird Street Faire
"Beats for Peace"
Friday March 23, 2007
10pm to 5am
1015 Folsom St., San Fancisco
$20-30 sliding scale, $10 before 11pm
Limited $15 pre-sales (available at www.wantickets.com)
21 + with ID

You are invited to a benefit for two worthy causes as San Francisco's
largest club will be transformed into a gathering of communities in the
name of peace. 100% of the proceeds will go to the production of the 8th
annual How Weird Street Faire and to the Baby Hazel Fund. The How Weird
Street Faire is an experiment in creating peace, uniting the diverse art
and music communities of the Bay Area.

We've assembled an awesome collection of five rooms of music and art
representing some of the best the world has to offer. The main room will
be filled with psy-trance, including the record release of Penta's new
album "Horn Please". The decor and the sound will be top notch! And we're
giving away stickers to everyone who attends the benefit.

For more information, visit - http://www.HowWeird.org

For presale tickets go to - http://www.wantickets.com/?req=event&e_id=25092
(There are a limited number of $15 presale tickets available!)

The 8th annual How Weird Street Faire will take place
on Sunday May 6, 2007! This will be the last faire on
Howard Street.


BENEFIT LINE-UP for March 23, 2007:

In the Main Room - A Trance Mix (by CCC + Tantra)

Penta (AuraQuake Music, Russia/SF) - Presenting his new album "Horn Please"!
KJ (CCC/Tantra)
Liam Shy (Tantra)
Kode IV (Ceiba)
Cyril (Vaporvent)
Cybert (CCC)


In the Front Room - Beats for Life (by Raindance)

Liberation Movement (featuring Resurrector of
Heavyweight Dub Champion, Jillian Ann + special
guests)
Subal (Raindance/13 Moon Tribe)
Kraddy (Glitch Mob)
Boreta (Glitch Mob/Raindance)

Little John (Raindance/13 Moon Tribe)
Mozaic (Raindance/Nexus)


In the Bassment - A House & Breaks Mix (by Sunset +
Raindance)

Jeno (Wicked)
Galen (Pacific Sound/Sunset)
Solar (Pacific Sound/Sunset)
Mochi (Waffle Beats)
Hypnotech (Addictech)
Friction (Yellow #5)


In the Back Upstairs - A Downtempo Mix (by Dub
Beautiful + False Profit)

Sariah Storm (Terpsichore Group)
pureEvil (Space Cowboys/Glitch Mob)
maer (Dub Beautiful/Psyphy Machine)

obi-J (False Profit)
funktion (ill)


In the Front Upstairs - An Eclectic Mix (by Lowpro
Lounge + Symbiosis)

Munk)

--0-1341268853-1174503546=:72055
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ascii

Absolutely.  Suffering is myriad and pervasive and perhaps will always be.  On the other hand, we can take action to reduce and maybe even eliminate at least some suffering.  See my friend Robert Daoust's blog  http://aboutsuffering.blogspot.com/ for example.

My question is, despite the continuing suffering in the world, is there reason to be optimistic or will we always spend our lives in the shadow of the lengthy list of "things to be afraid of" which these days with our modern technology we constantly hear about from the media and each other.  

Just this week on the Fox show 24, terrorists attempt to nuke San Francisco.  And the recent local news told me about a fatal shooting and a deadly house fire.  Someone set me an email about how vitamins might really be bad for you.  

The woman that caused my car accident yesterday was so afraid she'd be blamed for a situation which she had obviously caused herself that she was out of control scraming and sobbing and she acted in the most aggressive and bizarre manner.  She was insane with fear.

Yes, I could focus on those fears or I could go sit outside in my garden.

Peace,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: SlumberMachine <sosteen@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Good News for Today: Its a less violent world...

Not to ruin the positive news, but unfortunately these types of acts still occur in countries and cultures that have not gone through reformation and enlightenment. Groups of people that still circumcise women, stone them for getting raped, and do not allow them education. Another practice of killing BORN babies if they are girls also comes to mind and holding dog fights, cock fights, and animal torture for entertainment. So the human race still has a long way to go. But, hey, we are doing WAY better then 100 years ago.

 

On 3/20/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

Partially inspired by "Pet Food Scandal"

"In sixteenth-century Paris, a popular form

of entertainment was cat-burning, in which a cat was hoisted in a sling
on a stage and slowly lowered into a fire. According to historian
Norman Davies, "[T]he spectators, including kings and queens, shrieked

with laughter as the animals, howling with pain, were singed, roasted,
and finally carbonized." Today, such sadism would be unthinkable in
most of the world. This change in sensibilities is just one example of

perhaps the most important and most underappreciated trend in the human
saga: Violence has been in decline over long stretches of history, and
today we are probably living in the most peaceful moment of our
species' time on earth."

...


http://www.tnr.com/doc.mhtml?i=20070319&s=pinker031907

the US.

> In 1978, it was determined I had experienced sufficient trauma to
> carry out my first trial run operation. An enormous quantity of
> cocaine had been flown in ... and I was to deliver it into the
> neighboring state of Arkansas. By that time, Bill Clinton's drug
> operation was in full swing. He was governor of Arkansas, and I
> delivered it to a remote airport in Wachata Forest, which I've since
> identified as Minna Airport. I also delivered a little packet of
> information and a small quantity of cocaine, a personal stash from J.
> Bennett Johnson to Bill Clinton. I delivered it to Bill Clinton, and
> he cut out two lines of the coke, and he *did* inhale. That certainly
> wasn't the only time I saw Bill Clinton doing cocaine.

At 08:04 PM 3/20/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>Partially inspired by "Pet Food Scandal"
>
>"In sixteenth-century Paris, a popular form
>of entertainment was cat-burning, in which a cat was hoisted in a sling
>on a stage and slowly lowered into a fire. According to historian
>Norman Davies, "[T]he spectators, including kings and queens, shrieked
>with laughter as the animals, howling with pain, were singed, roasted,
>and finally carbonized." Today, such sadism would be unthinkable in
>most of the world. This change in sensibilities is just one example of
>perhaps the most important and most underappreciated trend in the human
>saga: Violence has been in decline over long stretches of history, and
>today we are probably living in the most peaceful moment of our
>species' time on earth."
>...
>
>
>http://www.tnr.com/doc.mhtml?i=20070319&s=pinker031907

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

Minor correction via WikiQUote:

"Those who would give up Essential Liberty to purchase
a little Temporary Safety, deserve neither Liberty nor
Safety."

This statement was used as a motto on the title page
of An Historical Review of the Constitution and
Government of Pennsylvania. (1759) which was
attributed to Franklin in the edition of 1812, but in
a letter of September 27, 1760 to David Hume, he
states that he published this book and denies that he
wrote it, other than a few remarks that were credited
to the Pennsylvania Assembly, in which he served. The
phrase itself was first used in a letter from that
Assembly dated November 11, 1755 to the Governor of
Pennsylvania. An article on the origins of this
statement here includes a scan that indicates the
original typography of the 1759 document, which uses
an archaic form of "s": "Tho&#383;e who would give up
Essential Liberty to purcha&#383;e a little Temporary
Safety, deserve neither Liberty nor Safety."
Researchers now believe that a fellow diplomat by the
name of Richard Jackson is the primary author of the
book. With the information thus far available the
issue of authorship of the statement is not yet
definitely resolved, but the evidence indicates it was
very likely Franklin, who in the Poor Richard's
Almanack of 1738 is known to have written a similar
proverb: "Sell not virtue to purchase wealth, nor
Liberty to purchase power."
          
Many paraphrased variants derived from this saying
have arisen and have usually been incorrectly
attributed to Franklin:

"They that can give up essential liberty to purchase a
little temporary safety, deserve neither liberty nor
safety."
                  
"They that can give up essential liberty to obtain a
little temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor
safety."
                  
"Those Who Sacrifice Liberty For Security Deserve
Neither"
                  
"He who would trade liberty for some temporary
security, deserves neither liberty nor security"
                  
"He who sacrifices freedom for security deserves
neither"
                  
"People willing to trade their freedom for temporary
security deserve neither and will lose both."
                  
"If we restrict liberty to attain security we will
lose them both."
                  
"Any society that would give up a little liberty to
gain a little security will deserve neither and lose
both."
                  
"He who gives up freedom for safety deserves neither"

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Man, I was a huge Depeche Mode fan back in the late 80's. But now I can't
seem to get into their songs anymore. Maybe I just listened them out, but
the only album I still like is Violator. Someone really needs to do some
sort of remix using the arpeggio in "Waiting for the night". It would have
a "Boards of Canada" feel to it that could make a great chill out track.

Although I was a huge DM fan, New Order took the cake. I was obsessed with
New Order and still am although less. Funny how most of their songs were
about substances and I never even touched that stuff until much later on in
my life. But then again, music for me has never been about the lyrics, its
all about melody and chord progressions that create feelings. Music does
that. Certain progressions trigger strong feelings from euphoria (New Order
- Ceremony) to nausea (most 80's pop songs).

Not to be pedantic, but music is ephemeral and most meaningful. That is why
I'm here, in more ways then one.

Steve

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Pet Food Scandal

As in:

You build a little sealed enclosure filled with shallow drainable  
trays and a bug-zapper grate over a narrow slit..
You have a pipe going in to the top with a sealable opening.
Catch some flies and put them inside.
Every time you or your dog takes a shit, smush it up and throw it in  
to the pipe along with some water, then close it back up.
You now have a fly farm.
The flies will buzz around and upon hitting the grate, will fall out  
the opening in to your pond, where you have a bunch of Tilapia ready  
to eat them.

Another variant is to have a secure compost pile where you throw all  
your food scraps, and populate it with worms.
Then you feed the worms to the catfish in the barrels right next to  
the worm farm.

You and your dog now live on fish.

--
"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
AIM:IMFDUP

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Fri)

Is it Friday already?

So I was in a ratty 7-Eleven getting gas yesterday and I don't know if =20
I've told you guys this but pretty much starting after I read that =20
book "Spychips" all about RFID and shit, I pay cash for everything =20
that's not bills or a big ticket item in which case I'll use a credit =20
card, anyway, so I go to pay cash in this gas station, 7-eleven thing, =20
and there's this weird girl in there wearing gas mask insert glasses, =20
a nascar jacket and had a dont mess with texas flag on her truck, or =20
something, anyway, the female version of tacky redneck from hell, =20
she's taking forever telling her story of what kind of glasses she's =20
wearing, I'm hoping sometime I can pay my money and start pumping, and =20
then this lady from the Pizza Hut (she was wearing the uniform) next =20
door starts talking to me, she says in a really loud, manly voice

"HI, HOW YOU DOING?"

and I replied, "fine."

then she said "well I'm just gettin my caffeine fix," holding up a =20
tiny bottle of some kind of jolt caffeine in a vial type of crap they =20
sell at the counter.

so I said really loudly, "WELL YEA THAT'S GOOD, YEA!" with my right =20
hand at my hip and nodding.  i do that a lot these days, we kind of =20
mock this other guy we work with and i guess it's kind of like an =20
inside joke but it's generic enough where you guys might get it and it =20
was just kind of funny because it was a show stopper in the 7-eleven.  =20
well everyone went silent for just a minute and kind of stared at me =20
and cocked their heads about 3 degrees, not as much as a cocker =20
spaniel but definitely noticeable.

the conversation was over after that, unfortunately the gas pump =20
wasn't working, they switched me to another pump, and when i went back =20
in to get my change, it took like 10 minutes.  so 30 minutes later =20
i've got a full tank.  i guess the price of being anonymous in a world =20
of talking big brother cameras and forced HPV vaccines.

this was all on the way to my anger management class.  more on that =20
later.  have a nice weekend.  DF out

Constitution - taking from the federal government their power of
borrowing.

Perfection. You may try Flies From The Windscreen as a
starter. I'd recommend them tomorrow, But Not Tonight.

Cider or have absolutely Nothing...

guests will be required to Leave in Silence.

ah, but there ARE other energy sources in the cycle.  don't forget  
sunlight, and air, and water... those are all energy input sources.  
the trick is to create a closed loop system that catches and stores  
all those inputs.

read up on Permaculture design for more techniques.

-philip-

ps> don't forget to compost your own poop and feed it to your worms

> for the amount of fish required to feed me and my dog, I don't  
> think worms (or flies) can be raised quickly enough.  Energy cannot  
> be created or destroyed; recycling is grate, but there has to be  
> other sources in the cycle.
