> At 07:44 PM 3/22/2007, Nathan Seven wrote:
>> As in:
>>
>> You build a little sealed enclosure filled with shallow drainable
>> trays and a bug-zapper grate over a narrow slit..
>> You have a pipe going in to the top with a sealable opening.
>> Catch some flies and put them inside.
>> Every time you or your dog takes a shit, smush it up and throw it in
>> to the pipe along with some water, then close it back up.
>> You now have a fly farm.
>> The flies will buzz around and upon hitting the grate, will fall out
>> the opening in to your pond, where you have a bunch of Tilapia ready
>> to eat them.
>>
>> Another variant is to have a secure compost pile where you throw all
>> your food scraps, and populate it with worms.
>> Then you feed the worms to the catfish in the barrels right next to
>> the worm farm.
>>
>> You and your dog now live on fish.
>>
>> --
>> "Jupiter accepts your offer..."

On Fri, 23 Mar 2007, Philip.X.Diaz wrote:
-&e->ah, but there ARE other energy sources in the cycle.  don't forget
-&e->sunlight, and air, and water... those are all energy input sources. the
-&e->trick is to create a closed loop system that catches and stores all those
-&e->inputs.
-&e->
-&e->read up on Permaculture design for more techniques.
-&e->
-&e->-philip-
-&e->
-&e->ps> don't forget to compost your own poop and feed it to your worms

Philip, if I pooped in your composter, your worms would get sick or high.

And really, wind, hydroelectric, gas, coal, oil, are all solar energy.  
The biggest problem we get into is not that we use oil or anything like 
that, it's the amount we use.  And it's tough to stop.  Most people love 
thier cars.  I love class A tube guitar amps.  Other people love their 
TVs.  All this goes on with us not even thinking about the cost.  If we 
had to ride exercise bikes to generate that power, we'd give up a lot of 
stuff fast.  And we be healthier.

andyw

On Fri, 23 Mar 2007, Philip.X.Diaz wrote:
-&e->post of the fucking year, right there.

I like it, but it's almost all more recent DM song names.  I always feel 
the early Vince Clarke stuff gets the dick, which sucks cause he's what 
made early DM -> Yaz -> Erasure songs so damn catchy (and really, the guy 
has an extremely unique style that carried over a lot of very innovative 
work).

Feh, all this cruft took me back tho when Richard Blade was the morning DJ 
at KROQ, Rodney used to take us into the weekends.  If it ever got too 
wonky, I'd switch up to KUCI which was playing the best punk ever (exposed 
me to vandals, dri, suicidal tendencies, dead kennedys, all that crap).  
I used to give a shit about radio.  Life in a pre Clear Channel world.

I know part of it is just nostalgia, but I don't see 14 year olds boinging 
around to Smashmouth, My Chemical Romance or Britney even close to the 
same thing.

So as a funny side note, I was asked last minute to accompany a friend of 
mine to last weeks My Chemical Romance show in Oakland (someone had 
purchased their kid tickets and then they couldn't go).  I'd seen their 
videos, they were postured, overdressed, and their latest release is 
supposed to be this "rock opera" concept kinda thing.  I figured, it would 
be funny, I'd take BART and just get super stoned.  Except when I got 
there, I realized the kids in the row behind us were there with their 
parents.  And I realized that by my actions I was determining this kid's 
future ability to attend rock shows through their parents perception.  So 
I stayed mostly sober as a judge (had a couple $8 beers...).

And we watched this band that was somewhere between Queen, NIN and like a 
junior version of the New York Dolls.  And yeah, it was horrible.  But the 
songs were about rebellion and self awarenesss, the fists came in the air, 
kids sang along at the top of their lungs with the words they knew by 
heart, the girls screamed, and I guess it was almost like the real thing.  
If the band don't know they're bullshit, and the kids don't know they're 
bullshit, then I guess it's not bullshit after all.

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________
I'm coming down fast but I'm miles above you.

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] self-sustainability was Re: [sfraves] Pet Food Scandal

neither worms not flies take energy (for livelihood, flies do fly) 
from the sun, the air,. or from water.  I'd need something else to 
feed them, and so many, I might as well have cattle.  I'm not saying 
recycling is bad, or that we shouldn't do all we can, just that 
cutting myself and my pets from the food grid is nearly impossible, 
in an urban environment, as it is now.

At 09:46 AM 3/23/2007, Philip.X.Diaz wrote:
>ah, but there ARE other energy sources in the cycle.  don't forget
>sunlight, and air, and water... those are all energy input sources.
>the trick is to create a closed loop system that catches and stores
>all those inputs.
>
>read up on Permaculture design for more techniques.
>
>-philip-
>
>ps> don't forget to compost your own poop and feed it to your worms
>
>
>On Mar 23, 2007, at 7:09 AM, Sarilion wrote:
>
>>for the amount of fish required to feed me and my dog, I don't
>>think worms (or flies) can be raised quickly enough.  Energy cannot
>>be created or destroyed; recycling is grate, but there has to be
>>other sources in the cycle.
>>
>>
>>sarilion
>>
>>At 07:44 PM 3/22/2007, Nathan Seven wrote:
>>>As in:
>>>
>>>You build a little sealed enclosure filled with shallow drainable
>>>trays and a bug-zapper grate over a narrow slit..
>>>You have a pipe going in to the top with a sealable opening.
>>>Catch some flies and put them inside.
>>>Every time you or your dog takes a shit, smush it up and throw it in
>>>to the pipe along with some water, then close it back up.
>>>You now have a fly farm.
>>>The flies will buzz around and upon hitting the grate, will fall out
>>>the opening in to your pond, where you have a bunch of Tilapia ready
>>>to eat them.
>>>
>>>Another variant is to have a secure compost pile where you throw all
>>>your food scraps, and populate it with worms.
>>>Then you feed the worms to the catfish in the barrels right next to
>>>the worm farm.
>>>
>>>You and your dog now live on fish.
>>>
>>>--
>>>"Jupiter accepts your offer..."
>>>AIM:IMFDUP
>>>
>>>

   (Pass along if you can!)   Adam, also known as Atom Weaver, or DJ Oracle, of Omniscient Records designed a really amazing bluetooth headset for girls/women. When you wear it it appears as a flower worn in your hair/behind your ear, with the microphone suggestive of a blossoming twig extending from the bloom, across your cheek, to your mouth. The flowers are also interchangeable to match your outfit day-to-day.   There's nothing out there like it. In fact, I haven't really seen any bluetooth headsets that are specifically marketed toward women, other than those merely splashing pink paint on a previous design. They can do better than that and Adam did! :)   Anyway, his school is having a competition and if he wins, he gets a $20,000 scholarship *AND* his design will go into production with Motorola, which means you can get one yourself.   Please vote for Adam's "The Bloom" (link: http://www.nxzen.com/designcontest/view.php?p=3 ) for his sake--- and mine. Haha. I'm dying to get one, especially with the new California law that restricts cell phone calls while driving to hands-free devices only. We all (...well, us girls...) need this!   SO VOTE! :D Adam's is much more innovative than the other designs. He really deserves to win this. Help him out!   http://www.nxzen.com/designcontest/view.php?p=3   Thanks for the support! 
 Heart, Alida

Last Week's Shoddy Mix / Digg These Stories / Solar Storm 2012 /  
Internet Radio Streaming Ruling / Inflation / Rosie O'Donnell on  
9-11 / Charlie Sheen One Year Anniversary / HR 1022 Gun Ban Bill /  
NAU Slideshow / On Ron Paul for President / Mix

minutes long.  BTW speaking of last week's shoddy mix this week ...  
well let's just say it's a good thing to listen to what I'm putting  
out.  I don't know that any DJ can be totally satisfied with what  
they record but hey it's all a learning experience.

1.  KCM Project - Da Sleaze
2.  Pete Moss - Infra-dub
3.  The Rurals - Green
4.  Paste - Windhose
5.  Skool Phunk - Whistle Work
6.  Frank Dubois - Hats Off

9.  Underground Science - Reflected
10.  Rob Rowland - Long Distance
11.  Mosaic - X-Rated President
12.  Various Textures Pt. 2 - Together Now
13.  Wyatt Earp - Beachcomber

X-Greylist: Sender IP whitelisted, not delayed by milter-greylist-2.0.2 (kzsu.stanford.edu [127.0.0.1]); Sun, 25 Mar 2007 11:30:28 -0700 (PDT)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NYPD spied on Bands Against Bush & other groups before 2004 RNC

--0-1680677066-1174847359=:48271
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=WINDOWS-1252; FORMAT=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
Content-ID: <20070325112948.B48271@kzsu.stanford.edu>

City Police Spied Broadly Before G.O.P. Convention

http://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/25/nyregion/25infiltrate.html

From=20Albuquerque to Montreal, San Francisco to Miami, undercover New
York police officers attended meetings of political groups, posing as
sympathizers or fellow activists, the records show.

They made friends, shared meals, swapped e-mail messages and then
filed daily reports with the department's Intelligence Division. Other
investigators mined Internet sites and chat rooms...

These included members of street theater companies, church groups and
antiwar organizations, as well as environmentalists and people opposed
to the death penalty, globalization and other government policies.
Three New York City elected officials were cited in the reports.

In at least some cases, intelligence on what appeared to be lawful
activity was shared with police departments in other cities. A police
report on an organization of artists called Bands Against Bush noted
that the group was planning concerts on Oct. 11, 2003, in New York,
Washington, Seattle, San Francisco and Boston. Between musical sets,
the report said, there would be political speeches and videos.

"Activists are showing a well-organized network made up of anti-Bush
sentiment; the mixing of music and political rhetoric indicates
sophisticated organizing skills with a specific agenda," said the
report, dated Oct. 9, 2003. "Police departments in above listed areas
have been contacted regarding this event."

Police records indicate that in addition to sharing information with
other police departments, New York undercover officers were active
themselves in at least 15 places outside New York =97 including
California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Massachusetts,
Michigan, Montreal, New Hampshire, New Mexico, Oregon, Tennessee,
Texas and Washington, D.C. =97 and in Europe...

The Bands Against Bush site doesn't seem to be up, but here is what it
looked liked in Nov. of 2004

http://web.archive.org/web/20041105095310/www.bandsagainstbush.org/mt-again=
stBush/

and a permanent link for the article

http://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/25/nyregion/25infiltrate.html?ex=3D133247520=
0&en=3Db3a5c0cbb8a69e66&ei=3D5090&partner=3Drssuserland&emc=3Drss



http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: My Sat Night/ Sun Morn Adventure

OK.. so i'm kinda warming up here in my absence of my WRs.. ';cause I
looked @ my photo album & realized i hadn't been really posting them & I
seriously feel like i been commiting sin.. so for refresher WR, I'm gonna
talk about what i did this past weekend...

So alota y'all know that I been keeping house pretty much for the past 2
weeks by myself 'cause Mops & Pops went on a 2 week cruise through South
America... & like well.. i was kinda broke until like this past
Friday/Saturday & was pretty much in hell  'cause I didn't have money for
bart & couldn't make it out to where i need to in the previous days i
needed to be & stuff, Hello 2day...

Well... I figured like, "Well... i should walk to the gas station & take
care of my nic & caffine fits".. so i did!  Some of y'all who brought me
home know how far the gas staation is from my pad, so yeah.. it was a nice
2 1/2 mile walk :)

So i had ipod w/ me & took a brisk walk in the early late night/ early
morn... got to the gas station & there were these drunk people hangin out
outside.. after i got my stuff, the drunk girl came up & spoke to me.. her
name is dara & she was this model for hot tropic nights or something..
lol... & she was drunk, so drunk!  She told me about how her & her pose
went bar hopping all over the East Bay from Walnut Creek to Berk & ended
up @ her house in Hercules, then her & drunk dude friend w/ cool piercings
went to the gas station to keep Ben, the worker dude, company!

Anywaze.. so she ended up taking me back to her pad where there were more
drunk people!  Drunk dude guy w/ the cool peircings, actually
http://www.myspace.com/sk4v3ng3r  is his myspace, his GF was in the Family
room swirling around in circles to punk music, dara's bf was in the
kitchen drinking & laughing @ the magnets, & this other girl was there
making puking sounds, but couldn't yak... but yeah.. it was fun getting to
know these people!!  LoL... Dara & i talked alot about like going out,
DJs, & like music... so yeah.. she wants to hang out al next weekend w/ me
'cause i told her where i;ll be going, Evil Breaks & RAW in Sac, & yeah..
so i found a new party hopper to cause mayhem w/ me!

So yeah.... after a few vodka shots, well.. a lot of vodka shots & alot
more talk... all the Drunkie were sleepie & I took that as my que to head
out!  So i actually walked home & the walk was like sooo much longer than
from the gas station... but it was nice tbh!

LoL.. so yeah... that was kinda random & fun!!  But yeah... while i was
gone, my Mom called & left a message on the answering machine saying they
docked in Fla & were boarding a bus to go Miami airpot... LoL... so i
kinda freaked out 'cause well.. there was still a lil more cleaning in the
house i needed to do... didn't get to sleep 'til 9:30AM ('cause I wanted
to watch the Fairly Odd Parents movie on Nick ;)  BUt yeah... that was my
Weekend pretty much!!!

So anywaze... i shall see some of you throughout the week then on the
weekend!!!  I got al whoel lot to catch up on postingwise & a few
CandyFly/ Osby adventures!  Love U all!!!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] Sound Equipment/Gear for sale

------=_Part_44227_30368884.1174945629011
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

If you, or anyone you know is looking for more sound reinforcement, please
pass this info along to them  :)    Most of the equipment listed below is
fairly new, we don't have any set prices, but we'll consider any reasonable
offer.

2 Yorkville LS1208P 18" hornloaded subwoofers.  Some minor scratches,
purchased new in spring 2006, have only been used at 3 parties.  These bad
boys kick and run perfect with the QSX plx-3602 putting out 3600 watts of
bass. Please note, these speakers have the heavy duty paint/lacqeur and not
the carpet.  They retail at just under $1000/each.  If you went to last
years 3 year anniversary, you've heard them run at about half their
potential.  For the price, you wont find a sub that puts out this much
bass!  If you need speakon speaker cables, we have these too.

QSC plx-3602    This badboy puts out a whopping 3600 watts in bridge mono
and weighs in at an amazing 22lb.  Has only been used at 3 parties to power
the LS1208's above.  Will consider a package deal with the yorkville
LS1208's.  The PLX-3602 sells for $1200 at guitar center.  purchased new
spring 2006

1 Yorkville LS700PB  powered subwoofer.  Two 10" woofers pack a powerful
punch in this compact powered sub.  Very portable, and weighs in at only
90lb and puts out 700watts.  Retails for $840.  purchased new spring 2006


Please email  BENHAUS@GMAIL.COM

Date: Mon, 26 Mar 2007 17:07:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Message-ID: <387303.13861.qm@web32104.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] UR in SF, Saturday, March 23, DJ S2 from Underground Resistance + Jonah Sharp w/ Mr. Projectile

for those who know...

Saturday, March 31, 2007, 10pm till 4am

downtown SF

Bassaholics Anonymous, Peoplemuver and Subversive
Soundz, present:

UR in SF

Santiago Salazar
(Underground Resistance, Los Hermanos, Galaxy 2
Galaxy, Planet E)
FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!

Jonah Sharp with Mr Projectile
(Reflective) (Semisexual)
LIVE HARDWARE TECHNO SET!

Support from:

James Bass
(Bassaholics Anonymous)

Tomkat
(Subversive Soundz)

ADMISSION:	$10 at the door, $8 in advance

Limited Presale tix available at
bassaholicsanonymous.com

Santiago Salazar, aka DJ S2,is a core member of the
Underground Resistance 'family' of Detroit electronic
artists. Underground Resistance,  also known as UR,
has been on the cutting edge of techno, electro, and
funk representing the Detroit sound the world over.
The Underground  Resistance roster has included such
known fugitives as Jeff Mills, Robert Hood, Dj Rolando
and Mike Banks. Santiago is a core member of the
Galaxy 2 Galaxy and Los Hermanos live UR bands, and
has mixed and edited several UR 12 inches.
His production alias S2 has added a new direction to
the classic UR catalog described as experiments in
acid-funk and creative sampling.  Currently, as  Ican,
Salazar has been releasing quality dance music on Carl
Craig's Planet E label.

Techno innovator Jonah Sharp has recorded several
albums and EPs as Spacetime Continuum and played an
important role in the 90's in consolidating the global
experimental ambient and techno scene through his
Reflective Records imprint.  While his work has been
split over a number of different project headings
(Emit Ecaps, Alien Community, Reagenz, Electro
Harmonix, and others), his most consistently visible
work has been as Spacetime Continuum, most of which
was released by Astralwerks in the US.  He has
performed live electronic music all over the world
including a slot at the very first Detroit Electronic
Music Festival in 2000 curated by Carl Craig and on
Mount Fuji in front of 18,000 people during an insane
torrential rain storm. He has done many fantastic club
nights and is fondly remembered for dropping an "Ass
Bomb" monthly at club 6, bringing out much great
Detroit music.

Mr. Projectile, otherwise known as Matt Arnold,  is an
innovative fusionist of irreverent IDM syncopation.
His work has been released on mass imprints like !K7,
as well as buried labels like Topscore, in addition to
Merck, Toytronic, and his own Semisexual. Mr.
Projectile's live shows summon loft, anti-gravity and
height. For those who have ever pondered the word
"Dance" in Intelligent Dance Music, we challenge you
to witness the sheer brilliance of Mr. Projectile.

Jonah Sharp and Mr. Projectile will be playing a live
all hardware gear set.  Those who heard their set at
1015 last month say it is not to be missed.

James Bass was born inside a bassbin at Castlemorton
Free festival then taken, adopted really by Cuban
parents and sent to the finest socialist education in
the world.  Somehow he ended up washed ashore in San
Francisco at a Reclaim the Streets party dropping mad
leftist booty.  He has been dropping beats on the bay
for the last several years under the name Sexaholic
BassBot, but has stepped into his own as the son of
Bass, respect.

Tomkat, born under a black sun, was orphaned at birth
and was adopted and raised by an alley cat on Albion
Street.  He began his dj career in a truck container
somewhere in Oakland at an early FnF party, and has
played everywhere from radical soup kitchens to the
middle of the street outside the metreon.  


CONTACT FOR MORE INFORMATION: 1-800-350-3719
bassaholicsanonymous.com

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Alameda late night event cancelled

Alameda torpedoes 'lust, libation' party

Chip Johnson

Tuesday, March 27, 2007

It was to be a night of "lust, libation and laughter," according to
the promoter's Web site, a first-ever Spring Shwing in an old Navy
hangar in Alameda.

Think Exotic Erotic Ball. The same folks who have staged the wildly
popular Halloween-time bash in San Francisco were setting up a
six-hour party planned for this Saturday.

But three weeks ago, it all went poof, like Cinderella's ball.
Partygoers will have to settle for March Madness highlights instead.

On March 9, Alameda city officials notified John Walker, who leases
the space from the city, that the event license had been denied and
the party was canceled.

"The event you have proposed would involve adult entertainment, last
until 3 a.m., include serving alcohol and be open to the members of
the general public through ticket sales over the Internet," wrote City
Manager Debra Kurita, who also serves as executive director of the
Alameda Reuse and Redevelopment Authority.

In other words, the event -- which promised to include "erotic
burlesque, exotic dance, circus sideshows, playful interactive fun,
plus fantasy, fetish and all-out naughtiness" -- was just a bit too
lusty for the East Bay's island city.

The city manager went on to say in her letter that "it is not
generally the policy of the ARRA to lease or license buildings or
space for large evening events open to the general public, especially
those that include the serving of alcohol, live or amplified music or
live entertainment."

The only exceptions to the city's rule have been parties aboard the
Hornet, a decommissioned aircraft carrier at the former base, that
include alcohol and live music and, in some cases, go on well beyond
midnight. The flight deck can accommodate up to 3,000 people.

"That entity has its own use permit and the ARRA has no authority over
them," Lisa Goldman, a deputy city manager, offered Monday.

But the city's decision to reject the Spring Shwing has spawned
finger-pointing from Walker and event promoter Howard Mauskopf -- and
niggling suspicions that the adult theme and promise of scant costumes
played a role in the outcome of this one.

Still, just about every other sentence in city officials' explanations
of the decision in recent days has included the phrase "nothing to do
with content."

Walker, a veteran promoter who goes back to the early days of Bill
Graham-sponsored events, says the confusion is easy enough to explain.

"He (Mauskopf) marketed the show on the Internet before I had a chance
to make a presentation to the city -- or call my landlord, and a few
other people," Walker said Monday. He said he was not provided with
information to answer obvious questions about security, parking -- or
ticket sales.

"I had nothing to propose to them. Ticket sales? I don't know.
Security, parking, I got nothing from them," Walker added.

In a phone interview Monday from Los Angeles, Mauskopf said he
believed he had entered into a contractual agreement with Walker and
expects to be compensated for his expenses. He said Walker has
received a signed contract from him, but has not yet returned it with
his signature.

"Contract law and John are not in sync," Mauskopf said. Walker
disputes the assertion.

Whether a contract exists could well become a legal matter, but city
officials said they learned of the dance when it was advertised via
the Internet.

"They never applied for anything, and we heard tickets were being sold
on the Internet and that's when we got involved," Goldman said. If so,
organizers would have learned that the cards were pretty much stacked
against them from the start.

The proposed dance would have violated a city policy that requires
quiet hours at the base between 12:30 a.m. and 5 a.m. Police received
a license request for the site in mid-March and although they didn't
have adequate time to investigate thoroughly, a cursory review raised
concerns, Lt. Art Fuentes said Monday.

"We looked at what they were proposing, we saw the Internet ads, and
when we spoke with the promoter he could not give us an estimate on
the size of the event," Fuentes said. "We did some checking with other
(police) agencies and discovered that events like this usually require
large police staffing, and there has been a history of tailgate
parties, public drunkenness and sexual assaults."

Alameda is known for a lot of things, but being San Francisco's sister
city isn't one of them. It's described by some of its own residents as
a stodgy, old-fashioned place with a Midwestern atmosphere, not to
mention some lingering conservative political leanings. And they seem
to like it that way.

That's all right, because not every city in the Bay Area has to become
a miniature version of the city by the bay. Not all people who live
outside San Francisco aspire to live there or take their cues from the
latest fashion or cultural trend born there.

And it seems unlikely that a potentially wild event like a Spring
Shwing would fit in a city that sees itself as a small-town enclave
surrounded by an urban skyline.

--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Alameda late night event cancelled

Having lived in Alameda the majority of my life, I can attest that the 
"content" did not have anything to do with the permit being denied.  No 
event, wether the Hookers Ball, or the HHHH club veggie-feed dinner and show 
would be permitted to go until 3am in Alameda.  Selling hard alchohol ?  It 
better be over by 10pm and then only if it's the annual Elk's Lodge 
fundraiser dance.

Nope, this is a sleepy, sleepy town and they like it that way.  If you think 
they objected to the event because of the content, you are surely right, but 
don't think this is singling out just this event.  Anything racier than the 
current showing of Beauty & The Beast at the old Alameda Theatre would get a 
sneer eye by the government officials and base re-use committee.

I've spent probably 70 cumulative hours writing letters and speaking with 
officials over the phone just to get the reuse commity to allow a grassroots 
low-speed driving event to held there - with zero progress.  Again, the 
annual 50's car show down park street with only Beer & Wine sales, all over 
by 4PM is more this towns speed.

It's part of the charm as well as the frustration with living here.

While growing up I thought "oh, these old farts will die off eventually" but 
I now realize that the only people who stay in Alameda are those hopeful few 
like me who like it's sleepiness and central location and enjoy driving 
across a short bridge or two for my excitment, and those who never want it 
to change.  You can guess the latter are the ones who will forever man the 
stations of the Alameda local government.

Bottomline is this was stereotypical behavior of Alameda and shouldn't be 
considered an issue relating to the "adult" orientation.


Lucky 13 is g r a t e !

-=dave

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Alameda late night event cancelled

Interestingly, when parties had outdoor sound systems
at Home Base, the OPD would often get noise complaints
from the island. We actually had to turn off the
outside sound system we were running at Mega Buzz one
year due to the noise complaints...

As a funny aside... We never had an outside sound
system at our parties at Home Base. But, we succeeded
in getting the most noise complaints from Alameda...
from the RIDICULOUS sound systems INSIDE. Ahhhhh...
the good ole days, when during sound-check, you could
stand in the middle of the room, and watch your
clothes twitch and dance because of the massive amount
of air moving around due to the BASS...

E

From sfraves-return-138349-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Mar 28 09:14:34 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-138349-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 96015 invoked by uid 1103); 28 Mar 2007 09:14:32 -0000

Received: (qmail 95996 invoked from network); 28 Mar 2007 09:14:31 -0000
Date: Wed, 28 Mar 2007 02:14:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>
cc: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <206169.58313.qm@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0703272031150.9439@atari>
References: <206169.58313.qm@web36805.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Alameda late night event cancelled


On Tue, 27 Mar 2007, Eric Spire wrote:
-&e->As a funny aside... We never had an outside sound
-&e->system at our parties at Home Base. But, we succeeded
-&e->in getting the most noise complaints from Alameda...
-&e->from the RIDICULOUS sound systems INSIDE. Ahhhhh...
-&e->the good ole days, when during sound-check, you could
-&e->stand in the middle of the room, and watch your
-&e->clothes twitch and dance because of the massive amount
-&e->of air moving around due to the BASS...

Glory days Eric.
(the following is pure fiction)

I miss dropping the needle on a fresh out of the mailbox test pressing and 
inching up a fader connected to a semi and a half worth of sound gear in 
front of several thousand people.  <Jon Stewart> On weed. </Jon Stewart>

My favorite was how Thunder and Lightning and sometimes JK used to set up 
their stages, with a seperate rise for the DJ to stand on so you could 
dance your ass off while DJing and not cause record skip.  :)

I miss MP-24s with the dip in the crossfader and no EQ per channel and 
headphone cues that could fry an egg.

I miss monitors that took two people to lift.

I miss cutting out a record and hearing a warehouse full of people's feet 
pogoing on dusty concrete for a second.

I miss running into people I'd only seen in magazines or record stores 
trying to get Stacy or Vlad to pay me.

I miss crew laminates.

I miss a whole chill room cooing along in bliss to a melody from my first 
chill room live PA.

I miss the jog I used to take around Jack London Square first couple times 
I played at 2nd and Jax to take the nerves off.

I miss prop making parties in my back yard.

I miss the way it sounded when a DJ I didn't know dropped one of my tracks 
on a big system.

I miss thinking about how much wood you need to build a frame for a giant 
mylar covered ufo.

I miss having a paper macheie mushroom in the front yard of Cupertino 
Heights (the old house) for months.

I miss being able to go all weekend and still somehow wake up for work on 
monday.

I miss ridiculous Rainbow Brite lookalikes grabbing my wrist to adorn me 
with candy while I play some scorching evil shit.

I miss hearing a new record on a big sound system and going to the store 
on monday after work and seeing if they had another copy cause I just 
loved it that much loud.

I miss my brown NeverWorry hoodie.

I miss the records they stole.

I miss being in the checkout line at Home Depot as they ring up $2100 in 
extension cords, staple guns, steel cable & turnbuckles, fire 
extinguishers, zip ties, tools and day glo flag twine... wearing JNCOs and 
sunglasses and paying cash.

I miss reviews where people would go on about what a great time they had, 
and how it was ridiculously cheap and obviously done for the love.

I love calling up and asking for "two of the biggest trucks you got for a 
class C licence".

I love getting my gear home and realizing some guy I have 15 records from 
just played on those turntables and that mixer *right there*.

I miss getting a contract rider from a DJ that said "Overnight 
Accomodations: Prepaid single occupancy hotel preferred, but couch (no 
scabies, no fleas) is acceptable".

I miss the sound of a room full of people that couldn't think of leaving 
early cheering as we open up the side doors of the armory to let the 
sunrise in.

I miss the morbid humor of cleanup by a posse of jaded people who are 
beyond exhaustion.

I miss the look on everybody's face when you'd bring cold non-shwaggy beer 
to a particularly hot warehouse setup.

I don't miss shady dealers, hypocritical promoters, sellout bitch DJs, 
groupies who just don't listen, people who had a narrow mind to any 
deviation from their agenda, kids with saucers for pupils and varying 
symptoms of malnutrition, dehydration and mental distress all over their 
faces.  I don't miss kicking people out, turning kids away, inter promoter 
political shibby, and fire marshalls who want grease.  I don't miss $3 
water or a total doublespeak when people throwing parties called 
"MegaBuzzOnE" claimed to not allow drugs in or even throw raves (it's a 
festival... of OnE-ness I guess).  I don't miss city officials lying about 
permits processes, or what they are and are not ok with.  I don't miss the 
acts, I don't miss the hype, I don't miss all the people who had so much 
to say when they were just wearing furry overalls a couple months before 
(yes, myself included).  I don't miss having to work with people who were 
all love and smiles and you couldn't trust for a second.  I didn't like 
Vlad sometimes, but sometimes I disliked his detractors even more.  I 
didn't like being told that this door must be kept unlocked by one person 
that can shut your party down, and must be locked by another with the same 
abilities.  I didn't like how massives would tear collectives apart and 
force them to pick less and less people who could be trusted with so much.  
I didn't like the point in time after you'd paid so much money out that 
you couldn't not throw the party.  I didn't like investors.  I didn't like 
weird messages on the voicemail threatening us.  I didn't like having to 
watch my gear like a hawk when I'd play live.  I don't miss the people 
that used this list for promotion but couldn't tell the truth about the 
same parties they were promoting.  I didn't like being handed a backpack 
and being told cops are here, act like you paid to get in.  I never liked 
having to explain to a cop what was going on here, when they knew and I 
knew and it was a funny little sparring match.  I never liked the radical 
difference between what we were held accountable for, and what we actually 
had control over.  I never liked paramedics taking away that kid.  Never 
was a big fan of how a couple of the local clubs would slam raves for 
being unsafe and illegal.  Never did like Maritime Hall (although the 
little Filipino karaoke across the street was THE PRE-SHOW BOMB).  Always 
thought it was funny that one of the people who argued most with me on the 
list would call me up and share party ideas to see what I thought.  I 
don't miss making a buck or two remastering and even editing other DJs 
"for promotional use" mixtapes (yeah, nice "skills" there).  I didn't like 
competing in an artistic circle for bookings with people who faked a lot 
of shit.  I never liked having to feel like a criminal because I wanted to 
throw a party that went after some peoples' bedtime.  Always felt weird 
about how a lot of the people who had the spotlight often didn't seem to 
love the music the way some of us did.  Never did feel right how some DJs 
changed their minds about what genre they felt like sharing while behind a 
cash register.  Never did like hoochies on flyers.  Never liked how 
massive promoters would shit on undergrounds, and to a lesser degree vice 
versa.  Never liked velvet ropes, vips, and people who got waved through.  
Never liked how often I'd see torches at afterparties.  Never did believe 
that Mars believed in the 8th frequency as much as he wanted others to.  
Never did like that sticky shit all over every single cable in the place 
by morning.  Never did like the fact that to do what you felt was right 
past a certain scale, you almost had to be in bed with the people who you 
felt did it wrong.  I didn't like it when DJ tapes and massive presales 
outsold records at my local record shop.  I don't miss seeing some of my 
friends go crazy, go deaf, or just go.  I didn't like seeing expensive 
water being sold at a party I volunteer crewed at.  Never liked seeing a 
pile of huge flyers on top of a storm drain.  Never liked the fact that if 
you couldn't afford to lose every penny you put into a party, you always 
ended up having to compromise somehow sooner or later.

Those were incredible times, we did amazing things, I never wanted it to 
end.  And I'm glad it did.

andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Alameda late night event cancelled

Glory days implies that I, like the character from
"Daized and Confused," sit around hoping beyond hope
that some day I will return to high school football
and throw the winning touchdown for the State
Championship. If this is how you see me Andy, you are
sadly mistaken. Although, from your editorialized
responses to many of my posts, I don't think it is
very un-clear, that for some reason, you don't like
me. I'll reply to that, and the rest, privately.

Glory, Gig-swapping, editing, 300K flyers, taking
credit for others accomplishments, paying people
shitty, doing $300K parties for $100K, investors, not
out-doing yourself at every opportunity: Those were
all things I forsook. Rumors, want, greed,
manipulation, envy, and jealousy may have colored me
otherwise. But, the rants of Harry Who? and anyone
else do not a person make. I sleep well knowing how I
treated and paid people, how far out-done each event
we ever did was, how seriously we took our REAL
mantras, and how gross the other side of the scene
was.

Like I said, the good-ole days. A time to remember
fondly. A time to remember as you wish. The PAST. But
for me, certainly not THE GLORY DAYS.


> Glory days Eric.
> (the following is pure fiction)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Alameda late night event cancelled


On Wed, 28 Mar 2007, Eric Spire wrote:
-&e->Glory days implies that I, like the character from
-&e->"Daized and Confused," sit around hoping beyond hope
-&e->that some day I will return to high school football
-&e->and throw the winning touchdown for the State
-&e->Championship. If this is how you see me Andy, you are
-&e->sadly mistaken. Although, from your editorialized
-&e->responses to many of my posts, I don't think it is
-&e->very un-clear, that for some reason, you don't like
-&e->me. I'll reply to that, and the rest, privately.

Erm, nope.  Read me totally wrong.  The "glory days" comment was my email 
equivalent of a knowing smile, "raising my beer can" if you will before 
waxing nostalgic myself.

I honestly figured maybe you and a handful of people would get this (there 
aren't that many people on this list who have DJed on big guns to 1000+ 
people, were involved with large parties in the late 90s, dealt with 
Homebase or 85th and Baldwin, etc).

At no point did I even come close to mentioning Harry Who, I never singled 
you out.  As for liking or not liking you... we've talked, never felt like 
you thought much of me but we had some good friends in common and that's a 
long way down the road from dislike.

I posted what I did because I didn't want to see people gush over how 
great the massives were without at least a semblance of the price.  They 
were a very two sided beast that ate too much and shat too much to 
possibly survive without a constant flow of new faces to feed it 
enthusiasm and $20s... while at the same time something of incredible 
power and occasionally even beauty.  I said what I said, in what I felt 
were clear words.  I'm glad I was there, but it didn't seem like it could 
go on like that for long.  Some promoters managed to sustain some degree 
of integrity through it (I'll go so far as to cite you and Martin), but 
most didn't.

peace

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________

Well I LIKE YOU BOTH & think YOU BOTH made COUNTLESS contributions to the scene we all cherish(ed). And while we're at it:

THANK YOU BUZZLINE. THANK YOU SF, OAKLAND, RICHMOND, SANTA CRUZ, SANTA ROSA, AND EVEN SAN JOSE. THANK YOU FTT, HARMONY, SKILLS, SPACE CHILDREN, CLOUD FACTORY, AND CLOCKWORK (DOWN THE LINE), JUST TO NAME A FEW. . .

Pack that in your pipes & smoke it, toke it, or choke it what have you.

BTW, Andy, I miss & don't miss the same shit you do. Seriously, you spoke for many. And props where due, Eric, I meant it when I said awhile back that one of your sets I saw @ Quest was of the highest caliber I've ever seen. 

peace

chuck

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Evil Breaks 3-Year Anniversary w/ Deekline & MC Ivory - Friday - Free

we just opened up another 100 guestlist spots for those that missed
out after the first 400 spots filled up.  we don't want anyone to have
an excuse not to come out.

hope to see some of the SFR family out at this one!

--
Evil Breaks 3 Year Anniversary Bash!!!!!
Friday, March 30th, 2007
FREE before 1130 w/Guestlist & only $10 after
door is $15 if you don't make the guest list
Located @ Whisper (535 Florida st @ Mariposa)
10pm - 4am
21+ w/ID


A great location, 10-4, a couple sick headliners, all the Evil Breaks
residents, all of your favorite locals, and a 400 person guest list!!!

yes we are crazy, so please, come help us celebrate our Anniversary
with style......


Our Headliners:

Deekline w/MC Ivory - UK
(Botchit & Scarper/Rat Records/Hardcore Beats)

Deekline started collecting records as a youngster, inspired by funk
and electro, before becoming interested in hardcore and jungle. His
first release was the immense "Don't Smoke (Da Reefer)", a bass-heavy,
two-stepping beat monster with the catchiest vocal line ever =96 it was
the first record put out on the newly-formed Rat Records, an imprint
which still continues to churn out top-quality releases at the
forefront of breaks and booty bass.

Further tracks with legends like Arthur Baker and Rennie Pilgrem and
other groundbreaking producers like Donna Dee and Freq Nasty sealed
Deekline's reputation as a leading light in the UK dance music scene =96
a reputation helped along by the chart success of "Don't Smoke", which
went to number 11 in the charts, and which led to Wu Tang Clan-member
and twisted genius Ol' Dirty Bastard asking for an official remix of
his track "Want Your Money".

At the same time, Deekline was livening up breaks in the UK, shaking
up the sedentary nu-skool scene and twisting out the fattest basslines
in the club nights he put together - Breakbeat Connection and Thursday
Night Throwdown, both of which are still among the best and most
exciting nights out to be had in the capital.


Evil Breakers:

Aaron Jae
Bam
M.O.D.
Athena


Our friends:

Mozaic
Kapt'n Kirk vs Evinrude
Melyss
Komega - Live PA
Redstickman vs Actual Rafiz (Matt Jakes Ghetto-tech tribute)
Jay Vigor vs Influence


Timeslots:

downstairs:

10-11 Jay Vigor & Influence
11-1145 Komega Live
1145-1245 Kirk & Evinrude
1245-130 Mozaic
130-215 Melyss
215-3 Redstickman & Actual Rafiq


upstairs:

11-12 M.O.D.
12-1245 Bam
1245-215 Deekline w/MC Ivory
215-3 Aaron Jae
3-4 Athena


Art on the walls provided by Faern

Midnight fire performances from some of the LSD Fuego kids.

You can sign up now @ www.EvilBreaks.com

--=20

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

Sunset is usually held in Marin County at Stafford
Lake in Novato and sometimes in SF at various
locations...

http://www.co.marin.ca.us/depts/PK/Main/pos/pdstaffordlke.cfm

starts at 11AM and goes until 7PM.

Rule reminders from the Pacific Sound crew:

They don't allow pets in the park and if you bring one
you won't be admitted.  Don't bring Fido.

The sherrif is going to be out there looking for drunk
drivers so designate a driver.  This always a good
idea anyway.

The park is a protected watershed so absolutely no
peeing in the bushes!  They have extra porta-poddies
this year, but I advise you to pee early and often to
avoid the lines ;)

Finally, smoking isn't allowed in Marin parks, but I
gather they don't intend to enforce this too much. 
Smoking in designated areas only.  Not sure how
they'll be designated tho!

As has been the case for at least a couple of years
the rangers are not sure they'll let the party
continue at this location if a lot of people are
breaking the rules, leaving trash, etc.  

Pix from last year's opener:
http://sunsets.tribe.net/photos/66111157-ffda-432f-ad4a-60ff52d68c0b

Peace,

Peter

P.S. Last time I saw Tony Hewitt spin was at the bar
Blue in Miami during WMC 2001!

Subject: [sfraves] The Image and the Real - An Upcoming Interactive Performance - April 7th

Mission Arts & Performance Project=20
Introduces
The Image and The Real

A RFCL Production


You are invited to enter an experimental space where creation will be =
taken
out of the hands of the elite few
and restored to the community.=20
Join us in the hospitality of L's Caf=E9 as we weave music and imagery,=20
improvised theatrics and sound into a seamless tapestry.

Where is the line between creator and created; observer and observed?

Within this unique gathering you will be asked to cross the line
and become an active element within a living work of art.

The music of Kyron sets the stage,
opening a chamber of childlike discovery, and prelinguistic expression.

You will be ushered in and invited to play by strange apparitions,
your guides in this twilight space between the Image and the Real.


This event is free and open to the public. Pay with your Presence.


Saturday, April 7th
Time 7pm-10pm
At L's Cafe
2871 24th St, San Francisco, 94110
www.lscaffe.net=20
(415) 206-0274


This event is a part of MAPP - Mission Arts and Performance Project.
For more information about MAPP, go here:
http://www.redpoppyarthouse.org/mappabout.html=20


For more information about RFCL and Black Note Music, go here:

http://www.sfbardo.com/rfcl.html

www.blacknotemusic.com=20


JC Mendizabal
Black Note Music
http://www.blacknotemusic.com
Via Sinistrae
www.viasinistrae.com
http://sinistrae.libsyn.com/
